PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
REGINA, SASK. June 27, 1939

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find voucher in triplicate in connection with the inspection of the J.I. Case boiler and the Loco. Return Tubular boiler both of which are located in the Cowesses Indian Residential School at Marieval, Sask., and were inspected under date of June 25th, 1939, by Government Boiler Inspector Auckland of Regina, Sask.

The fees for these inspections amount to $8.00. On receipt of your cheque covering same, we will be pleased to mail you the Inspection Certificates, which are on file in this Department.

Faithfully yours,

D. WEBSTER
Deputy Minister.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, July 7, 1939.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

Re Requisition dated April 13, 1939, for electric plant for Cowessess Indian Residential School.

With reference to Mr. Wardle's memorandum of May 29, addressed to Dr. McGill, I enclose copy of a letter just received from Indian Agent McKenzie. I enclose also letter received from the Principal of the Cowessess Residential School together with a rough diagram of the layout of the buildings and a communication received by the Principal from Mumford, Medland, Limited, dated March 25, 1939.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Memorandum:-

Mr. J. M. Wardle,

With reference to your memorandum of May 25th of 1939, to Dr. McGill regarding new lighting plant for the Cowessos Indian Residential School at Marioval, Sask. I now enclose copies of correspondence received from Mr. R. A. Hoey, containing information requested.

Will you please arrange to furnish at your early convenience the specification originally requested in Dr. McGill's memorandum of May 22nd, 1939, file 108-2-5, addressed to the Director of the Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

WMV/MLC

GOVERNMENT OF THE PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
STEAM BOILERS BRANCH

REGINA, SASK.

July 28, 1939.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your cheque for $8.00, covering the inspection fees of the Loco. Stationary boilers located in the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Mapleval, Saskatchewan. For which we thank you.

We accordingly enclose herewith the Inspection Certificates, which we trust will be found in order.

Faithfully yours,

D. WEBSTER
Deputy Minister.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, August 2, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I enclose the inspection certificates regarding the boilers at the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

Yours truly,

Encl.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend V. de Varenne, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Cowessess Residential School,
Marieval, via Grayson, Sask.
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Referring to my request made yesterday for twenty school desks for the Cowesses Indian Residential School, I am informed in a telegram from Father de Varennes that the desks which he now has in his school are from the Moyer Co. The sizes required are sixteen number 2 and four number 3 with two rears and two fronts.

As these desks are required for the opening of the school September 1st, I hope that your purchasing agent will be good enough to place the order immediately.

Please accept my sincere thanks for granting Fr. de Varennes' request so readily.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, C.M.I.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Hoey

In connection with the proposed installation of a Diesel electric lighting plant for the Cowesses Indian Residential School at Marieval, Saskatchewan, the question has arisen as to whether the contractor will install the unit or will the foundation block and labour for erection and installation be supplied by the Indian Affairs Branch.

I will be glad to have this information at your early convenience.

W.M. Bailey,
Departmental Purchasing Agent.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 15, 1939.

Re: Electric lighting plant,
Cowessess Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir:

This Branch is in receipt of a memorandum from the Purchasing Agent of the Department, which reads in part as follows:

"In connection with the proposed installation of a Diesel Electric Lighting Plant for the Cowessess Indian Residential School, Marienval, Sask., the question has arisen as to whether the contractor supplying the plant will install the unit or if the foundation block and labour is to be supplied by the Indian Affairs Branch or by the School Management."

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, is absent from the office on holidays. In his absence I have gone carefully over the files, and there is nothing on record here to indicate whether the contractor or the school management will undertake the installation of the plant. I should like to have information from you on this point at your earliest convenience.

I was somewhat surprised to learn that the request for this plant reached this Branch early in February. It would appear that the delay in making the purchase has been due almost wholly to our failure to secure sufficient information to satisfy the Purchasing Agent. Under existing purchasing regulations it is of the utmost importance that the fullest possible information with respect to the supplies ordered, their delivery and their installation be forwarded with the requisitions.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

E.A.F.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
Sir:-

Referring to your letter 108-2-5 of the 15th instant concerning installation of the electric light plant at the Cowessess I.R. School I yesterday visited the Revd. Principal and he advises me that in his specification which was forwarded on to Ottawa he made an allowance of $75.00 for labour installing this plant.

There is an electrician living within 4 miles of this school who has always done any work of this category which the Revd. Principal required, a Mr. Arthur Kendrick, whom he had in mind for the work and who is quite capable and whose charge would be far less than getting in a man from Regina or some outside point.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Eben. A. W. R. McKenzie
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.
REV V DE VARENNES OMI
PRINCIPAL
COWESSIES INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
MARIEVAL VIA GRAYSON SASK

R A HOEY

Indian Affairs,

GRAYSON SASK AUG 22-39
R A HOEY

SUPT WELFARE AND TRAINING INDIAN AFFAIRS, BRANCH OTTAWA ONT
ELECTRIC PLANT PROMISED LAST FEBRUARY NOT YET RECEIVED STOP AS SCHOOL WILL OPEN SEPTEMBER FIRST WOULD APPRECIATE SPECIAL EFFORT BEING MADE TO HAVE PLANT PURCHASED AND SHIPPED IMMEDIATELY STOP CONSIDER THIS MATTER SO URGENT THAT IF YOU ADVISE IT WILL COMMUNICATE DIRECTLY WITH THE MINISTER STOP COULD YOU ADVISE ME BY TELEGRAM COLLECT THE DECISION OF YOUR DEPARTMENT.

OMI PRINCIPAL COWESSIES INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Indian Affairs. (RG 1C, Volume 6303, file 651-5, part 5)
Ottawa,
August 23, 1939.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I am attaching hereto for your information copy of a letter received by this Branch from Mr. M.A.W.R. McKenzie, Crooked Lakes Agency, and also a copy of a telegram received from the Principal of the Cowessess Indian residential school. Both these communications, you will note, relate to the purchase of an electric lighting plant at the Cowessess residential school. It is my hope that you will be able to make arrangements for the delivery of this plant at the earliest possible date.

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,
August 23, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Electric lighting plant,
Cowessess residential school.

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant in which you supply additional information with respect to the installation of an electric lighting plant at the Cowessess Indian residential school.

In the first paragraph of your communication you state: "I yesterday visited the Rev. Principal. He advises me that in his specification which was forwarded to Ottawa he made an allowance of $75.00 for labour for installing this plant." I have made a detailed search of the file relating to the purchase of this plant and I have made a careful perusal of all the letters received from you and from the Principal with respect to the matter. The first letter from the Principal to you was dated Marieval via Grayson, Sask., February 12, 1939. There is no reference whatever in this communication to labour costs. May I refer you also to your letter to the Department dated February 13, 1939, your letter dated March 2, 1939 and your letter of April 1, 1939. No doubt you have on file copies of these letters and you will note that in none of these is there a reference to the $75.00 installation costs. In your letter dated June 28, 1939, you enclosed a letter from the Principal of the school together with a diagram of the building. You also sent forward a letter received by the Principal from the Mumford Medland Company Limited. Here again there was no reference to installation costs.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
In view of the delay experienced by the Principal in securing delivery of this plant it is altogether likely that the matter will be referred to the Minister for review and for whatever action he may deem necessary. Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division, is, at this date, absent from the office. The files here indicate that the delay, to some extent at least, has been due to the failure of the Principal and yourself to send forward the information requested by the Purchasing Branch. I am anxious, therefore, that you should send forward immediately particulars of the specification referred to in your letter of August 18. I am anxious to know if this particular specification was dated, the date it was sent forward and if it was sent forward with a covering letter and, if so, the date of the covering letter. When delays such as this occur it is, in my judgment, of the utmost importance that we should seek out and determine exactly the individual or individuals responsible for the delay. I feel confident that it will be the desire of the Minister that we should do so in this case.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

| Quantity | DESCRIPTION                                                                 | UNIT | TOTAL |
|----------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|------|-------|
| 1 only   | Diesel Electric Lighting Plant for the Cowesses Indian Residential School, Marieval, Sask. |      |       |

The plant will supply current for lighting only. It shall be fully automatic and shall consist of:

- One-vertical, 4-cycle, water-cooled Lister Diesel engine, 9 H.P., 1000 R.P.M., direct connected to a 5 K.W., 110 volt D.C. Generator, shunt wound for battery charging, similar or equal to Lister Type 52, with complete equipment including the following:

- Switchboard complete with all instruments and appliances necessary to control the unit.
- Fuel tank with capacity for 24 hours running.
- Fuel pipe
- Cooling water tanks & Piping
- Exhaust Silencer
- Foundation Bolts and template for setting same.
- Foundation plans for unit.
- Tools and spare parts customarily supplied for maintenance of engine.
- Storage Battery - one GLOBELITE Battery, G.D.11, consisting of 56 cells of 11 plates each having a capacity of 140 amperes hrs. at 10-hr. rating.

The above equipment and all labour necessary for installing same, including foundation, ready for operation (Sales Tax included)........$1,069.00 Net-

Prices F.O.B. Grayson, Sask., as per your tender of Aug. 26th.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter 109-2-5 of the 23rd ultimo and as the Revd. Principal of the Bowesean I. R. School was away in the States I was unable to see him until yesterday when I went down to the school.

It appears on his referring to his file that he went through the necessary particulars with Mr. McKenzie and on his pencil copy of his figures he has an allowance of $75.00 for installation but I am unable to find any record of this $75.00 being requisitioned for to Ottawa until mentioned in my letter of 16th August last and evidently this was omitted.

The Revd. Principal feels that this was an omission on Mr. McKenzie's part as he counted on it but states that the most important thing as far as he is concerned is to get the new plant and if this could be supplied at an early date as it is badly needed he would be willing to instal it etc. at his own expense rather than delay further.

Your obedient servant,

Wilfred J. B. Bell,
Agency Clerk.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I attach account covering cost of beds, springs, mattresses and pillows for the Cowessess Indian residential school.

It was found necessary to take in some deserving pupils immediately and the Principal was, therefore, authorized to purchase the items shown on the attached account in order that he could accommodate these children. I should appreciate your issuing purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding will be 76-12-415.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter 108-2-5 of the 27th ultimo and have to advise that the Revd. Principal of the Cowessess I.R. School informs me that one of the desks arrived with back broken, and in another the inkwell was broken.

He advised the company and they requested him to forward the freight receipt when they would deal with the matter.

He forwarded the same and has heard nothing further since.

He states that when the goods are satisfactory he will O.K. the account and then submit to me for vouchering.

Your obedient servant,

Wilfred J. B. Ball,
Agency Clerk.

Dear Sirs:

On August 24 last purchase order No. 27058 was forwarded to your firm to cover the purchase of desks for the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

Please let me know what action you intend to take with reference to the damage that was done to the desks in transit.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

CANADA
Broadview, Sask,
April 12th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Voucher #937 enclosed in favor of Dacoust & Cie, St Boniface, Man., for fire box etc., for Cowessess Indian Residential School, this account was received through the mail a day or so ago, from the Reverend Principal.

I could see no authority for this on file and there seems to have been some misunderstanding about the purchase.

Mr. McKenzie states that when the principal asked for these repairs he advised him to write, setting out the repairs needed, and upon receipt of this he would write the Department for authority to purchase.

Instead it appears that the Reverend Principal understood he had authority to buy the repairs, and did so.

As March 31st was the end of the fiscal year I thought it better to make a covering voucher and forward at once rather than causing delay in writing about the matter first.

If the account cannot be passed for payment, if you will return the voucher, I will advise the Reverend Principal accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

G.A. Havers,
Clerk in charge.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Memorandum

Doctor McGill

With reference to J.H.Ashdown Hardware Company's account dated the 28th Dec. 1939, for fire fighting equipment submitted with Mr. Hoey's letter of the 10th instant, File 108-2-5, I note that the amount involved ($167.29) is considerably in excess of the figure authorized for emergency purchases. I may add that the required equipment could have been bought through this office at a figure $18.50 lower, or at a saving of 11%.

Under the circumstances will you kindly advise why local purchase by the Indian Agent was authorized, instead of submitting requisition for the usual action by this office.

W.M.Bailey

CANADA
Dear Sir:

I am attaching Requisitions in triplicate for one range boiler for the Cowessess Indian Residential School, Crooked Lake Agency.

Mr. Havers, Clerk in Charge, advises me that Father de Verannes, Principal, has told him that the boiler now in use has been in service for over fifteen years and is now worn so thin that it has become dangerous. There are several holes in it and as soon as one hole is plugged, another appears.

The approximate price for a new boiler is $40.00 as listed in the catalogue of Marshall-Wells. It is evidently a case of buying a new boiler and I recommend that one be purchased.

If there is any question of furnishing this school with a new boiler, I hope to be there some time this Summer and will go into the matter of this old boiler and the need of a new one.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

Enc.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa,
May 31, 1940.

June 20, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to painting at the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

An amount of $575.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for purchase of new equipment, repairs and improvements at this school. We have already expended $207.00. This leaves a balance of $368.00.

It should be impressed on the Principal that the amount above stated is all that we will have to expend at the Cowessess School during the current fiscal year. Consequently if there is anything more urgent than the painting a request should be forwarded for obtaining it. If, however, the painting is considered the most important you may submit a requisition for the paint required. It is presumed that the school will supply the labour without cost to the Department.

With reference to your other letter of the 12th instant I may say that the Purchasing Agent took exception to some of the prices charged by the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company for fire extinguishers. Consequently there was some delay in having the account passed for payment. However, cheque No. 38906 for $167.29 was issued and sent to the Company on the 18th instant.

Yours truly,

Mr. G. A. Havers,
Clerk-in-Charge,
Indian Agency,
Broadview, Sask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Broadview, Sask., July 3rd, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Departmental letter #108-2-5 dated June 20 regarding the painting of Cowessess Indian residential school etc., I have received a letter today from the Principal in which he states that he considers that the foundation of the Farm Instructor's house, and also the foundations of the machine shed and harness room need some alteration for which a total amount of 25 sacks of cement will be required.

The Principal also asks for paint etc for painting the buildings, the total cost of which, including the cement would be $350.97. All prices are taken from Marshall Wells catalogue, Winnipeg prices.

Requisition for material required is attached and I would be glad if authority could be granted for these purchases at once as the children are now out on holidays and the work should be proceeded with as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The grainery at the Cowessess Residential School is in very poor condition and is infested with rats, the Rev. Principal is asking that it be reshingled and remodeled. This is particularly necessary this year owing to the increase in the coarse grains acreage.

I have secured quotations on the material required from the Security Lumber Co., Ltd., Broadview, and this amounts to $150.00. The Rev. Principal, however, states that if he be permitted to purchase this material from St. Lazare, Man., he could get it for $125.00. If this was satisfactory to the Department you could communicate with Rev. Father de Varennes direct.

I would recommend the above for your consideration.

**CANADA**
Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that it has been brought to my notice that our Branch installed a lighting plant in the Cowessess Residential School, in the Crooked Lake Agency, in the Fall of 1939.

The Saskatchewan Power Commission has now informed me that they are in receipt of a report on this school from one of their inspectors in which he states that this plant has changed the lighting of the school and associated buildings over from 32 to 110 volts. The wiring is defective by reason of the circuits being run with bell wire, and stapled to the surface finish, and the circuits extended with flexible cord. There are also exposed blade knife switches used to control outlets. This is a hazardous condition using either 32 or 110 volts and it is suggested that the Branch have a licensed contractor check over the wiring, and submit prices for bringing the whole installation up to the standards of the Canadian Electrical Code in compliance with the Electrical Inspection and Licensing Act.

For your information the following contractors are licensed in the Crooked Lake district:

H. E. Hurst at Grenfell, W. E. Biram, at Wolseley,
G. V. Lamont, A.F. Miller, and A. Sieble at Whitewood,
H. Gottfried at Lemberg, Helge E. Anderson at Dubuc, and
Frank Chomos at Esterhazy.

Evidently it is necessary to make the change they have suggested.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
August 6th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

The present water supply at the Cowessess Residential School is not sufficient for their needs. The present well is 3 ft in diameter and there is only 2½ ft of water, this can be pumped dry in ten minutes. It would offer little protection in case of fire.

In discussing this matter with the Rev. Principal, it was thought that the best solution would be to dig a new well 25 ft. deep and 6 ft in diameter. It has been tested and water was found available adjacent to the work shop. If the Department would supply the materials the school staff would do the work.

The following materials would be required:
- 100 sacks cement
- 40 ft. 2" Galv. pipe
- 2 - 90° Galv. Elbows.

The approximate cost would be $125.00.

I would recommend that this be granted as it is very necessary, particularly so from the viewpoint of fire protection.

Your obedient servant,

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 12, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, requesting materials costing approximately $125.00 in order to provide a new well at the Cowessess Residential School.

In regard to this school I may say that an amount of $400.00 was provided in this year's appropriation for repairs and improvements and the purchase of new equipment. We have already expended an amount of $47.20, leaving a balance available of $152.70. This, of course, would be sufficient to cover the materials required for the well, but before a decision can be made in this regard I wish to bring to your attention the contents of a letter just received from Mr. Christianson.

He has been informed by the Saskatchewan Power Commission that one of their inspectors recently visited this school and states:

"The lighting plant has been changed from 38 to 110 volts. This was apparently done by the school at the time the new lighting plant was purchased in the fall of 1939. The Provincial Inspector states that the wiring is defective by reason of the circuits being run with bell wire, and staked to the surface finish, and the circuits extended with flexible cord. There are also exposed blade knife switches used to control outlets. This is a hazardous condition using either 22 or 110 volts."

In view of this report the Department considers that before any other expenditures are incurred we should have an estimate of the cost of putting the wiring in this school in proper condition. Mr. George Lamont, of Whitewood, Sask., is on the Preferred List and I am informed he could give us an idea of what expenditures it would be necessary to incur. Please make the necessary arrangements in this regard and submit his report at the earliest possible date. Then we have this we will be in a position to decide if the funds available will permit the purchase of the materials requested for the well.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

You shall receive through our good Indian Agent the estimates for 1942 which I believe are very necessary. I know that the war burden is heavy, but on the other hand, I know that you are very pleased to see our Institution being kept in good order. And I believe, in this regard, that I have done my best, and I was glad to do it, to improve and embellish your property here.

Two years ago, I have built a cattle shed and a house for our farm-instructor. Last year, an electric centrifugal pump for the stable, a new milk cooler and a room were installed. All the buildings were painted anew (paint furnished by the Dept), a new lawnsman and sidewalks were made, an old shed rebuilt. This year, the old permanent granary was rebuilt, the foundation of one man's house made, cement and lumber supplied by the Dept. Implements shed was covered anew, the inside of the School refreshed, also, $104.88 were spent in blank fabrics, curtains & mattresses. All these expenses, except those specially mentioned were paid partially by our grant and partially by our Missionary funds.

Unfortunately, the Department has deemed necessary to cut off our grant. By this move, since the living cost is increasing, I am facing a great problem too not be able to give a proper salary to my men and to not be able to well look after the children, which I am obliged to keep over my number even by discharging those of 15 years of age.

I do not ask the Department to increase the pupilage number, but only to pay for the 70 children entitled to me in 1939.

Besides, the crop is close to a failure this year, the wheat gave 16 bushels an acre, the barley 5 and the oats 20 bushels an acre, but the hay and potatoes are good enough.

This statement is made only in view to bring good to this school and to give you in short what is going on here.

I remain yours sincerely,

Rev. V. de Varennes
C. J. ROSBOROUGH
RETAIL LUMBER AND COAL DEALER

Dear Sir:

Re File No.108-2-5, Sent. 4th, 1941.

Replying to your letter of the above date I beg to advise that on receipt of your letter of Aug. 12th, I immediately phoned Mr. Geo. Lamont and he promised to send an electrician down to Cowessess School the next day. He did not do so and since then I have called on him twice and each time he stated he would send someone. I phoned him again today and he informed me that he was unable to send a man as one electrician was sick and the other was too busy to go. He promised to try and get another man to go and if so he would send his estimate in a few days. I would be glad to have your further instructions in the event that he is unable to make the above arrangements.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th instant with reference to wiring at the Cowessess Residential School. On receipt of your letter of August 4 Indian Agent Kerley was written and directed to have the wiring inspected and a report submitted regarding the cost of making the repairs that are required.

Although Mr. Kerley was written on August 12 he did not reply until September 8 at which time he stated that he had been unable to obtain the electrician owing to the latter's illness. He promised at that time to get another man and said that he would send the estimate in a few days. Since that time we have heard nothing further from him.

It would be appreciated if you could take any action that would make Mr. Kerley respond more promptly to official communications.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of September 26 with reference to new wiring required at the Cowessess Indian Residential School in the Crooked Lakes Agency.

Some weeks ago an inspector of the Saskatchewan Power Commission visited the school and advised that certain necessary changes were required in the wiring system at the Cowessess School. Indian Agent Kerley was requested to obtain an estimate of the expenditure required but was unable to secure a competent person to supply this information. Consequently on September 27 the following telegram was forwarded to him:

Fire Alarm for School

In order to place this fire alarm in a working condition suggested by the power commission inspector will cost $75.00 as it requires 1450 ft. of wire to cover the lay out.

It could be fixed for $18.00 by disconnecting the alarm from the power line and using a battery system of 12 volts, although there is the danger of the batteries being neglected and becoming dead when a time came that the alarm might be required. This cost does not cover the batteries.

All the estimate prices quoted only hold good unless a great change takes place in electrical wiring materials due to the war.

Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.
October 1st 1941.

Dear Sir:

As instructed in your Night Letter received September 29th; I beg to forward herewith detailed estimate of material and labour from Mr. A. Kendrick, to place the electrical wiring of the Cowessess Indian Residential School and buildings in proper condition.

The total estimated cost without the wiring of the fire alarm system is:

Material $157.54
Labour $112.70
$270.24

The cost of wiring the fire alarm system into the 110 volt circuits, labour and 1450 ft. of wire is $75.00 making a total of $345.24.

The existing fire alarm system is one of the most dangerous defects pointed out by the lower commission, and should be changed, as it is constructed of bell wire and stapled to the building with a lamp bank near each bell to cut down the resistance.

Mr. Kendrick states that the fire alarm could be run on a battery system of 12 volts, this would have to be rewired, would not be so efficient and over a period of time more expensive. The cost of wire and labour $18.00 batteries $4.80 a total of $22.80.

This work is all necessary, but I had Mr. Kendrick estimate each part in case the Department saw fit only to do the school building and laundry at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
October 6, 1941.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Father de Varennes, Principal of the Cowesses Indian Residential School, Marieval, Saskatchewan, regarding the want of stable accommodation for the school herd.

If I am not mistaken Father de Varennes' predecessor on several occasions requested the agent of the Crooked Lake Reserve to apply to the Department to have the school stable enlarged. Owing to want of funds his request was refused year after year.

Owing to present conditions Father de Varennes does not hope for any assistance from the Department but he would appreciate it very much if you would allow him to demolish the stable at the Crooked Lake Agency which is not in use any more, and use the lumber and other materials to enlarge the school stable. He undertakes to do all the work without any assistance from the Department as he has at his disposal for the present, a substantial amount from the Missionary fund of the Oblate Fathers.

It is to be hoped that you will be able to grant Father de Varennes' request, and as the season is already far advanced, an early decision would be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6303, file 651-5, part 5)
Ottawa, June 23, 1942.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the Cowessess Indian Residential School, the following is an excerpt from a letter that we have recently received:

"Owing to present conditions, Father de Varennes does not hope for any assistance from the Department, but he would appreciate it very much if you would allow him to demolish the stable at the Crooked Lake Agency, which is not in use any more, and use the lumber and other materials to enlarge the school stable. He undertakes to do all the work without any assistance from the Department, as he has at his disposal for the present a substantial amount from the missionary fund of the Oblate Fathers.

"It is to be hoped that you will be able to grant Father de Varennes' request, and as the season is already far advanced an early decision would be greatly appreciated."

I would appreciate your advising me what use is being made of the stable mentioned in the above communication. I would like to have a specific recommendation from you on the matter, stating whether or not you feel that we should accede to the request.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 108-2-5 of the 23rd ultimo regarding turning over the barn at the Crooked Lake Indian Agency to the Principal of the Cowessess School, to be demolished.

In this connection I wish to inform you that the request was made to me by Father de Varennes some time ago and as far as I know this is the only barn we have had at the Agency and much too large for our present use. However it is the only place we have at the present time to the best of my knowledge. It would cost $1200.00 to build a stable of the proper size for our use and I do not suppose that our Branch would want to advance this money at the present time so that we could give the present barn to the Cowessess School. However, I am going down to the Cowessess School in a few days and I shall telephone before I leave to Father de Varennes and ask him to meet me at the Agency.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Father Plourde:

On receipt of your letter of June 20, I wrote Mr. Christianson regarding the request of the Principal of the Cowessess Indian Residential School for permission to demolish the stable at the Crooked Lake Agency. The following reply has been received from him:

"In this connection I wish to inform you that the request was made to me by Father de Varennes some time ago and as far as I know this is the only barn we have had at the Agency and much too large for our present use. However, it is the only place we have at the present time to the best of my knowledge. It would cost $1200.00 to build a stable of the proper size for our use and I do not suppose that our Branch would want to advance this money at the present time so that we could give the present barn to the Cowessess School. However, I am going down to the Cowessess School in a few days and I shall telephone before I leave to Father de Varennes and ask him to meet me at the Agency."

On reviewing your letter of June 20, I notice Father de Varennes advised you that the stable at the Crooked Lake Agency was not used any more. Apparently, from Mr. Christianson's letter, some use is being made of it by the agency. However, when I hear further from Mr. Christianson I will write you again.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermott Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
Regina, Saskatchewan,
July 18th., 1942

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that we have a large barn at the Crooked Lake Agency. The Principal of the Cowessess School is very anxious to get this barn and as it is much too large for our use and can be put to good use by the school since they have a lot of cattle and horses, I have decided that as far as I am concerned it will be in order to hand the barn over to him.

I believe Miss Walton has a book there which shows snaps of all the Agency buildings at Cowessess, and you can judge the size of the barn from that.

However, we will require to fix up an old barn that we have at Cowessess and which will meet our requirements. This will take from $150.00 to $200.00 in the way of repairs in addition to what old material we have on hand. I believe there is sufficient money in the $1800.00 that was allowed for repairs to Agency buildings to do this work.

I have discussed this matter with Mr. Kerley, the Agent, and he is in agreement with the above plan. I would refer you to Departmental letter No. 108-2-5 of the 23rd ultimo with reference to this.

As Father de Varennes wants to get at this work immediately I am sending this letter by Air Mail and I trust that you will give me a reply as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

M. Christenson
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Mr. Christianson has reported that the large barn at the Crooked Lake Agency is too large for Agency use and can be put to good use by the Cowesses School as they have a large number of cattle and horses. Also that there is an old barn at Cowesses which will meet the Agency requirements but which requires repairs.

He recommended the expenditure of from $150. to $200. for repairing the old barn. In view of the fact that Mr. Christianson states that the barn at the Agency is too large and should be handed over to the school and the barn at Cowesses repaired for the Agency use I would recommend the expenditure of from $150. to $200. for the purpose.

Secretary.
July 28, 1942.

Dear Mr. Christianson,

I have your letter of the 18th of July suggesting that the barn at the Crooked Lake Agency be handed over to the Cowessess School, as it is too large for agency use and can be put to good use by the school as they have a number of cattle and horses.

In reply I would say that it is not considered advisable, at the present time, to transfer this barn to the school.

I note your reference to a barn at Cowessess, which you state would be suitable for agency use if repaired, and that the repairs would cost from $150.00 to $200.00. Is this barn the property of the school, and as the transfer of the Agency barn to the school is not approved, will it be necessary for the school to make application for the repairs to this barn?

Kindly let me hear from you in this regard.

Yours very truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
General Superintendent of Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

July 25th, 1942

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 108-2-5 of the 24th instant and I note you think it is not advisable to transfer the barn at the Crooked Lake Indian Agency over to the Cowessess school.

The barn we were going to repair is an old barn at the Agency but as the transfer is not to take place this will close the matter.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.
Ottawa,
August 4, 1942.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to official letter of July 14 and previous correspondence, regarding the request of the Principal of the Cowessess School to demolish a stable at the Crooked Lake Agency, it is not considered advisable at the present time to allow this building to be torn down.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.

GOVERNMENT OF THE PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
STEAM BOILERS BRANCH

REGINA, SASK. November 11, 1942

Dear Sir:

The Department is attaching hereto voucher in triplicate in connection with the inspection of the two Loco. Stationary boilers (Record Nos. 15037 and 10216) located in the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Marteauval, Sask., which were inspected by Government Boiler Inspector Auckland, under date of November 2nd, 1942.

Upon receipt of your cheque for $8.00, we will be pleased to mail you the Inspection Certificates, which are on file in this Department.

Faithfully yours,

D. WEBB
Deputy Minister

Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch
Royal Bank Building,
Ottawa, Canada.

GOVERNMENT OF THE PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS
STEAM BOILERS BRANCH

REGINA, SASK. November 24, 1942

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your cheque for $6.00, being the fees for the inspection of the Locomotive Stationary Record No. 10218 and the Steam Heating boiler Record No. 15105 located in the Cowesses Indian Residential School, Mariaval, Sask. For which we thank you.

We accordingly enclose herewith the Inspection Certificates, which we trust will be found in order.

Faithfully yours,

D. Webster
Deputy Minister.

Rev. V. de Varennes, Principal of the Cowessess Indian School, has requested a new fire box for their bakery oven as the old one is burned out. This is a single fire box for "Economy Oven" manufactured by Daoust, St. Boniface, Man.

Will you kindly give authority for the Reverend Principal to order this.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
April 19, 1943.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Broadview, Sask.

R.A. Hoey,

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Rev. V. de Varennes, Principal of the Cowessess Residential School is asking for material to build a slaughter house. This will amount to approximately $110.00.

He also asks for the paints and varnish to the value of $75.00 as asked for in the 1943-44 Estimates, as he wishes to get the painting done early this year.

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 8, 1943.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Broadview, Sask.

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, in which you state you have received a request from the Principal of the Cowessess Residential School for material costing approximately $165.00.

You should forward immediately a requisition giving detailed information regarding the material required. You must be aware of the purchasing regulations. The Department cannot understand why the requisition was not forwarded with your letter and thus avoid the necessity of further communications.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re 108-2-5, June 8th, 1943.

I am enclosing requisitions for paint and material for the slaughter house at the Cowessess Residential school. The material for the slaughter house amounts to considerably more than the Rev. Principal estimated but the enclosed requisition is in accordance with the Provincial Government specifications.

I am also enclosing a requisition for flooring for the boys' playroom at the above school.

The prices on paint was taken from Marshall-Wells Co., Winnipeg, Man., catalogue and the lumber quotations from the Security Lumber Co., Grayson, Sask.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

The well at the Cowessess Residential School needs enlarging and new cribbing installed as the water supply is insufficient for their needs and the situation would be serious in case of fire.

I am enclosing a requisition for 7 lengths of concrete pipe 54" X 4' @ $9.00 per foot without sales tax. The total cost including labour would amount to $347.16. This would of course be a permanent job and would be the cheapest in the end and is what the Rev. Principal would prefer. However, in case the Department would prefer to use wooden cribbing I am also enclosing another requisition which amounts to $119.00 including labour, though I should also point out that owing to the shortage of lumber they cannot guarantee delivery.

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.

I beg to forward herewith requisition for three manhole covers and labour to install same on the three pressure tanks at the Cowessess Residential School. At present there is no way to clean them and the tanks are quite dirty with sediment that has gathered since the tanks were installed, two in 1920 and one in 1927.

The water is now very dirty and rusty and this appears to be the only way to clean the system, and to do so periodically in the future.

W. J. D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Broadview, Sask.

I am advising them of the quotation that you received from the Vulcan Iron Works, Winnipeg. When these covers arrive you may arrange for their installation. It is noted that this work will cost $20.00.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa,
March 4, 1944.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Broadview, Sask.

I desire to refer you to your letter of the 8th ultimo, enclosing requisition for three manhole covers for the pressure tanks at the Cowessess Residential School.

You stated on your requisition that the cost of these would be $129 and that the quotation had been received from the Vulcan Iron Works Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba. The Purchasing Branch wrote to this firm but they have failed to reply.

Did you receive a written quotation from this firm? If so, I wish you would forward it to this office by return mail. We are anxious to know if the price of $129 included both sales tax and transportation from Winnipeg to the school. As just intimated an immediate reply is desired.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
March 7, 1944.

Memorandum:

Mr. Hoey,

On the 14th ultimo you sent us a requisition for three manhole covers and reinforcements for the water system at the Cowessess Indian Residential School (your file 108-2-5). We were not sure that the quotation of $129.00 indicated on your requisition included sales tax and transportation, and we, therefore, proceeded to obtain this information.

This morning Vulcan Iron Works sent us their tender on these covers, together with blue prints illustrating the product they propose to supply. Their price is $145.00 f.o.b. Grayson, Dominion sales tax included. It would, therefore, appear that the original quotation (referred to on your requisition) did not include sales tax or freight.

We have not sufficient information to judge whether or not the manhole covers as described in the drawings herewith would be satisfactory, and suggest that they be referred to Mr. Gow at Winnipeg for his advice.

It will be in order for Mr. Hamilton to place the order with Vulcan Iron Works, Ltd., Winnipeg, provided the drawings are approved by Mr. Gow. The Company state in their tender, dated March 6th, that they can ship within ten days from receipt of order.

When delivery has been accepted please send the invoice to this office for the usual action.

Enclosure 3.

H.J. Davidson,
Dept. Purchasing Agent.
Ottawa,
March 9, 1944.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

Recently Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent,
Broadview, Saskatchewan, forwarded a requisition for
three manhole covers for the pressure tanks at the
Cowessess Indian Residential School. He requested:

3 11" x 15" Plate Manhole Covers &
Reinforcements including Manhole
Bridges, Bolts and Gaskets for
welding inside 52" diameter
shells of water pressure reservoirs.

In forwarding the requisition he stated
that he had received a quotation from the Vulcan Iron
Works, Winnipeg. A request was submitted to the
Purchasing Branch and, for your information, I enclose
a copy of their memorandum of March 7. It would be
appreciated if you would immediately submit the
attached drawings to Mr. Gow and, if he considers
the covers suggested are satisfactory, you may place
the order with Vulcan Iron Works and arrange for
shipment of the covers to Mr. Kerley. At the same
time you can certify the account and forward it to
this office for payment.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
February 1, 1944.

Rev. V. de Varennes,
Indian Residential School
Marieval, via GRAYSON, Sask.

Reverend and Dear Father:

This quotation is conditional on satisfactory terms in respect to payment and security being arranged. All prices quoted herein are net, also freight charges, insurance, sales tax unless otherwise specified. It is further subject to any additional customs duties, sales tax, charge in rate of exchange, or any other government taxes and to any undue increase in price of materials or labor. All promises of deliveries are subject to government regulations and other interferences beyond our control.

We will not be responsible for delays due to fires, strikes, labor difficulties, accidents, delays in transportation, or other causes beyond our control.

This replies to your valued letter of January 28th in reference to manholes which you require for your 52" diameter water pressure reservoirs.

We can arrange to make up these manhole covers complete and ship them to Marieval and on same we are pleased to quote you as follows:

3 11 x 15 Plate Manhole Covers & Reinforcements including Manhole Bridges, Bolts and Gaskets for welding inside 52" diam. shells of water pressure reservoirs.

PRICE: $129.00

Looking forward with pleasure to undertaking the above work for you, we remain,

Yours very truly,

VULCAN IRON WORKS LIMITED,
per:

General Sales Manager.

Ottawa, March 28, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Re: Cowessess Indian Residential School.

The Principal of the above-mentioned school, Reverend J. Lemire, O.M.I., has advised this Branch that he wishes to purchase a John Deer tractor, Model "D", for use on the farm attached to the school. Payment of the cost of this tractor will be made from school funds and the Cowessess School is government-owned.

The Principal further states that he knows where he can secure the machine mentioned, but the firm requires a priority. I would appreciate it if you could arrange to have the necessary priority issued.

Acting Director.
MEMORANDUM

DEPUTY MINISTER

Tractor for Indian Mission School,
Broadview, Sask.

Representations have been made to this office to the effect that it is very necessary that a new tractor be provided for the above Mission School in order that they may carry on their farm operations.

It is stated that they have completed all the necessary documents for the authorities in charge of allocation of farm machinery and that the John Deer Company at Yorkton are holding for them a 38 D-Model tractor on rubber. The Company, however, have told them that they must have a letter of recommendation from the department, recommending or verifying that this implement is needed.

It is stated, further, that there are 900 acres under cultivation, 7 of which will be put into crop this spring providing they get the necessary machinery; that there are also 200 acres to be summer-fallowed; that they work 16 head of horses on this farm and the tractor is also used to do threshing etc.

This further statement is made; that the tractor on hand has been in continuous use for 19 years and is almost a total wreck and of no further use, and the need of a new tractor is stressed.

Immediate consideration is desired as we are informed that it is only a matter of days before the School will be starting the crop year of 1945.

Will you please let me have a report, at the earliest possible moment.

Mr. Hoey -

For report as requested.

[Signature]

Private Secretary.
A complimentary copy of our "Canada Descriptive Atlas" is sent you herewith. While we are able to supply a complimentary copy to a teacher it has been found necessary, in order to keep distribution within reasonable limits, to make a nominal charge of ten cents a copy for atlases sent to pupils or the general public. Should you require additional copies on this basis we will be glad to supply them. It is a convenience when pupils pool their orders and have the amount remitted by their teacher. PLEASE DO NOT SEND STAMPS.

Herewith we are sending material relating specifically to the National Parks of Canada which I hope will be of interest to you.

Yours very truly,

ROBERT J.C. STEAD,
Superintendent,
Publicity and Information.

Encl.
Ottawa, April 18, 1945.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

With reference to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of April 16, regarding a tractor for the Cowessess Indian Residential School, near Broadview, Sask., we have verified, on our files, the information he has evidently received. Under the circumstances, I believe that a letter should be forwarded to the John Deer Company, and therefore I attach a draft reply that might be sent.

Acting Director.
COPY - to be returned to Indian Affairs when letter is signed

Ottawa, April 18, 1945.

Gentlemen:

This Department has recently been advised that the management of the Cowessess Indian Residential School, near Broadview, Saskatchewan, is endeavouring to secure a tractor. The Indian Residential School mentioned is operated for this Department by the Oblate Order. There are 90 children in attendance and it is necessary for the management to cultivate a very large area of ground in order to provide the necessary food. From the information that we have available it is evident that a tractor is essential and this Department believes that the management is justified in endeavouring to secure one.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Minister.

The John Deere Company,
Yorkton, Sask.

RL/GC
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I understand that the Lestock Residential School have recently changed from D.C. to A.C. electric current and that there are a few surplus D.C. electric motors on hand there.

The Cowessess Residential school is badly in need of a 1 H.P., D.C. motor for pumping purposes as the old one is burned out and cannot be replaced by a new one as these are not available in this size at present. I believe there are two 1 H.P. surplus motors at Lestock and these could both be used to advantage at the Cowessess School as the other one could be used in the bakery, if the Department will authorize their transfer.

I would recommend this for your consideration.

W.J.D. Kerley

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 19, 1945.

Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Sask.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Kerley, Crooked Lake Agency, in which he states that he has been informed there are two 1 horse power surplus motors at the Muscowequan School. These could be used to advantage at the Cowessess Residential School.

Please consult the Principal, and, if the motors mentioned are not required at the Muscowequan School, it will be in order for you to transfer them immediately to the Cowessess School. You should let me know what action you take in this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to your letter #108-2-5 dated the 19th inst., arrangements have been made to ship the two 1 horse power motors to Cowessess Indian Residential School.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 12, 1945.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 12th ultimo, I am now advised by Indian Agent Davis that arrangements have been made to ship the two 1-horse power motors from the Muscowequan Residential School to the Cowessess Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Ottawa, December 20, 1945.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
414 Federal Building, Regina, Sask.

We have recently been requested to supply six closet bowls with flush valves for the Cowessess Indian Residential School, and the Purchasing Agent has placed the business with the Ashdown Hardware Company, Regina, Sask. They have been requested to consult you regarding the kind of equipment that is needed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant, No. 108-2-5, in connection with closet bowls and flush valves for the Cowessess Indian Residential School, I have been in contact with the Ashdown Hardware Company of Regina and after some delay have been advised today that they have not this equipment on hand and do not expect to have any for some considerable time. I would therefore suggest that the Purchasing Agent make an effort to purchase elsewhere.

I am informed by the Marshall Wells Company of Regina that they have none in stock at the present time but that they expect in about two weeks' time to have some of the ordinary flush bowls of tank type. Perhaps if an order was placed with them at once by the Purchasing Agent it would be on hand when the equipment is received.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith requisition for 12 Double Bunk Beds and 24 Rolled edge Mattress required for the Cowessess Indian Residential School at a cost of $161.40.

I would recommend that authority be granted for this purchase if funds are available as the additional beds are badly needed.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, January 3, 1946.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, March 13, 1946.

The Security Lumber Company Limited, Broadview, Sask.,

We have your account of February 22nd for material furnished to the Cowessess Indian Residential School. We are having the Treasury Branch issue a cheque for $211.92. The reason for this change is that an error occurred in adding the totals. The first addition instead of being $67.72 should be $53.92, hence, the change.

We hope that this will prove satisfactory.

Philip Phelan,

Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
April 1st, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re P.O. 5423

We have been advised by the Security Lumber Company, Broadview, Sask., that they received a cheque in payment of our voucher No. 433 of March 2nd, 1946, but that there was a deduction of $13.80, the cheque being for $211.92 instead of $225.72 the amount of our voucher.

There was evidently a clerical error in copying this account from the original slips as the material was all received. We do not have a copy of the accounts attached to the voucher, our office copy was the customers copy of the original slips and this was checked before the voucher was sent in but unfortunately we only compared it with the one sent in as to total and not in detail.

I am enclosing these slips which were signed by Rev. M.St. Jacques, assistant principal of Cowessess School and I trust that an adjustment can be made for the $13.80.

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
**DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES**

Note:

The above was ordered on purchase order No. 5423 and voucher No. 433 was issued on December 28, 1945, but the item mentioned above was not shown on the account and consequently the voucher ($423) was paid at $211.92. The Indian Agent writes as follows:

"There was evidently a clerical error in copying this account from the original slips as the material was all received. We do not have a copy of the accounts attached to the voucher; our office copy was the customer's copy of the original slips and this was checked before the voucher was sent in, but unfortunately we only compared it with the one sent in as to total and not in detail.

"I am enclosing these slips which were signed by Rev. M. St. Jacques, assistant principal of Cowessess School, and I trust that an adjustment can be made for the $13.90."

OTTAWA, April 9th 1947

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Re: New school at Cowesses.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing a petition from the Indians of the above reserve asking for the construction of a new residential school.

The information I have is that the school is too small and looked upon as some kind of a fire trap. The Indians are very fearful for the lives of their children should a fire originate during the night. The present building could be used for class rooms and, therefore, need not be considered a total loss.

Very truly yours,

J.O. Flourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, April 17th, 1947.

Dear Father Plourde:

We have your letter of the 9th instant enclosing petition from certain Indians of the Crooked Lake Agency requesting the erection of a new school to replace the present Cowessess Residential School. As no provision was made in the current year's appropriation for the erection of a new school at this point, I regret that immediate consideration cannot be given to the request contained in the petition.

However, we are noting the matter for reconsideration when preparing the estimates for the fiscal year 1948-49.

It should be understood that we cannot give you any definite assurance that favourable consideration to the project will be given at that time.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Ave., E., Ottawa.

Marieval, via Grayson, Sask.
Grenfell, Sask.
September 3rd, 1947.

Mr. R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Director of Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

We, Indians of Sakimay Band, Sakimay Reserve, Crooked Lake Agency, in the Province of Saskatchewan, wish to draw to your attention the complete inadequacy of the present school buildings situated at the east end of the Crooked Lake, in the Crooked Lake Agency.

The present school building is very old, and entirely out of date for school purposes; in comparison with similar schools for white children, we are certain in that our school would be condemned out of hand. It is a complete fire-trap, and children would have no time to escape, and we imagine that the majority would perish, if it ever happens that a fire starts or breaks out during night. And us, parents, we never feel at ease when our children are at school. We do implore and insist that the Department should take the means to put or to have our children in safety when at school.

Further it is stated to be pointed out, that there is not nearly sufficient accommodation for the present number of scholars. There should be accommodation for at least 200 children.

We feel that in view of the age of the building, and its negative nature as a school, that remodelling or making additions to same would not put same in a first class condition for proper school purposes. Therefore we do respectfully urge that a new school be built, fully modern in every respect, and particularly to include gymnasium, and one capable of favorable comparison with a similar type used for the white children, and one that will not only fulfill the present needs, but capable of providing for our increasing school population.

Yours Respectfully,

[Signature]
King Jerome Piell (signature)
Koel Joel Williams

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am enclosing letter received from the Sakimay Band Indians belonging to the Crooked Lake Agency in the province of Saskatchewan, which I have been asked to forward to your office for your kind attention. A similar request is being mailed to Mr. Keenleyside, the Deputy Minister of the Department.

I do not know whether you have ever visited the Cowesses school. If you have, you will readily understand the fear which the Indians live under for the lives of their children. All possible supervision is exercised in connection with fire prevention but they know that accidents will happen in spite of these measures, that is why the present request is forwarded to you in the hope that you will take their case before the Minister and obtain for them a new school.

Should it be impossible for the present year to meet their wishes I believe that a four-room school building would materially relieve the situation. This class-room building could be well utilized when the new school is built and would not, therefore, be a loss or useless expense on the part of your Department.

In any case the whole matter is left to your kind attention and I shall notify the Indians that you will take their interests to heart.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Encl. 1.
Mr. H. L. Keenleyside,
Deputy Minister,
Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

I beg to enclose another letter received today in connection with the request of the Indians of the Cowesses School for a fireproof building to replace their present institution.

The arguments brought forward in favour of this project are about the same but I thought that you might like to know that the sentiment among the Indians of the Agency are quite unanimous in this respect.

Thanking you for your kind attention to this matter, I remain,

Respectfully yours,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Mr. H. L. Keenleyside,
Deputy Minister,
Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to enclose the originals of two letters which I have just received from the Indians of Cowesses Reservation in Saskatchewan, in which they ask for a new fireproof school to replace the present building.

The Indians of this reservation are very conscious of the danger to which their children are being exposed in the present old school building and their desire to have it replaced by a modern fireproof building is quite normal and natural.

On my return from the Makenzie District, I stopped at Cowesses School and I can assure you that what is said in these letters is quite accurate.

In your coming estimates it is to be hoped that provisions will be made for this project. These Indians are a deserving group and the fact that they have already written several times about this same matter shows on their part a desire to give their children a modern education which the Department has every advantage to encourage.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain, Mr. Keenleyside,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Flourde, O.M.I.

Enc1. 2
On the date mentioned above I, W.J. Redwood, constable of Lowered band of Crooked Lake Agency.

I am sending you a few lines on behalf of Crooked Lake Agency in order to ask you for some help, as you know yourself that we need a new school in Marieval. Our school that we have is only a fire trap too old and too small. We need a school at least for 200 children. I did will say that we have children in the Reserve should be in school, but there is no room for them. Some time ago a petition was sent to the Indian Dept. and was signed by all Indians and headmen. But we got no satisfaction. But we still feel we should get a new school. Rev. Father Sam
asking you to help us with all your power to get a new school. By doing this you might be saving a lot of lives. We don't know what is going to happen anytime with this old school as I said before it's only a fire trap. I will also add that we have a good staff in this school, we have a good principal who does his very best to cooperate with the Indians, and good to everyone also the sisters are good to all the children. They are really taking place of mothers. So we have something to be proud of. Hope this will put in your mind our big question is worth something and why we like to keep up our Roman Catholic school.

N.J. Remmert
Cowesses Indian Reservation,
Marieval, P.O., Sask.

Reverend Father J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Oblate Fathers University,
Ottawa.

Reverend and Dear Father;

Our Reverend and dear Principal and Pastor, Father J. Lemire, has told us that we could put into your hands our request for a new and larger fire-proof Indian residential School. Twice already we have made petition to the Department of ours for the urgent need of a new and larger fire-proof School, but it seems that no worthwhile consideration has been given to our petitions.

Being Indians, it does not mean that we do not love our children, and then could be exposed to the greatest danger. As you must know yourself this actual residential School is a fire-trap and a real danger for the lives of our beloved children. We certainly feel unsafe sending our children this said School at the present, and we conscientiously believe that we should not send them at all, especially knowing so many Schools of the kind burning down. We do not wish to be mean to the Department, as mostly all of us have went through this present School, and we surely are very grateful to the Department for the education received, and also to the reverend Fathers and Sisters.

Rev. Father J. Lemire, we know, is taking all precaution possible actually for the safety of our children, still the danger is existing and very great.

This said residential School is not only a fire-trap, but also far too small. We do appreciate a lot the education given at the School, and we wish to see all the children to have the opportunity to be educated.

We do hope, reverend and dear Father Plourde, that you may present our request to the Indian Department in our behalf, and you succeed to obtain for us a new and larger fire-proof residential School—-for the accommodation and the safety of our beloved children, and also of our dear staff, who is exposed also seriously.

We are very grateful, rev. and dear Father, for all you are doing and will do for us.

On behalf of the Indians of Cowesses reservation specially of those who have children at the said School, and are mostly interested of a larger and fire-proof building, we do sign hereunder.

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

You know the situation at Cowesses school, the size of the building, the number of children, the demand made by the Indians for a new fire-proof building and the necessity for it.

If it is impossible to include this project in this year's estimates, would it at least be possible to provide a four-room class building which could be integrated in the new building whenever you decide to erect it. Such a project would release considerable space in the present building, which could be used for dormitories and recreation room.

I, therefore, hope that you will be able to consider my proposition favourably when preparing your estimates if you find it impossible, as stated above, to erect a complete new building.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

OTTAWA, January 27, 1948.

The Secretary,

Re: Machines and Utensils asked by your Dietitian for the Cowesses Indian Residential School.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

In her report on the above school, as result of her visit made last October 16 to 18, 1947, your dietitian wants your Department to supply the following machines and services needed for the food preparation and sanitation:

1. A food service set-up including kitchen, dining-room, bakery, refrigeration, storeroom and dairy room.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

DATE: May 3rd, 1948
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Gymnasium for Cowesses School

About two weeks ago, I asked for a car load of cement to build a Gymnasium for the Cowesses Indian Residential School. My request was received favorably, but you asked for some information, which I was not then in a position to give you, but which I since received.

The building will be 375 feet from the Principal's residence and 450 feet from the school. Both heating and lighting will be independent of the school facilities, as it is the Principal's intention to install a small heating and lighting plant in the new structure.

Under these circumstances I feel sure that you will be glad to supply the cement needed for this structure which will be of such benefit to the present school children as well as to the former pupils.

Your very truly,

J. O. Plourde, o.m.i.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Gymnasium for Cowesses Residential School.

Further to my letter concerning the above project and in the hope of clarifying this matter, I am glad to inform you that the Principal has collected from friends and benefactors a little over seven thousand dollars, which it is his intention to use for this building.

This amount though large is not quite sufficient. He would appreciate it very much if your Department could supply him with one earload of cement and undertake to meet return of labour accounts to the extent of eighteen hundred dollars.

The building of this gymnasium is considered by the principal an essential factor in disciplining the older pupils of the school and establishing a former pupils society for the general betterment of the reserve.

Church authorities have allowed him to use the seven thousand dollars referred to above to bring about this improvement in the general condition of the reserve and we would certainly appreciate it very much if the department would give what we have just asked for.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, o.m.i.
Ottawa, June 24th, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Cowesses Indian Residential School,
Province of Saskatchewan.

We have received a request to permit the principal of the above school to proceed with the erection of a gymnasium. The proposal made to us is as follows:

"Further to my letter concerning the above project, and in the hope of clarifying this matter, I am glad to inform you that the Principal has collected from friends and benefactors a little over seven thousand dollars, which it is his intention to use for this building.

"This amount though large is not quite sufficient. He would appreciate it very much if your Department could supply him with one carload of cement and undertake to meet return of labour accounts to the extent of eighteen hundred dollars.

"The building of his gymnasium is considered by the principal an essential factor in disciplining the older pupils of the school and establishing a former pupils society for the general betterment of the reserve.

"Church authorities have allowed him to use the seven thousand dollars referred to above to bring about this improvement in the general condition of the..."
reserve and we would certainly appreciate it very much if the department would give what we have just asked for."

The Cowesses School is Government-owned and I feel that the provision of a gymnasium would be very beneficial to the students as well as providing a meeting place for the ex-pupils association.

You will note that the Principal is prepared to expend an amount of $7,000.00 from the funds which he has personally collected and that he requests the Department to supply one carload of cement and an amount of $1,500.00 towards the cost of the labour. Funds are available in the current year's appropriation to carry out the expenditure requested from the Department.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would give his approval.

PP/MGD

On June the 21st last, I wrote to you about the above matter.

As the season is well advanced and construction during July and August is made easy with the work of former pupils, it would be appreciated if you could let me have a favorable answer immediately.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sirs;

At present we are unloading the 600 bags car-load of cement, for the purpose of a gymnasium. We surely appreciate the generosity of our Indian Department to come to our aid.

Would you kindly accept our sincere thanks, also from the Indians. Rev. Father J.E. Plourde has assured me also that the Department is very willing to contribute up to $1800.00 in wages for the labour. It is most encouraging for us, and I am most thankful to our Department for their grand generosity. I firmly hope also that the Indians of this Agency will appreciate this generous gift on their behalf....I will do my utmost to make them appreciate it.

Once more, dear Sirs, I renew my most sincere appreciation for your great generosity.

I remain yours very thankful,

Father J. Lamire, O.M.I.
Principal.

CANADA
Regina, September 20, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

A "Night Letter" was sent to the Department on the 22nd of August, 1948, by the writer from Punnichy reading as follows; "High Pressure Boiler Cowessess Residential School condemned. stop Request authority from T.S. Mills for A.H. Hargreaves to examine and make recommendation. stop. Will extend Hargreaves trip approximately six days. stop. Wire reply care of Superintendent Simpson. stop"

Mr. Hargreaves examined the condemned boiler at the Cowessess School and also a boiler at the Port Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital. But I did not see him after the examinations took place. In consequence, I am not certain of recommendations he made.

In any case action should be taken at once to replace the condemned boiler. I would suggest that in order that the new boiler may be installed before the weather becomes too cold, Mr. T.S. Mills be asked for an immediate recommendation.

W. P. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
September 22, 1948.

Messrs. Neil, Stoddard & Chapman,
Plumbers, Steam Fitters, etc.,
Brandon, Manitoba.

Gentlemen:

Mr. A.H. Hargreaves of the Lands and Development Services Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, advises that he called on your firm recently with a view to arranging for certain work at the Cowessess Residential School.

The following work is required:

(1) Obtain low pressure heating boiler from the Indian hospital at Qu'Appelle, Sask., and move same to the Cowessess School and install it,

(2) Move high pressure boiler from the Gordon's Indian Residential School near Punnichy, Sask., to the Cowessess Residential School and install it.

We would appreciate hearing from you as soon as possible stating that you can undertake the above work and we would like to have an idea of the cost that would be involved.

I understand that Mr. Hargreaves explained the matter to you fully but if you require any further information regarding distances, etc., you can obtain same by applying to Mr. J.P.E. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, 304 Post Office Bldg., Regina, Sask.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry
Superintendent of Education.
