ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Labour for repairs at the Cowesses Residential School..$1,800.00

For Voucher d/28 aug 48 - 305.00
Re: Indian Residential School - Cowessess, Saskatchewan.

You are advised that our Heating Engineer visited the above on his recent trip to the West. While this school was not on his original itinerary, the visit was arranged at the request of Regional Supervisor J.P.B. Ostrander, who obtained the necessary authority by telegram from this Division through the Indian Affairs Branch.

The following report is the result of the survey made:

The heating system is a one-pipe low pressure steam type, not of modern design. It was reported to our Officer that the system functioned as well as could be expected under present circumstances. The existing low pressure steam steel fire box boiler was found to be of insufficient capacity, and in addition, several tubes were leaking. No record could be found with regard to its age but it may be assumed to be between 20 and 25 years old.

With a boiler of insufficient capacity, which shows considerable damage as a result of forcing, it would be uneconomical to incur expenditures for repairs.

Dr. Simes of the Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital, in a letter to Indian Superintendent W.J.D. Kerley, offered a 35-horse power Leonard low pressure steam, steel fire box boiler for use at the above school. Our Officer visited the hospital and inspected the boiler and obtained all details in connection therewith.

The boiler was installed in 1936 as an emergency measure while general repairs and revisions were being made to the hospital power plant, and in all, was only used for a period of 10 to 15 hours. Our Officer found it to be in all-round first class condition. It is therefore recommended that this boiler be acquired by Indian Affairs for installation at Cowessess to replace the present 25-horse power unit.

There is an old 15-horse power Case threshing machine, locomotive type, high pressure boiler in the boiler room of the school which supplies the laundry with high pressure steam. This unit was found to be so badly worn and deteriorated as to be a source of great danger. It should be immediately cut out of service. The plates are worn exceedingly thin in spots and its operation to

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6303, file 651-5, part 6)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
date has been permitted by the Provincial Boiler Inspector only because the Foreman operating the boiler has had considerable experience with the unit for the past 17 years and fully realizes the inherent danger.

There is now at the Gordon's Indian Residential School, a new 15 horse-power high pressure boiler, ordered by the Contractor carrying out boiler room remodelling there, which was not acceptable to this Division for the purpose it was to serve. It has not yet been returned to the manufacturer.

It is recommended that this unit be purchased by the Indian Affairs Branch for removal to, and installation in the Cowessess School.

While the matter is urgent, it is unlikely that any contractor would submit a firm tender for carrying out work of this nature. It is thought, however, that a number of firms may be willing to undertake the work at cost plus a percentage, or at cost plus a fixed fee, in which connection is suggested that the firm of Neale, Stothard and Chapman of Brandon, who are familiar with the situation, be asked along with other contractors, to submit an estimate for carrying out this work.

Should the Indian Affairs Branch accept the foregoing recommendations, this Division will prepare a specification covering the work to be carried out, for use in obtaining estimates.

Chief Engineer.
NEALE, STOTHARD & CHAPMAN
TINSMITHING, PLUMBING AND HEATING

BRANDON, MANITOBA

Dear Sir:

RE Cowesses Indian Residential School.

We wish to quote on the above Boiler room revisions as follows:
To move Leonard High Pressure Boiler from Gordon's School, Punnichy, Sask. and install same in Cowesses School, complete with brick setting and outside steel suspension, new smoke breeching, (Boiler to Chimney). One 2" Injector, all pipes, fittings, valves, labor, transportation and board to complete this installation.

To disconnect and remove low pressure Leonard Boiler, #312635, plus off connections, change smoke breeching, clean up site at Indian Hospital, Qu'Appelle, Sask.

To transport and install same in Cowesses School, complete with new smoke breeching, (Boiler to Chimney), all pipes, fittings, valves, labor, transportation and board to complete this installation as a one pipe heating system to your satisfaction for the sum of $3,676.40.

Further to the above, it would be, in our opinion, greatly to the advantage of the School to have the low pressure heating Boiler stokerized, as the Boiler being installed is not any too large. Therefore, we quote for your approval as follows:

To -- One Canadian Fairbanks-Morse #1-350 Industrial Stoker equipped with 110 to 120 D.C. Motor, installed complete with:
1-- McDenneill Millar #47-2 Feeder and Cutoff.
1-- #P404 Pressuretrol.
1-- R. 19A Relay.
1-- T. 11A Thermostat.
1-- C.R. 7006 Magnetic Switch.

This Stoker will burn the low grade Souris coal and is sized for that purpose.

The above for the sum of $1,605.65.

Total price complete, $5,282.05.

Regarding old Case steam Engine at Cowesses School, you are of course informed that this Boiler was used also for power. Is it the intention of your department to run the Laundry, Dairy, Pressure Pump and Sump Pump from the power plant supplying the electric power? Or was it your intention to have a steam engine installed for power and supplied by steam from the high pressure boiler?

Please advise, as we have made no provisions for power take off or steam engine.

Yours very truly,

Neale, Stothard & Chapman.

Per [signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6303, file 651-5, part 6)
MEMORANDUM

Re: Indian Residential School, Cowessess, Saskatchewan.

Further to our memorandum of September 27th, in connection with the above, you are advised that the Indian Affairs Branch have submitted for comment, a tender received from Messrs Neale Stotheid and Chapman, of Brandon, for carrying out the work at the above, as outlined in our memorandum.

Their price of $3676.40, is in our opinion, a favourable one, and it is therefore recommended that the Indian Affairs Branch be advised to award the work to that firm.

Since the Indian Affairs Branch are desirous of keeping the expenditure to the minimum, it is recommended that no stoker be installed at the present time. The heating boiler which it is contemplated to use, is 10 horsepower larger than the existing unit, and is large enough to handle the heating load when fired by hand.

The high pressure boiler is intended to serve several items of existing laundry equipment only, including the tumbler dryer and the box coil drying cabinets.

It is understood that this work will be carried out by the Indian Affairs Branch, and will be under the nominal supervision of Indian Superintendent Kerley and that no funds will be transferred to this Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, October 19, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Cowessess Indian Residential School.

One of the officials of the Lands and Development Services Branch recently visited the above school and in a memorandum dated September 27th, 1948, from the Director of that Division, it is strongly recommended that we make immediate changes in the heating system.

To carry out the recommendations of the Lands and Development Services Branch will involve an expenditure of $3,676.40, for which amount the firm of Neale Stothard and Chapman will do the necessary work.

From the information received from the Lands and Development Services Branch we believe that the work that they recommend is very necessary and we would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the expenditure mentioned above, funds for which purpose are available in the current year's appropriation.

Acting Director.

Ottawa, October 19, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Cowessess Indian Residential School.

One of the officials of the Lands and Development Services Branch recently visited the above school and in a memorandum dated September 27th, 1948, from the Director of that Division, it is strongly recommended that we make immediate changes in the heating system.

To carry out the recommendations of the Lands and Development Services Branch will involve an expenditure of $3,676.40, for which amount the firm of Neale Stothard and Chapman will do the necessary work.

From the information received from the Lands and Development Services Branch we believe that the work that they recommend is very necessary and we would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the expenditure mentioned above, funds for which purpose are available in the current year's appropriation.

Acting Director
Dear Mr. Neary,

Find enclosed snaps of the GYMNASIUM taken about a couple weeks ago, later I will be sending you some again. At present they are preparing the roof, tomorrow they will start to put it up and, I believe, by the end of the week the roof will be up.

I am surely most grateful for the great help that our Department is giving me. Its generosity is greatly appreciated by this Community. Will accept, then, our heartfelt thanks. And it is for me specially a very great encouragement.

I remain, yours very truly,

Father J. Lemire, O.M.I.
Pastor & Principal

Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Welfare & Training
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 2, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Gymnasium - Cowessess Residential School.

Please find attached two photographs of the progress being made at the gymnasium being erected at the above Indian Residential School. You will recall that the minister approved the supplying of one carload of cement and an amount of $1,500.00 towards the cost of the labour involved. In a letter addressed to the Department, the Principal states as follows:

"Find enclosed snaps of the GYMNASIUM taken about a couple weeks ago, later I will be sending you some again. At present they are preparing the roof, tomorrow they will start to put it up and, I believe, by the end of the week the roof will be up.

"I am surely most grateful for the great help that our Department is giving me. Its generosity is greatly appreciated by this Community. Will you accept, then, our heartfelt thanks. And it is for me specially a very great encouragement."

It is felt that the erection of such gymnasia will do a great deal towards promoting the interest in athletics which we have recently been discussing.

Acting Director.

BFH/EM
November 3, 1948.

Reverend Father:

I have for answer your letter of October 26th.

The pictures of the gymnasium were sincerely appreciated and we have taken the liberty of sending them over to the Deputy Minister who is keenly interested in the development of Indian athletics.

I hope that the work has begun or will begin in the near future in repairing the boilers at your school. It is hoped that this will keep everyone comfortable during the coming winter.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

November 3, 1948.

Dear Mr. Stothard:

This will confirm the telegram sent you recently with regard to the repairs to the heating system required at the Cowessess Residential School.

Your tender of $3,676.40 for the moving of the boiler from the Gordon's Residential School and the other details as listed in your letter of October 5 has been approved by our Minister.

We have spent a considerable amount of money at the Cowessess School this year and, therefore, funds are not available for the installation of the stoker at the present time. The heating boiler which it is contemplated to use is 410 horse power larger than the existing unit and we are informed that it is large enough to handle the heating load when fired by hand.

The high pressure boiler is intended to serve several items of existing laundry equipment including a tumbler dryer and a box coil drying cabinets.

When the work is completed would you please submit your account to the office of Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional supervisor of Indian Agencies, 30th Post Office Building, Regina, Saskatchewan. It can then be certified and returned here.

Sincerely yours,

Neale Stothard & Chapman,
118 - 8th St.,

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan:
Re: Steam Engine for operating Laundry machinery
for the Cowesses Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Jean Lemire, O.M.I., principal of the above school in which he states that the old combination steam-boiler and engine which was used to operate the laundry machinery is being removed and a new boiler is being installed instead. He has no objection to the change, but it seems that no provision was made for another steam engine. If that be so, he wonders how he will be able to operate the laundry machinery. I believe that it would be in order for your engineer to examine the power facilities at the school and suggest such changes as he may deem fit. It would certainly be unfortunate if the laundry was left for a certain period of time without sufficient power to operate.

Moreover, he states in the same letter that it is impossible to secure good cordwood and he is therefore obliged to install a stoker, the value of which will be between fourteen and fifteen hundred dollars. This is also a matter which your engineer should study. Wages in a matter of this kind are so important a factor that mechanical facilities might be provided where they are found necessary or very useful.

Will you please let me know at your convenience if the Department can do anything to remedy both conditions.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Col. F. B. Neary,
Sup't Indian Education,
Dep't Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Regarding Stoker,-the School, I understand, are installing a Stoker, funds for this to be authorized by the Oblate Fathers. I only mention this to clarify our position as regards to a Stoker being installed, as we do not wish at any time wish to question your Department.

We will, as you direct on completion of this work, submit our account to Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Yours very truly,

Neale, Stothard & Chapman,

Ottawa, November 26, 1948.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch.

Sowassee Indian Residential School.

You will recall that in your memorandum of October 12 you advised with regard to the acceptance of the tender received from Messrs. Neale, Stothard & Chapman of Brandon, Manitoba, for carrying out certain work at the above school.

In accordance with your technical advice, this tender was submitted for approval by the Minister, and the work is now being done.

We have recently been advised that the low pressure heating boiler has been installed and is now in operation. The bricklayer is now bricklaying in the high pressure boiler, and the whole of the work called for in the tender should be completed on or about November 30.

We have received further representations with regard to the steam engine and the installation of a stoker at this school. The request reads in part as follows:

"I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Jean Lemire, O.M.I., principal of the above school in which he states that the old combination steam-boiler and engine which was used to operate the laundry machinery is being removed and a new boiler is being installed instead. He has no objection to the change, but it seems that no provision was made for another steam engine. If that be so, he wonders how he will be able to operate the laundry..."
machinery. I believe that it would be in order for your engineer to examine the power facilities at the school and suggest such changes as he may deem fit. It would certainly be unfortunate if the laundry was left for a certain period of time without sufficient power to operate.

Moreover, he states in the same letter that it is impossible to secure good cordwood and he is therefore obliged to install a stoker, the value of which will be between fourteen and fifteen hundred dollars. This is also a matter which your engineer should study. Wages in a matter of this kind are so important a factor that mechanical facilities might be provided where they are found necessary or very useful."

You will recall that with regard to the stoker, funds were not available this year for the work, and we did not accept that part of Mr. Stothard's tender which dealt with the installation of an industrial stoker. However, we would like to have your comments with regard to the steam engine.

Acting Director.
MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, December 1, 1948.

Re: Cowesses Indian Residential School,
Cowesses, Sask.

In connection with Major MacKay's memorandum of November 26th bearing your notation of the 30th, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

While no mention was made of a new engine in our memorandum of October 12th, enquiries were instituted to obtain prices and delivery of a new unit. Thus far prices have not been received.

In the meantime, in order to provide temporary service, it is suggested that the old engine be removed from the old Case Boiler and set up on a firm base in the boiler room and piped to the new horizontal return tubular high pressure boiler now being installed, to provide temporary service for the laundry machinery. As far as could be determined at the time the inspection was carried out, the engine appeared capable of providing power for the laundry machinery, for a limited time at least.

In dismantling this engine, it will likely be found that in order to provide continuous and efficient service, major repairs will be necessary. As this unit has been in use for a considerable length of time, it would more than likely prove extremely difficult and uneconomical to effect such repairs, and it is considered that a new engine should be installed.

The purpose of this steam engine, is to drive a line of shafting and counter-shafting which in turn is connected to the various items of laundry machinery through belts and pulleys. Since the electrical services at the school are taken care of by a direct current generating unit, which incidentally is loaded to capacity, it is not possible to drive the laundry machinery by means of electric motors.

When prices have been received for the proposed new engine, a further recommendation will be submitted for your approval and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Chief Engineer.
December 7, 1948.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Broadview, Sask.

Cowessess Residential School - Steam Engine

It is understood that the low pressure heating boiler has been installed and is now in operation at this school.

Our reports indicate that the brick layer should have finished bricking-in the high pressure boiler by this time. As you are probably aware, we have spent a considerable sum at this school this year and our funds are running low.

Therefore, our engineers have been asked to advise with regard to carrying on with the old steam engine. Their report is attached hereto in duplicate.

Would you please confer with the principal of the school and find out whether it is possible for these adjustments to be made locally. Mr. Hargreaves advises me that one of the Brothers at the school might be capable of providing temporary adjustments.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

o/c to Rev. J.O. Plourde, OMI.

Ottawa, December 17, 1948.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Land and Development Services Branch
Cowessess Indian Residential School

Immediately your memorandum of December 1 was received here, we wrote to Mr. Indian Superintendent Kerley concerning its contents.

We have now received a self-explanatory reply from him reading as follows:-

"With reference to the above mentioned letter, I beg to report that I have conferred with the Principal of the school, and find that the old Casq Steam Engine has been dismantled and broken up and, is now in no shape to be used even if no other one is available. At the present time the laundry is being done by a small electric washer, and by hand. This engine was condemned by the Provincial Inspector, and was really dangerous to use, the metal in many places being too thin to work on.

It was found that the flues on the furnace shipped down from the Indian Hospital at Fort Qu'Appelle, were leaking, and had to be replaced before it could be used, this will mean an added expense to the amount estimated by Mr. Hargreaves.

We tried to get an estimate of a suitable engine to be used there and find that there is not one in either Regina or Winnipeg but that there is a possibility of one in Calgary. On receipt of more information we will forward same to the Department."
It has been found that the electrical unit is not capable of driving the laundry machinery; the Principal requests that a steam engine be installed as soon as possible. There would not be room in the Boiler Room for the old Case engine even if it could be made serviceable.

In view of the expense of installing a new steam engine, we would appreciate being advised whether a small diesel would suffice for our requirements at this school.

Acting Director.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

December 23, 1948.

Memorandum:

Departmental Purchasing Agent

Re: Cowessess Indian Residential School
Purchase of Diesel Engine

Formerly the laundry and drying unit at the above Residential School were operated by an old Case Steam Engine unit. This engine became so old and worn that it was necessary to dismantle it. It was condemned by the Provincial Boiler Inspector as being too dangerous to use. In some places the metal was too thin to work with. The purpose of the steam is to drive a line of shafting and counter-shafting which in turn is connected to the various items of laundry machinery through belts and pulleys. Since the electrical services at the school are taken care of by a direct current generating unit, which unfortunately is loaded to capacity, it is not possible to drive the laundry machinery by means of electrical motors.

On December 17, a memorandum was submitted to the Lands and Development Services Branch concerning the installation of a small Diesel Engine at this school. We have just received a call from the Engineering and Construction Division of this Branch advising that a 20 horse power Diesel is available at the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Factory. This firm has quoted to our Engineer a price of $1,660.00 f.o.b. the Cowessess Residential School, Grayson, Saskatchewan. Apparently we are very fortunate in being able to locate such an engine and particularly at a price which is so fair and reasonable.

I was advised by the Engineers that immediate action will be necessary if we are to secure this machine. I
have, therefore, prepared a requisition for its purchase and am sending this letter and the requisition to you by hand. I would appreciate your phoning to Mr. Lee of the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Branch in Ottawa at phone number 3-7779 if you can obtain the necessary approval for its purchase.

At the present time, it is necessary to do all the laundry at this school by a small electrical washer or by hand. It is obvious that this condition cannot last for any length of time particularly as the Indians are complaining about the use of child labour in our school. Normally, it would take three or four months to obtain such an engine, and we would appreciate your cooperation in obtaining the one mentioned above which can be delivered in two or three weeks.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Cowessessess Residential School,
Low Pressure Steam Boiler.

The low pressure furnace recently installed in the Cowessess Residential School was found to be badly in need of new flues, the first time it was operated, many of the flues were found to be rusted out and not safe to use; as a matter of fact they were in a far worse condition than the flues in the furnace that was taken out.

There is no doubt that although this furnace was only in operation twice at the hospital water must have been left in it and the flues rusted out.

Enclosed herewith is a requisition for the very necessary repairs to put the furnace in operation.

W. J. D. Kerley,
Superintendent.

re Diesel Engine for Cowessess Indian Residential School

In Mr. Neary's memorandum of the 23rd ultimo - file reference '651-5 (E)' - there was a statement to the effect that Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co., Limited, quoted a price of $1,660.00 f.o.b. Grayson, Saskatchewan.

As your requisition did not give any other details other than 20-HP Diesel Engine was required, we requested the company to furnish full information regarding the type of engine they are in a position to supply as well as a written confirmation of price.

Their quotation of the 29th ultimo was $2,162.00 f.o.b. Montreal, duty and federal sales tax included. They quoted on their Model 48AS 4½ Diesel Power Unit complete with standard equipment. The rating given was 32-HP at 1,800 rpm and approximately 19.5-HP at 1,200 rpm.

In view of the difference in the above quotations, will you please arrange to supply us with the original quotation of $1,660.00 f.o.b. Grayson, Saskatchewan. Please also let us know if the model quoted by the Ottawa office is satisfactory.

W. M. Vincent.
Indian Affairs Branch

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

While the extensive repairs to the heating and plumbing system at Gordon's Residential School were being made, a vertical boiler was purchased. Our understanding is that this boiler could not be properly installed at the Gordon's Residential School owing to lack of space, and it was necessary to secure a horizontal boiler.

Payment was not made for the vertical boiler, and before it had been finally decided that it could not be used, the president of the plumbing company doing the work died, and his business was evidently taken over by someone else. While the contract for the plumbing and heating was satisfactorily completed, the new owner did not wish to take back the vertical boiler.

At that time, Mr. Hargreaves of your Division was in the west and ascertained that a new boiler was needed at the Cowessess School, and it was found that the vertical boiler, surplus to requirements at the Gordon's School, would be satisfactory for the Cowessess School. Arrangements were then made to transfer the vertical boiler to that school.

We have now received an account amounting to $932.86 covering the cost of the vertical boiler, and we will have to secure a Purchase Order before payment can be made.
We would, therefore, appreciate it if you would let us have as much information as your Branch has available, in order to assist us in securing a Purchase Order.

PP/ST Director.
Indian Affairs Branch

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to the enclosed copy of a Purchase Order for a Diesel Power Unit which has been delivered to the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Grayson, at a cost of $2,162.00, when visiting at the Cowessess School recently, and discussing this motor with Reverend Father Lemire, the Principal, and Indian Superintendent W.J.D. Kerley, it appeared that this equipment cannot be used satisfactorily at the Cowessess School for lighting purposes.

No generator came with the power unit, and a generator of an A.C. type is required to use it. Even if a generator is supplied, the Reverend Principal is not satisfied with such an arrangement without batteries. This type of power unit is for furnishing power direct from the generator without storage batteries. As the Department is aware, storage batteries are practically essential at a residential school, as it often happens that one or two lights are necessary through the night because of sickness and for the use of the Night Watchmen in his travels. Such temporary lights cannot be supplied without starting the motor unless there are storage batteries.

Reverend Father Lemire informed me that when Mr. Hargreaves visited his school he drew to the attention of Mr. Hargreaves that new storage batteries would be needed shortly, as the old ones have just about outlived their usefulness. Indian Superintendent Kerley informed me that he forwarded to the Department a requisition for new batteries.

Neither Reverend Father Lemire nor Mr. Kerley are aware of any requisition having been forwarded to the Department for the power unit which has been delivered.

Please instruct me further in this connection.

J.P.B. Ostander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, July 12, 1949.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR OF LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Cowessess Indian Residential School

I desire to refer you to our memorandum of Nov. 26th, 1948, and your reply of Dec. 1st, 1948, and subsequent memoranda in connection with supplying a Diesel engine to the above school.

Mr. Hargreaves is aware of the requirements at that school which resulted in our purchasing a Diesel power unit at a cost of $2,162.00. A copy of our purchase order is attached for your information.

Also attached is a copy of letter dated June 20th, 1949, from Regional Supervisor Ostrander. This letter explains itself, and we would appreciate it if you would advise us as soon as possible what further action you consider should be taken.

Acting Director.
MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, July 18, 1949.

Re: Cowesses Indian Residential School, Saskatchewan.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of July 12th bearing your marginal notation of the 14th instant, to which was attached copy of Regional Supervisor Ostrander's letter of June 20th, you are advised as follows:

Mr. Ostrander's letter indicates a total lack of knowledge regarding the purpose served by the diesel engine referred to, and it is felt that a brief review of the facts at this time would be worthwhile.

Our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above school last August and recommended that a new high pressure boiler be purchased and installed, as the existing threshing machine type high pressure boiler was in a precarious state. It was felt at that time, that the steam engine, which was mounted on the old boiler, could be salvaged, repaired and connected to the new high pressure boiler and could continue to drive the line shafting which powers the laundry machinery.

However, in dismantling the boiler, the engine was found to be in such poor condition, that it could be put to no further use.

We then recommended the purchase of a diesel engine fitted with a suitable fly-wheel pulley for driving the laundry line shafting. Our memorandum to you dated January 15th for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, clearly stated the purpose of this unit.

It would appear that Mr. Ostrander's letter was written before he acquainted himself with the facts. It also appears that neither the Principal nor Indian Superintendent Kerley were informed by the Indian Affairs Branch as to the reason for supplying this engine, or if so, they both have failed to remember.

When our officer made his visit, Principal Lemire was verbally advised to request the Indian Affairs Branch through Indian Superintendent Kerley for new batteries when required, for use in the existing DC diesel operated lighting plant.

In the light of the above information, it can be clearly seen that the diesel engine recently supplied to the school, has no connection whatever with the lighting plant, but is intended to provide power through pulleys and line shafting to operate the laundry equipment.

Chas. H. Buck,
For Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

CANADA
AIR MAIL

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrender,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Re: Cowessess Residential School
Your File No. 1496-6-6-108

We received your letter of June 20th with reference to a Diesel Power Unit recently delivered to the above school.

During the fall of 1948 Mr. Hargreaves of the Lands and Development Services visited the school and on his return advised that he had inspected the mechanical equipment and discussed with the Reverend principal their requirements. As a result of his visit the Lands and Development Services recommended the purchase of a Diesel Power Unit to which you refer in your letter. In recommending the purchase the Lands and Development Services wrote as follows:

"We have investigated the performance and general characteristics of the Fairbanks-Morse Company Model 48AS 41 diesel power unit which is offered complete with standard equipment, and it is our opinion that the Indian Affairs Branch would be well advised to purchase this unit for driving the line shafting in connection with the various items of laundry equipment at the above.

It is recommended that this machine be run at 1200 R.P.M., at which speed a rating of 19-5 H.P. can be obtained. This capacity should be sufficient for the purpose.

In view of Mr. Hargreaves' visit to the school, we do not feel that it was necessary to explain this matter..."
Again to the principal as we felt that he understood the reasons for supplying the power unit.

Memorandum

Indian Affairs Branch

Re Replacement batteries for Cowessess Indian Residential School.
I.A.B. File 651-5E1.

We note from Mr. Phelan's memorandum of the 23rd instant, that the Principal of the above school requests replacement set Globelite Batteries W.17, 360 A.H. capacity. In this connection it is our understanding that the Battery supplied in February 1940 was 180 A.H. capacity. Where such a heavy set is actually needed, we would like to check the estimated daily watt hour load to insure having a battery of sufficient power. A W.17 battery, 56 cell, furnishes 8000 watt hours per day, which seems excessive. Would it be possible for the Principal to advise the number of lamps, the wattage of same, and the approximate number of hours the washing machines, electric irons, or other appliances that are operated on the battery.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Re File 651-5 (E.l), Sept. 29th, 1949.

Replying to your above letter a 180 A.H. battery is sufficient for the Cowessess Residential School. The present batteries are G.D. 13 - 180 A.H. 56 cells Serial No. 8696.

The average daily consumption is estimated at 6½ K.W. hours. There are five motors as follows:
1 - 1 H.P.
2 - ¼ H.P.
2 - 1/8 H.P.

It is arranged so that all motors do not cut in at the same time.

In the various buildings there are 181 lamps averaging 40 watts each.

Dear Mr. Neary:

According to the 1944 Census, the Indians of the Crooked Lake Agency had, at that time, 173 children of school age.

The population since then has increased considerably. I am informed that there are over 200 children who are asking to be admitted to the Cowesses School, and there is no room for them as only about 100 can be received in the present school.

Some two years ago, promise was made that a class-room block would be built so as to make room for the large number of children who are not yet receiving any education.

Circumstances apparently did not allow you to proceed with this project, but it is hoped that you may do so during the current fiscal year.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

As you are aware, we included in our appropriation a few years ago, an amount for a classroom block at the Cowessess Indian Residential School. We did not proceed with the construction of this building, and no funds have been provided for it in the appropriation for the current fiscal year.

We have received representations lately that the school management has been applying for some years past for a classroom block at this school, and they consider that funds for the construction of the building should be included in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1950-51.

Please let us have your comments on the matter by army signal as soon as possible. It is noted that you did not include this item in your letter of October 7th, in which you forwarded a list of the Indian day schools which you consider should be erected in the Province of Saskatchewan during the next fiscal year.

Philip Phelan,

RE LETTER NOVEMBER 4 ADDITIONAL CLASSROOM CONVESSS RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL MR OSTRANDER ON NORTHERN INSPECTIONS THIS WEEK CONVENT AS REQUESTED BY ARMY MESSAGE IMMEDIATELY HE RETURNS TO REGINA OFFICE

SCOVILL

PM/AS
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Attention of Mr. Phelan

Your letter of the 4th instant, File 1-1-5 Sask./651-5 (EL) arrived in this office on November 7th when I was absent in the northern part of the province. You will have received an Army Message from Mr. H.F. Scovill acknowledging receipt of the letter and advising that the matter referred to would be given attention upon my return to the office.

I am not giving the information by Army Signal as tomorrow is a holiday and an Air Mail letter will reach the Department on Saturday morning, the 12th.

With regard to the matter of a classroom block for the Cowessess Indian Residential School I was under the impression that funds are available in this year's Appropriation to build the classroom block, but that the Department had delayed the construction because of the fact that a decision had not been made as to what kind of a building would be constructed if one was constructed at all.

It has always been my opinion that a separate building is needed at the Cowessess School, and that if it is built it should be a dormitory building of one storey.

I know the Department is aware that the Cowessess School is not by any means safe against loss of life by fire. It would burn very quickly, and has too many corridors and corners where trouble could result if children had to be removed from the school quickly during the night. With this in mind I must say that I cannot agree with the policy of having the children in a safe building of one storey in the daytime for classroom work, and at night in a dangerous location, too high off the ground for them to jump out safely in case of fire. Actually, the classrooms in the main building at the Cowessess School leave little to be desired, and one more classroom could easily be added in the main building in one of the dormitories if a dormitory building of one storey was built a short distance away from the main building.

I know there are some objections to having children sleeping on the ground floor, but one very important thing in its favour is that in case of fire if a doorway gets blocked there is no difficulty in kicking out a window or windows through which the children can climb with safety. If the school authorities do not wish to have the older girls and boys sleeping on the ground floor of a one storey dormitory building I see no reason why arrangements could not be made in such a building for sleeping quarters for all the younger children of both sexes. Certainly, in case of fire, the older boys and girls are much less likely to have difficulty in vacating the building by the fire escapes.

It is my recommendation that a dormitory building be erected on a suitable plan to provide dormitory space for 40 boys and 40 girls and that the classrooms remain in the main building. If it is decided to approve my recommendation I see no reason why this building could not be constructed in....
not be constructed in two parts, if necessary constructing half of it, or accommodation for 40 children in 1950, and, if found practical, an addition to house another 40 children could be added in 1951. I suggest this because of the fact that the present emergency would be met, and there would be sufficient room in the building suggested to provide accommodation for 40, or all of the younger children. The immediate fire hazard would thus be partially met, and the dormitory space now being used by those 40 children could become classroom space.

I am unable to give any estimate of the cost of a building to provide dormitory space for 40 children, but I have no doubt that the Engineering Services could furnish a close enough estimate on this for immediate use in providing the money in the 1950-51 Appropriation.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Voucher No. 856

DATE: Nov. 30th, 1949
Cowessess Indian Residential School:

Additional accommodation:

With Mr. Supt Kerley I surveyed the existing buildings and the nearby reserves and checked population statistics. I had a long discussion also with the Reverend Principal and he and the Departmental officials concerned concur in the following recommendations:

(1) Instead of a class-room block on the school grounds, supply modern dormitory space.

(2) Convert the Cowessess Agency office to school purposes

(3) Permit the attendance as day pupils at the residential school of the few Indian children who could go attend.

(4) Permit the residential school to serve the metis or non-Indian children who live near the reserve (on road allowances and other non-taxpaying property).

Regarding the first recommendation Mr. Regional supervisor Ostrander wrote to you on November 10th, suggesting a one-story dormitory building. This might not be adequate for the needs of this area, as the children are so scattered that residential facilities are necessary for a minimum of one hundred twenty pupils unless it is the intention to go back to one-room and two-room schools and abandon the advantages which concentration of pupils permits. I may seem to be contradicting myself in recommending the one-room or two-room school at the old agency, but I have to suggest that the eligible pupils from this school receive their vocational training at the residential school centre. Other ways in which they could share the activities of the larger centre could be arranged. The people for miles around visit the school's new hall for movies, pool and bowling.

The residential school has an authorized pupilage of 110. I counted 125 present. That means that some sleep two to a bed. The plumbing is ancient and inadequate for mass use but would serve for individual use during school-hours. The corridors, stairways and fire escapes seem to me hazardous during the hours of darkness.

The present main building could continue to supply living quarters and chapel for the staff, office and reception rooms, infirmary and sewing quarters. In this building there are at present three rooms being used as class-rooms and a fourth room as a sewing-instruction room. The former larger sewing-room has become a dormitory; 16 girls and one staff member. It could be a regular class-room. The two top-floor dormitories which have dormer windows and sloping ceilings could be adapted for class work, perhaps for the lower grades or for manual arts. Thus there would be room for 150 or more pupils during the day. As a start a dormitory building for girls only would release half the attic and the small girls' dormitory and allow a safer distribution of the boys on the top floor and make available one more classroom.
The second suggestion (converting the agency office) might get under way at an early date so as to use any funds surplus to requirements between now and March 31st 1950. The cost will be comparable to the cost at Saddle Lake or Winterburn (Stonyplain).

The third recommendation might be arranged to go into effect after Christmas on an experimental basis. It would relieve some of the present congestion in dormitories.

The fourth suggestion would involve some negotiations with the Province of Saskatchewan, but the school already deals with the Province because the nearby Metis school is taught by a reverend sister who is associated with the residential school. The single Grade 8 pupil enrolled at the residential school in reality does her school work as a pupil at the Metis school. Here is an opportunity to implement the Parliamentary Committee's recommendation that wherever possible Indian children be educated along with other children. There are presently about thirty-five of these Metis. If they were consolidated with the residential school and distributed throughout the grades (as day pupils or in some cases boarders), another teacher could be added to strengthen the present staff and to permit better division of the grades. Social conditions in the area would also be subject to improvement. The Cowessess Co-op is already an example of Indians co-operating with non-Indians, so also is Grouard. In the educational field there are already similar mergers at Grouard, Fort Chipewyan, Ermineskin, (Church-owned residential schools) and Hobbs, Big Eddy and Wahpotan Sioux day schools. The fact that Cowessess is a government-owned school would allow the Department to have a voice in the negotiations.

C.A.F. Clark

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
304 Post Office Building,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

COWESSOON SCHOOL.

I have noted Major Clark's report of December 6 and his discussions concerning the best type of educational facilities to be provided for the children living near the Cowessos Residential School.

PROPOSAL 1:

It would seem that the need is for a modern dormitory building instead of a classroom block. We have such a dormitory building now being designed and I would ask that Mr. Kerley write to me again in late January, when I should be able to provide him with a set of these plans for further discussion with the Principal.

PROPOSAL 2:

I have already written indicating our concurrence in the establishment of a day school in the former Cowessos agency buildings.

PROPOSAL 3:

We have a number now of residential schools who are admitting day school pupils and the Department pays a share
of the teacher's salary on a proportionate basis. I concur in Major Clark's recommendation that some of the children living near the school begin attending on a day basis after the Christmas holidays and in this way relieve the present congestion in the dormitories.

PROPOSAL A:

This would of course involve rather lengthy negotiations with the Saskatchewan Department of Education.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Flag 12 - Memorandum dated July 18th, 1949, from the Lands and Development Services Branch answering Mr. Ostrander's letter.

CROOKED LAKE AGENCY BROADVIEW, ASSA.

241633 APR 4 - 1908

Ref.: Your Letter No.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform the Department that a meeting of the members of Cowessos' Band was held here yesterday at which twenty four were present.

It was unanimously agreed to the Roman Catholic mission and Board School the use of forty acres of land commencing from about 100 yards south of the school building down to the Sibley River, so long as it was used for mission and school purposes only. If for any reason they are removed or abandoned, the land to revert to the Band.

This was passed subject to the approval of the Department, and the Rev. Principal agreed to pay the expenses of the survey.

I consider the amount of land hereby ceded to be about what they require for school and mission purposes and the Principal agreed that if it was found in the future, that more land was needed, they would get it across the River off the Reserve. If approved by the Department, I should be glad to receive the necessary forms to complete the transaction.

I have the honour to be Sir,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-9, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 4th inst., I beg to inform you that you may grant permission to the authorities of the Roman Catholic Mission and Boarding School to occupy the tract of land containing 40 acres in Reserve No. 73 of Cowessess band desired, to be held by them so long as it is used for mission and school purposes, and during the pleasure of the Department.

As stated in your letter the land in question should be surveyed; care should be taken to have the survey tied to a corner of the reserve or some other well known point, in order that it may be correctly plotted on plans in the Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Deputy Sect. General
of Indian Affairs.

Magnus Berg, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Assin.

Cowessess Boarding School,
Crooked Lake Agency,
8th April, 1907.

Mr. H. Miller,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I desire to purchase for the purpose of making
a farm in connection with our Indian boarding school, t
the following land belonging to Cowessess Band of
Indians. That is to say, the portion of land bounded
on the east by Weed creek, on the north by the hill,
on the west by Crooked Lake, on the north by the
Qu'Appelle river, with the exception of four acres
intended for Cemetery and church purposes.

The price I am willing to pay is $15.00 per
acre cash.

In connection with this application I have
reason to believe that a good majority of the Indians
will be favorable to making the surrender, and that
the price stated will be satisfactory, as I consider
it a very fair valuation.

I would be pleased if the Department at an
early a date as possible would have a deed of
surrender submitted to the Indians for their approval,
so that the land could be surveyed by the survey
party, who I understand, is to shortly begin surveying
the other portions of the Indian lands which have
been surrendered.

Asking favorable consideration of this
application,

I am,

Yours truly,

(Sig'd.) S. Perreault,
Principal.
Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter dated 8th instant of the Rev. S. Perreault, Principal of Cowessess Boarding School, addressed to me, asking for a deed of surrender to be submitted to the Indians of Cowessess band for certain lands situated near the school, which he desires to purchase, and is willing to pay $15.00 per acre for cash for the land. He states it as his opinion that a majority of the Indians will favor a surrender if it is submitted.

I forward the application to you and would request that you will be good enough to forward same to the Department with a report in the matter, as you are familiar with the circumstances.

I beg to point out if it is decided to ask the Indians to surrender this land for the purpose stated, that care must be taken to reserve a roadway, say 60' wide between the south boundary and the base of the hill for the purpose of making a roadway through the land asked for to Crooked Lake, along the bank of which a great deal of the wood, and most of the building timber belonging to this Band is located, and is only accessible by crossing the land which Father Perreault desires to purchase.

I may also point out that the only hay obtainable in the valley is included in the portion of land described by the Rev. Father. The hay flat is on the north side and near the Qu'Appelle river.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Insp. of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres.
It might be well to consider whether this hay land should be kept for the Indians.

It is said to be the wish of the Indians, in the event of surrender of this land, that they should be paid the whole of the proceeds in equal shares per capita, no part of the proceeds to be funded. Father Perrault is prepared to pay $3,000.00 at time of taking surrender, and the balance as soon as the quantity of land is ascertained.

Yours truly,

(Signed) M. Miller,
Indian Agent.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev. Father Perreault, Principal of the Cowessess Boarding School on Cowessess Reserve, asking that a block of land in the rear of his school about 200 acres and owned by the Indians be sold to the Roman Catholic Church for the purpose of establishing a home farm in connection with the school.

I also enclose a copy of our letter from our Agent at Crooked Lakes dealing with the matter.

When at Crooked Lakes last winter the matter was brought up by the Rev. Principal, who is much handicapped in not having a farm in connection with his school (which is a good one) and I went over the property and I consider the price offered viz. $15.00 per acre full value. I do not however approve of selling any new land that might be included, but as this is all at one end of the property it could well be withheld.

The large majority of the Indians on Cowessess reserve are treaty half-breeds and members of the Roman Catholic Church and I am led to believe that they are willing to sell, and if the Department grants the Principal's request I would suggest that the surveyors who are to be on this reserve in a short

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa

The Principal is quite anxious to secure the land and would commence farming operations in June if possible.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

April 30, 1907.

Memorandum for Deputy Minister,

I think that if you approve, instructions might be sent to Mr. Reid to survey 200 acres of land in the Crooked Lake Reserve No. 75 (Crooked Lake) to be surrendered and sold to the Roman Catholic Church authorities as recommended by Mr. Inspector Graham in letter hereunder or the next instant.

It is to be noted, however, that Mr. Agent Miller says that the Indians desire that they should be paid the whole of the proceeds of the sale of the land. The Act provides that only one half may be paid them. I think this point should be explained to the Indians, and if they are still willing to make the surrender, the survey may go ahead; if not it is to be held in abeyance.

Dr. Minister,

This land is situated in the northern and unoccupied portion of the Reserve. It will require to be surrendered in the usual manner; for this purpose the survey is required. Mr. Reid is now surveying the southern and surrendered part of the reserve. S. Bury, 14 May 1907.
The piece of land is at the North end of the River. The surrendered portion is the South part.

S. B. [Signature]
Ottawa, May 15, 1907.

Sir:—

I have to request you to communicate with Mr. Inspector Graham, and Agent Millar, with the view of surveying a block of about 300 acres of land applied for by the Principal of the Cowessess Boarding School.

The land is to be surrendered by the Indians. Mr. Graham has been authorized to take the surrender. I have, however, to inform you that the Indians desire that the whole of the proceeds be divided among them. The Department is willing to distribute the full amount allowed by law, viz 50%. If the Indians do not accede to this, you are not to make the survey and no further action in the matter is to be taken.

The survey is to be made in the usual manner or which you are well informed. If at all convenient, the lines should conform with the projected section lines or be parallel to them. Mr. Agent Miller will also inform you of a road allowance to be surveyed in connection with the proposed surrender.

Your obedient servant

J. L. Reid, Esq., D.L.S.,
c/o M. Millar, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

CANADA
Ottawa, May 18, 1907.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 16th ultimo, No. 5, and enclosures, I beg to inform you that Mr. J. L. Reid will be instructed to communicate with you and with the Agent, Mr. Millar, with a view of surveying the block of about 200 acres of land applied for by the Rev. Father Pendult, Principal of the Cowesses Boarding School.

The forms of surrender which are enclosed herewith and which you are hereby authorized to submit to the Indians in accordance with the provisions of the "Indian act" have been prepared, allowing for lease or sale as may hereafter be decided upon; the Department considering that the sale of a block of land situated within a reserve is not always advisable, and it may be that in the present case a lease will be preferable. If the sale is made the Department can distribute to the Indians only the per cent allowed by law namely, 50 per cent, the rest will have to be funded for the benefit of the band. Should a lease be decided upon, however, the rental payable thereunder can be distributed to the Indians in cash or expended for their benefit as may be arranged or decided according to the circumstances during the currency of the lease.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.

CANADA
I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter above quoted with enclosure as stated therein. I was just taking the train at Broadview for Regina when I received your letter. I returned to the Reserve three days later and held a meeting of Cowessos Band for the purpose of obtaining a surrender of 200 acres of their land for School purposes. There was a full meeting of the Band, who were unanimous in refusing any proposition I could offer them.

The Band is quite willing to sell 200 acres to the School authorities for $15.00 per acre, providing all the cash is paid to them; and nothing deducted for the land management fund, as they would not accept any other proposition I am returning you the forms of Surrender you sent me.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, July 5, 1907.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th ultimo, No. 5 and of the blank forms of surrender returned therewith, relating to the proposed surrender of 200 acres of land for school purposes in the Cowessess Indian Reserve. Kindly inform Father Penault of the decision of the Indians. You will, of course, understand that it is impossible for the Department to accept any surrender that does not comply with the Statute.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Secretary.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.
Sir,

I have just received a letter from Indian Agent Miller of Crooked Lakes stating that the Chief and Councilors of Cowessess Band had called at his office and requested him to notify me that they would now be willing to surrender the 200 acres of land to the Roman Catholic Church for School purposes on the condition that they receive $15.00 per acre (which amount has been offered) and a cash payment of 50% of the whole. If you feel disposed to send me the papers I will have them executed in time. Fifteen hundred dollars will be required to make the payment.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 11, 1907.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 3rd instant, with further reference to the question of surrender of 200 acres of land by the Cowesses Band of Indians for school purposes, and stating that the Chief and Councillors had expressed a willingness to surrender the land on the condition that they receive $15 per acre and a cash payment of fifty per cent. of the whole, I beg to point out that in your letter of the 7th ultimo, returning the draft surrender, it is stated that the Band was then willing to dispose of this land for $15 per acre, but without deducting anything for land management fund. You will, therefore, be good enough to state whether this exception is made in connection with their last proposition, as you are aware that the Department cannot accept a surrender which does not comply with the Statute.

Your obedient Servant,

S. STEWART
Assistant Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of letter above quoted and in reply to say that I took it for granted as the matter was fully explained to them in the first place that the Indians of Cowesses would agree to the deduction of 10% and then accept 50% of the balance. However as you have raised the question I have written to Crooked Lakes to find out if the Indians are agreeable to this deduction for Land management being made.

When I hear from Crooked Lakes I will communicate again with you.

I have the Honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary

Dept of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.
Dear Sir,

I beg to write you again about the land I desire to purchase for the purpose of making a farm in connection with the Cowessess Indian Boarding School; the following land belonging to Cowessess Band of Indians, that is to say, the portion of land bounded on the east by Wood creek, on the south by the Hill, on the west by Blackwood lake on the north by the Red apple river; the approximate area being from three to four hundred acres which I am willing to pay $15.00 per acre cash.

In connection with this application I may state that a good majority of the Indians have already declared before the Inspector and Agent that they would be willing to make the surrender for the price I propose them and at the conditions set by the Indian Department.

I would be pleased if the Department at an early date as possible would have a deed of surrender submitted to the Indians for their approval so that the land could be surveyed at once and breaking would not be delayed.

Hoping a prompt and favourable consideration of this application.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-9, part 1)

Ottawa, June 3, 1908.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 29th ultimo, in regard to the question of acquisition by the Cowesses Indian Boarding School of a portion of land on Cowesses Reserve, and in reply to say that, when the question of surrender of a portion of their land for the above purpose was submitted to the Indians about a year ago, they expressed their unwillingness to surrender the land unless they received more than the Department could authorize under the provisions of the Act.

You might submit your application to Mr. Inspector Graham, and furnish him with such a description as would enable the Department to identify the land, for his report thereon to the Department.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

S. Perrault, Esq.,
Principal Cowesses Indian Boarding School,
Broadview, Sask.
Sir,

Referring to past correspondence on the subject of surrendering about three or four hundred acres of Land on the Valley of the Qu'Appelle on Cowessess Reserve for School purposes— I beg to say that the Revd Father Perrault Principal of the Cowessess Boarding School forwarded me a copy of your letter to him dated June 3rd., No.174864-22 in which you suggested that he take up the matter with me again. Since the receipt of this letter I visited the Cowessess School and have gone over the land and I think there is somewhere in the neighbourhood of 350 acres. You will remember when this matter was first taken up, it was thought there were about 250 acres in the piece asked for. The Land in question is situated as follows:- Situated on the East end of the Crooked Lake, bounded on the North by the Qu'Appelle River, on the East by Weed Creek, on the West by the Lake on the River.

The Secretary

Dept of Indian Affairs

Ottawa.
The Indians are now quite willing to surrender the Land to the Roman Catholic Church for the purposes mentioned, and are willing to accept the terms offered, viz $15.00 per acre, and a payment of 50% at the time of signing after deducting 10% for Land management.

The Revd Father Perrault informs me that he has the cash ready to make the full payment, and I would suggest that the payment be made of 50% at the time of signing on the three hundred acre basis, and after the Land has been surveyed and the exact acreage determined, the difference, if any, can be paid to the Indians.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Inspr of Indian Agencies
Ottawa, September 8, 1908.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 24th ultimo, No. 5, in regard to the question of surrender of a portion of the Cowessess Indian Reserve, applied for by the Rev. Father Perrault principal of the Cowessess Boarding School, and in reply to inclose form of surrender, in duplicate, which you are hereby authorized to submit to the Indians under and in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Act.

Cheque No. 487, for the sum of $2,025.00, for payment to the Indians at the time of signing the surrender, is herewith inclosed.

The cash payment proposed to be made by Rev. Father Perrault may be accepted and forwarded to the Department along with the surrender.

Your obedient Servant,

FRANK PEDLEY

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.
Sir,

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter above quoted, I have the honour to inform you that I arrived at Crooked Lakes Agency on the 11th instant and took steps at once to notify the Indians that there would be a meeting on the 13th of the month for the purpose of submitting the surrender to them. The meeting was duly held in accordance with the rules of the Band and the Surrender submitted. Nearly every male Indian on the reserve was present and the vote was almost unanimous, only three voting against the proposition.

After completing the papers I started in to pay them the fifty per cent proceeds of Cheque No. 487, $2025.00. All Indians present were paid, but it will be some weeks before I can send you the pay-sheet, as there were a good many female absentees.

As instructed I am sending you an Imperial Bank Draft for the money received from Rev. Father Farrault, Five thousand, two hundred and fifty dollars ($5,250.00). There were three hundred and fifty acres at fifteen dollars per acre.

I am also sending you the forms of surrender duly executed.

Frank Pedley Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
executed. If it is too late to have the exact area of land in the piece described in former letters, determined this fall, Father Farrault would like to have the survey made in the spring so that the matter could be finally adjusted.

I trust you will find the papers etc. in connection with this matter in order.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Graham
Insp. of Indian Agencies.
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
submits herewith a surrender, in duplicate, made on the 13th
day of November,, 1908, by the Cowessess Band of Indians,
of 350 acres (described in the surrender) of their reserve,
No. 73, in the Crooked Lakes Agency, in the Province of
Saskatchewan, the said surrender having been made with a
view to the land covered thereby being sold for the benefit
of the band.

The Minister recommends—as the surrender has been
duly authorized and executed in the manner required by the
49th Section of the Indian Act,—that the same be accepted
by Your Excellency in Council under that Section,and that
authority be given for the land covered thereby being dis-
posed of by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs in
the best interests of the Indians concerned, without refer-
ence to the Land Regulations of the Department of Indian
Affairs, as established by the Order in Council of the 15th
September, 1888; the original surrender to be returned to
the Department of Indian Affairs and the duplicate to be
kept of record in the Privy Council Office.

The Committee submit the same for approval

[Signature]

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Know all Men by these Presents

THAT WE, the undersigned Chief and Principal men of

The Cowessess Band of Indians

resident on our Reserve on Crooked Lakes

in the Province of Saskatchewan and Dominion of Canada.

for and acting on behalf of the whole people of our said Band in Council assembled. Do hereby release, remise, surrender, quit claim and yield up unto Our Sovereign Lord the King, his Heirs and Successors forever, ALL AND SINGULAR, that certain parcel or tract of land and premises situate, lying and being in the Cowessess Indian Reserve No. 75 in the County of Saskatchewan containing by admeasurement about three hundred and fifty acres be the same more or less and being described as follows:— Situated on the east end of the Crooked Lake, bounded on the north by the Qu'Appelle River, on the east by Weed Creek, on the west by the Lake on the River, and on the south by the road allowance of the Saskatchewan Government.

Save and except a road allowance from the Steel Bridge on Section 4, Township 19A, Range 5, to the Weed Creek.

Form No. 68.
TO HAVE AND TO HOLD the same unto His said Majesty THE KING, his Heirs and Successors forever, in trust to sell the same to such person or persons, and upon such terms as the Government of the Dominion of Canada may deem most conducive to our welfare and that of our people.

AND upon the further condition that all moneys received from the sale thereof, shall, after deducting the usual proportion for expenses of management, be and fifty per cent. of the balance to be paid over to the Indians at time of signing these presents, be placed to our credit and interest thereon paid us, in the usual way.

AND WE, the said Chief and Principal men of the said Cowesass Band of Indians do on behalf of our people and for ourselves hereby ratify and confirm, and promise to ratify and confirm, whatever the said Government may do, or cause to be lawfully done, in connection with the sale of the said land and the disposition of the moneys arising therefrom.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, we have hereunto set our hands and affixed our seals this Thirteenth day of November in the year of Our Lord one thousand nine hundred and eight.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered,

Joseph Lerat his x (seal)
mark

Ambroise Delorme his x " mark

Alexander Gaddie his x " mark

Baptiste Henry his x " mark

Francois Delorme his x " mark

Pieriche Peltier his x " mark

Kanawaswevetung his x " mark

(sgd) W. M. Graham
Insp'r of Indian Agencies.
Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 30 Nov 1908

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, 1st December, 1906.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to submit herewith a surrender, in duplicate, made on the 15th day of November, 1906, by the Cowessess Band of Indians, of 350 acres (described in the surrender) of their reserve, No. 78, in the Crooked Lakes Agency, in the Province of Saskatchewan, the said surrender having been made with a view to the land covered thereby being sold for the benefit of the band.

The surrender has been duly authorised and executed in the manner required by the 49th Section of the Indian Act, and the undersigned would respectfully recommend that the same be accepted by Your Excellency in Council under that Section, and that authority be given for the land covered thereby being disposed of by the Superintendent General in the best interests of the Indians concerned, without reference to the Land Regulations or the Department of Indian Affairs, as established by Order in Council of 15th September, 1906; the original surrender to be returned to the Department of Indian Affairs and the duplicate to be kept of record in the Privy Council Office.

for Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Received from Dept., on account of Indian Funds, the sum of two thousand twenty-five dollars, which amount will appear at the Receiver General's credit with this Bank.

Signed in Triplicate,

Pro Manager.

CANADA
Ottawa, December 11, 1908.

Sir:

Re: Block of two hundred acres of land applied for by the Principal of the Cowessess Boarding School.

In compliance with your instructions of May 15th, 1907, 174664-22, I interviewed Agent Millar and the Indians regarding the survey of this land. The Indians refusing to accede, no survey was made.

Your obedient servant,

J. Lestock Reid

This block of land has been recently surrendered and sold for the use of the Cowessess Boarding School. The description in the purchase is not definite. The land should be regularly surveyed and posted. With your approval, J. D. McLean, Esq., will note the survey for Secretary, execution at as early a date as may be convenient.

Ottawa, Ont.

Description for Patent.

All that parcel of land situate in the Concessions Indian Reserve No.73, in the province of Saskatchewan, Dominion of Canada, containing by admeasurement three hundred and twenty-three acres, be the same more or less, being part of said reserve, described as follows:

Commencing at the North-east corner of Indian Reserve No.72 A or the North-east corner of the South-east quarter of section 5, Township 19, Range 5, West of the second Meridian, thence South along the East boundary of said Indian Reserve No.72 A and said East boundary produced South forty-seven chains and fifty links to the South limit of the Qu'Appelle River, thence Easterly and Southerly along the South limit of said River to the Westerly limit of Weed Creek, thence following the Westerly limit of said Weed Creek in a general South-western direction to the North limit of the road to Crooked Lake surveyed in 1908 by the Government of said Province, thence South seventy-six degrees forty-five minutes west along the said North limit two chains and eighteen links, thence along said limit North thirty-seven degrees forty-eight minutes west thirteen chains thirty-five links, thence along said North limit and said North limit produced North forty-eight degrees fifty-four minutes west, fifty chains and forty-nine links to the South limit of Crooked Lake, thence following said South limit of Crooked Lake and said South limit of the Qu'Appelle River in a general Easterly direction to the place of beginning. As said parcel of land is shown on a plan of the Concessions' Boarding school land, dated Nov.18, 1909, as surveyed by J.K. McLean, D.M.S., and of record in the Department of Indian Affairs.

And excepting therefrom and thereout the surveyed road across said tract surrendered in 1902 as shown on said plan.

Sir,

Referring to communication addressed you on the 3rd of June, 1908, in connection with application for a portion of land on the Cowesses Reserve, in connection with the Cowesses Indian Boarding School, I have to say that a survey of the land in question has been made, showing that it contains 325 acres, and as payment has been made for 350 acres of land at this rate, there is an over-payment of $405, being for 27 acres at $15 an acre, which will be refunded upon request.

REGINA, SASK., October 31st

Dear Sir:

On December 14, 1902, you issued to Mr. Hegele a Patent for a portion of this reserve. The description in the Patent refers to the survey of the road made by the Provincial Government in the year 1903. In checking the Patent with the plan of the road, I find that the same does not correspond with the land mentioned in the patent, as the land mentioned in the patent over laps the roadway.

I enclose herewith blue print copy of the roadway as affects the land mentioned in patent, and by referring to the same you will see that the two descriptions do not correspond.

Kindly let me hear from you as to what steps you are prepared to take, so as to make the corrections.

Apparently the plan of this land was made by one J. K. McLean, D. L. O., but we have not the copy thereof, in this office.

I have today seen the surveyor who surveyed the Government road and he informs me that while most of his field work was done in 1903, the plan was not completed until 1905, and some slight alterations were made in this.

No doubt this will account for the variations between the plan and the Patent.

I will be obliged if you will let me hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-9, part 1)

Ottawa, November 17, 1913.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st ultimo inclosing blue print and mentioning that the land covered by patent issued by this Department in December 1909, conveying to the Les Rev. Peres Oblates, a portion of the Cowessess Indian Reserve, overlaps the Provincial Government road; and stating that the discrepancy in the description might arise from the fact that although this road was surveyed in 1908, the plan was prepared in 1909, and some slight alterations were made on it.

The bearings and chainages of the north limit of this road, as returned by our surveyor, are not identical with those shown on the road plan, but the description expressly states the boundary in question to be along the north limit (and the north limit produced to the south limit of Crooked Lake) of the road to Crooked Lake surveyed in 1908 by the Provincial Government; on this account and from the fact that the monuments on the ground govern the survey, the description cannot be construed to include any part of said road.

Enclosed please find blue print of the plan referred to in the patent.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Registrar,
Lands Titles Office,
Regina.
