May 12th, 1915.

Minutes of a meeting of Cowessess Band held pursuant to notice for the purpose of considering an application made by the Reverend J. B. Beys, O.M.I., Principal of Cowessess Boarding School, in which the school authorities wish to erect a pasture on Cowessess Reserve.

The meeting opened at 2 o'clock P.M., there being present E. Taylor, Indian Agent; A. Boyer, clerk; H. Cameron, Interpreter; Joe Lerat, chief; Norbert Delorme and Pierre Lerat, headmen; and 19 voting Indians.

The agent informed the Indians that the Principal of the school desired to be given permission to build a fence on their reserve, size about one mile by about one and a half miles, for the purpose of pasturing during the summer season the cattle belonging to the school. The land which the Principal desired to enclose by the fence was of such a nature that it would not by allowing it to be enclosed affect the Indians of the Band in their agricultural or other industries, and as the school had no land of its own which could be utilized for a pasture and at the same time have sufficient land for grain growing or other purposes the agent thought that the Indians especially if they took into consideration which they should do the benefits derived from the school would after due consideration give their consent to the proposed fence being built. He, however, told them that after he had explained as nearly as was possible at the present moment the boundaries of the proposed fence and what remuneration the Band would derive from such a source that he would leave it to them for their consideration and if they were agreeable for the fence to be built he would afterwards
afterwards submit the whole matter to the Department, and that
the Department would after due consideration and in the best
interests of the Band give a decision on the matter and instruct
him accordingly.

The agent then outlined, as nearly as was possible,
the boundaries of the fence and also described the land which
would be enclosed. From such description it appeared that quite
a lot of timber, both green and dead poplar, would be enclosed,
but the school authorities agreed to provide gates wherever
necessary that the Indians in order to have access to the timber
would not be placed at any disadvantage to what belonged to them.
As regards remuneration to the Band the agent told the Indians
that the school was agreeable to pay $1.00 per head annually for
all stock over one year old pastured in the proposed enclosure.

The school authorities would erect the fence them-
selves, and provide all the materials necessary. The proposed
fence would not cross any government road allowances, and at
any road commonly used by the Indians which the fence did cross
gates would be provided.

The school authorities wished to reach an agree-
ment for the fence if built to remain and be used by the school
for at least ten years, but in this regard the agent said he
was not in a position to say whether the Department would grant
a lease for that length of time or not although if the school
went to the expense and trouble of building the fence it should
be distinctly on the understanding that the fence and land en-
closed thereby would be available to the school for stock graz-
ing purposes for many years. The Department however would lay
down a ruling in this regard and before the matter was finally
settled the Indians would be consulted further.

Joe Lerat, chief, then said that the Indians had
discussed the application of the school among themselves, and
that he thought they were all in favour of granting the school
school the privilege of building the pasture provided it was built where the agent and Principal stated. They would want the school to provide gates wherever the fence crossed commonly used roads. With reference to payment for the privilege of stock grazing in the pasture he said the Indians thought the school should pay one dollar ($1.00) per head for all stock whether under or over one year old. After discussing the matter among themselves he said they considered the school should pay one dollar ($1.00) per head for stock over one year old and fifty cents (50¢) per head for all animals under that age. As regards all other matters in connection with the fence the Indians knew that the Department would not make an agreement with anyone concerning themselves or their belongings which would be to their disadvantage and that the matter would now be left with the agent for him to report thereon and they would await the Department's answer. All of the Indians present, namely, Joe Lerat, Pierre Lerat, Norbert Delorme, Zac Lerat, Francis Delorme, Paul Peltier, Joe Peltier, Agecoutay, St. Pierre Aisaican, Francoise Jos. Delorme, Michael Le Vallee, William Aisaican, J.J. Stevenson, Stanislas Young, Emanuel Lerat, Patrick Redwood, William Trottier, Napoleon Sparvier and J. B. Sparvier voted in favour of allowing the school to build the pasture on the reserve.

Certified correct,

(Sgd) E. Taylor,
Indian Agent.
Indian Agent's Office,
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
May 15th, 1915.

In your reply refer to No. 27.

Also To date of this letter.

Sir,-

I beg to inform the Department of an application which has been made by the Reverend Principal, J. B. Beys, O.M.I., of Cowessess Boarding School for permission to erect a fence on Cowessess Indian Reserve for the purpose of pasturing the cattle which are raised and kept in connection with the school.

Hitherto such stock have partly grazed on land belonging to the school and partly on reserve land, but now the Principal desires in the best interests of the industry which is carried on in connection with the boarding school to erect an enclosure which would keep the school's cattle all together during the seasons of the year when the stock are not stabled. Practically all of the land owned by the school has been placed under cultivation so that no private land of an area large enough for pasturage is available, consequently conditions are such that a pasturage on the reserve is necessary.

A majority of the voting Indians of Cowessess Band attended a meeting at the office on the 12th instant. This meeting was specially called to discuss the question, and all present voted for the school to be allowed the privilege of erecting a fence and using the land which would be enclosed thereby as a pasturage for the stock which is kept by the school.

The land which it is proposed to fence, area about one mile by about one and a half miles, is not suitable.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-9, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
suitable for cultivation and taken as a whole it is not choice grazing land, but it is the only available land which could be used conveniently by the school for such a purpose, and moreover the Indians will not be placed at any disadvantage by the land being used in the manner desired.

The school if given permission to build the fence would purchase all the materials necessary and erect same at its own expense, and in payment for the privilege of using the area enclosed as a pasture is agreeable to pay annually to the Band's fund one dollar ($1.00) per head for cattle over one year old and fifty cents (50¢) per head for all animals under that age. The school would provide gates wherever the fence crossed commonly used roads, but no government road allowance would be crossed at all.

The Principal wishes an agreement to be reached whereby the pasturage so made could remain and be used by the school for a period of at least ten (10) years, but in this regard I informed both the Principal and the Indians that I could not say whether the Department would be agreeable to lease the land on the reserves or not, although if the school were given permission to build the fence it should be on the understanding that the land should be available to the school for stock grazing purposes for many years.

I am enclosing herewith copy of the minutes of the meeting had with the Indians, and I shall be glad to have the Department's advice or instructions at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

(Signed) E. Taylor,
Indian Agent.
Indian Agent's Office,
Crooked Lake Agency,

Ottawa, 23rd June, 1915.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith for your report thereon a copy of a letter from Mr. Agent Taylor, of the Crooked Lake Agency, covering minutes of a meeting held by Cowessess Band, relative to granting the application of the Principal of Cowessess Boarding School for a pasture field on the reserve in connection with the school.

From representations made the Department would have no objection to granting this privilege, but as you are aware could not issue a lease. A permit might be given the school to occupy the land as long as it is used for school purposes, or at least ten years.

A description of the land required should be given and a sketch forwarded showing the locality.

The terms offered by the principal appear to be reasonable.

Kindly attend to this matter as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Balcarres, Sask.

CANADA
Office of The Inspector of Indian Agencies,
South Saskatchewan Inspectorate,

Balcarres, Sask., Aug. 10th, 1915

Ref.: Your Letter of 23rd June 1915, No. 74864-5

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter above quoted and subsequent correspondence on the subject of granting a permit to the Principal of the Cowessess Boarding school to fence and pasture cattle on one and a half sections of land on Cowessess Reserve, the proceeds of the fund to be credited to the Band.

I have gone into the question and find that the land is described as follows:— East half of Sect. 31 and all of Section 32 in Township 10, Range 5 W and N. In all about 1000 acres. This land is mostly situated on the hillsides of the Qu'Appelle valley.

I note that the Principal is prepared to pay $1.00 for cattle over 1 year old and 50¢ for cattle under that age. While this might seem reasonable, I fear it might cause a good deal of dissatisfaction on the part of the Indians, for they are not unanimous for a permit, and there will be no way of exactly checking up the number of cattle that are pasturing as they will be put in and taken out at all times. In view of this I would recommend that a fixed amount be charged and in my opinion, this amount should be $100.00 per year.

I have the honour to be,

The Secretary,

Sir,

Dept. of Indian Affairs, Your obedient servant,

Ottawa.

[Signature]

December 13th, 1924.

Re: Crooked Lake Mission Property.

The Les Reverends Peres Oblats hold this property under a Grant from the Department dated December 14th, 1909 and are now I understand wishing to surrender a part thereof.

In checking up the grant of this land I find that reference is made therein to a survey of a road made by the Government of Saskatchewan in 1908, but the bearings and distances contained in the Grant do not correspond exactly with the only plan of this road on file in this office.

The Grant also refers to a plan of survey made by J. K. McLean of this property but there is no copy thereof in this office, nor does there appear to be a copy of the roadway surrendered in 1902.

I would be glad if you would let me have a copy of
the McLean Plan and either a copy of the Plan of 1902 or a metes and bounds description of the land contained therein.

Your obedient servant,

Registrar.

The Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

CVT/NT:
Ottawa, 3rd January 1925

Sir,

As requested in your letter of the 13th ultimo, I am enclosing a blueprint made from a tracing of the plan of survey by J.K. McLean, D.L.S., in 1908 of the Cowesses boarding school lands.

With reference to the explanation contained in the description of the Grant issued for this property, I have to say that the tract surrendered in 1902 was not definitely described in the surrender at that time but was referred to only as to general location and the surrender stated that the survey was to be made at a later date. The survey which would cover description in the surrender is that made by A.C. Garner in 1908 and is shown on his plan of survey of new road through Cowesses Indian reserve No.75, dated 29th April 1910. A copy of this plan, which was forwarded here by the Province and recorded under No.Rd.1035, shows the following reference Nos.-File 2375 - S R B 2790.

The road referred to in the description in 1908 by the Government of the Province of Saskatchewan is that shown on plan of survey of new road through Oakman and Cowesses reserves Nos.73 and 74 by A.C. Garner 1908-09, dated 16th March 1911, recorded in the Survey's Branch of this Department under No.Rd.1054. This plan was forwarded by the Deputy Minister of Public Works under cover of his file No.3562 and the plan is referred to as being Provincial No.2755. This plan also shows Provincial reference Numbers as follows,- S R B 3011 - Field Book 342.

It is hoped this will give you the information you require.

The Registrar,
Land Titles Office,
Wascana, Sask.

Your obedient servant,

(J.D. McLean)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
MOOSOMIN, SASK.

January 13th, 1925.

Sir:

Ref. Your file 108-2-9 Cowessess Boarding School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant together with blue print enclosed and thank you for the information contained therein which has assisted materially in clearing up the difficulty in this situation.

The Plan recorded by you as number 1033 is registered in this office as AP-1235 and Plan 1054 is registered here as AP-2688.

There is one difficulty remaining in this matter however. In the description given in the Letters Patent and on J.K. McLean's plan the boundary of this property from the West Bank of Weed Creek to the South shore of Crooked Lake is given as follows:-

"Thence South Seventy Six degrees forty five minutes West along the said North Limit two chains and eighteen links thence along said limit north thirty seven degrees forty eight minutes West Thirteen Chains Thirty-Five Links thence along said North Limit and said north limit produced North forty-eight degrees..."
fifty-four minutes West fifty chains and forty-nine links to the south limit of Crooked Lake."

Plan AP-2688 shows the first bearing as being N77.00 E, the second bearing as being S 37.29 E, the third bearing as being S 48.29 E. The distance from R 77 to R 78 is also shown as 13.34 chains.

I have submitted this matter to the Chief Surveyor at Regina who was the surveyor who originally surveyed this road and he states that Plan AP-2688 correctly shows the road as surveyed by him.

I would be glad if you would check the copy of this plan which you have and see if the same corresponds with the McLean Plan.

As far as this office is concerned however, I am prepared to waive the difference and to describe the land as bounded on the South by the roadway according to Plan AP-2688, but as I understand that this portion of the land is to be retransferred to your Department, it is best that the difficulty be cleared.

Ottawa, 20th January 1925

Sir,

I note in your letter of the 13th instant that you understand that a portion of the Cowessess boarding school property now held by Les Reverends Peres Colates is to be re-transferred by them to this Department and I have to inform you that while this matter has been under discussion and consideration, final arrangements have not been made in connection therewith. Should, however, a transaction of this nature be completed, I would suggest that it might be better for the whole property as transferred to the Oblate Order to be re-transferred to this Department and this Department would then issue a new title with correct description of the portion to be retained by the Order. If it should be decided that the whole property would be taken over by this Department rather than a part, it would appear that the transfer could be properly made by using a description identical with that used in the grant issued to the Order.

There is no doubt that it was the intention of the Department that the North limit of the road to Crooked Lake, surveyed in 1908 by the Province of Saskatchewan, and a portion of that road produced to Crooked Lake should be the southerly boundary of that portion of the property between the east bank of Wood Creek and the South shore of Crooked Lake.

I shall be pleased to receive an expression of your opinion as to the procedure above outlined.

Your obedient servant,

The Registrar,
Land Titles Office,
Moosomin, Sask.

(J.D. McLean)
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

With reference to the formal offer of the Cowessess Indian Residential School property made in Father Guy's letter of December 15th, last, I wish to make the following observations. In connection with page 2 of his letter, under the heading "Actual value of the property (church authorities' valuation)" I wish to point out that under "Lands", 206 acres was purchased in 1908 from the Indian reserve at $15 per acre. The 295.7 acre parcel was secured evidently in the open market. This parcel is across the Qu'Appelle river, approximately a mile from the school.

As far as buildings are concerned, the main building was completed in 1917. The Department provided a total of $1344 capital expense (fiscal years 1907-10). With reference to chattels, (page 3, Father Guy's letter and Exhibit F.) farm implements $4,890 appears satisfactory. Under Shop Equipment, whiffletrees, irons, clevises, chains, oils, bolts, screws, nails, iron, solder, stove bolts and stove pipes, a total of $292 should be subtracted from $1461, leaving $1169. The live stock inventory is satisfactory, but from the dairy, laundry and bakery shops should be deducted the refrigerator, which was built by the Department, flour, soap and lye, leather, tacks and thread, a total of $1690, leaving a balance of $691. In connection with furniture, the desks, clocks, 12 sewing machines and kitchen outfit were supplied by the Department, and the trunks could not be allowed - a total deduction of $605, leaving $2967.70. The whole clothing item of $9442.70 should be struck out, as also should the chapel equipment of $924.

I note that the bake oven, $266.14, and laundry machinery, $916, supplied by the Department, 1924-25, are not included in the inventory.

To recapitulate, the church valuation of the property that we should acquire is as follows:

| Lands | $14,661 |
|-------|---------|
| Buildings | $55,756.** |
| Chattels | $15,069.** |
| Total: | $85,486 |

**Department expense deducted.

The church is asking that the purchase price be

| Lands | $10,000. |
|-------|---------|
| Buildings | $50,000. |
| Chattels | $10,000. |
| Total: | $70,000. |

Dear Sir:

A considerable amount of correspondence has passed between this office and the office of the late Indian Commissioner, regarding a road along the valley, which road is, at the present time, running along the field which is farmed by the Cowessess Residential School and is the property of the Department. From all the information I am able to obtain on the subject, the Catholic Church, which formerly owned this land before it was sold to the Government, had allowed the road to be changed and had ploughed up some of the mounds which marked the road; consequently, when the land was taken over by the Government, this fact was overlooked and the matter continued until about 15 months ago, when the Canadian Pacific Railways, and Mr. E. Kendrick, owners of adjoining lands, complained and asked that the road be completed in the proper place.

The survey is spoiled and it is impossible to complete the road, either on the proper site or the new site until it is re-surveyed. The present location of the road, although not in the proper place, is quite as good as the approximate location of the survey which was destroyed. The site of the original survey takes the road through the school field, from end to end, cutting the field in two long narrow strips and spoiling the field considerably. In conversation with the Secretary-Treasurer of the Municipality, yesterday, he informed me that the Municipal Council were in favour of the survey being changed, but that the Department will have to stand the cost of the new survey and part of the cost of the work on the new road, before the Municipality will consent to the change in the road.

I beg to enquire whether it would be possible to have this road surveyed this year. I have been thinking that possibly the Department Surveyor will be coming west this year and could stop here and run the line without much expense. If possible, I think this should be done, as there is a possibility that the Municipality will proceed with the work on the original survey and the school crop will certainly be damaged, and the field spoiled for the future.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Complaints have been made to this Department extending over a period of two or three years, with regard to the roadway as now travelled through the south-half of section 3, township 19a, range 5, west of the 2nd meridian.

In 1900 this Department surveyed the old Valley Trail through this and adjoining lands. The plan is registered and we hold title. It appears that subsequent to this the Oblate Fathers acquired the S.W.¼ of 3, and that they pushed the trail back towards the hills until it is in such a location at present that it is neither a good road in winter nor summer, and the settlers complain that they cannot haul their loads over it. Our information is to the effect that the trail has been moved back more than one hundred yards.

The Municipality of Grayson, No.184, I understand, concluded an agreement last year with the then Indian Commissioner, and with Father Carriere, but just what the nature of the agreement was we do not know. I understand however that your Department has not carried out the agreement.

We have been requested to take action in the matter and if we do so, we will have no other alternative but to make a retracement survey of the trail as originally surveyed, and advise the municipality that this is the location upon which ...........

Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs.,
Ottawa., Ontario.
which roadwork must be done. This action would place the road a considerable distance out into your cultivated field and no doubt would be a considerable loss to your Department. I believe that a compromise might be reached between your Department and the Municipality acting for the settlers, whereby a road could be satisfactorily located somewhere in between the surveyed location of the trail and the road that is now used, and this location would not damage your field to anything like the same extent.

This Department therefore does not desire to take action, as we feel that the best arrangement would be for a compromise between the original location and the present travelled road.

As this matter has been hanging fire for several years, I would suggest that you endeavor to reach an agreement with the municipality as soon as possible in order that this vexed question might be settled without further delay.

Your obedient servant,

H.S. Carpenter,
Deputy Minister of Highways.

Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir:

Referring to your letter 108-2-9 in connection with the surveyed road through the field being used by the Cowessess Residential School I beg to inform you that I went over this road very carefully yesterday in company with the Reverend Fr. Carriere and a half breed who knew the location of the destroyed mounds.

I am enclosing herewith blue print showing road as surveyed in 1902. The approximate location of the road now being used and the approximate location of the proposed slight change. I have no doubt that this slight change will meet with the approval of the Municipality and the Canadian Pacific Railway if this Company are paid a small indemnity for land which they will have lost by the change.

I may say that the road as now used encroaches considerably upon lands owned by the C.P.R. and Fr. Carriere informs me that he could purchase the land which this encroachment affects for $200.00 and it would be worth that much for pasturage.

I am aware of course that the Department has no funds provided for the purchase of lands but I believe Fr. Carriere would be glad to purchase this land with school funds in the name of H.M. the King if it meets with the approval of the Department.

In any case a survey is necessary as the Municipality and the Department of Highways insist upon it failing which they insist on taking the old survey which would certainly seriously damage the field now being used by the School as it practically cuts it into two narrow fields from end to end.

All parties concerned are satisfied to make this proposed change if the Department will stand the cost of the survey but they are all insisting upon the survey being completed without further delay.

Kindly instruct me further in this connection and return the Blue Print when it has served its purposes.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

Re: Proposed survey of new road through section 3, township 19a,
range 5, west 2nd meridian.

With reference to my interview this morning with the Director of Surveys on the above matter, I am willing to perform the necessary field work and provide final plans of the survey for registration for an inclusive fee of One Hundred and Seventy Five Dollars ($175.00).

I would further agree that if, after the completion of the work, I found that this sum was in excess of the cost under "Day Rates" I would accept "Day rates".

J.P. Ostrander Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
Based on the information you obtain as to the cost of the land, apart from the cost of construction, if insisted upon by the Municipality and the fact that the survey will cost in the neighbourhood of $200.00, you are requested to report whether you consider the inconvenience of having the Municipality establish the road through the school property in the position in which it now officially exists is sufficient to justify the amount of expenditure that would be involved if we proceeded with the suggested change.

It must be realized that if the road is constructed on the old location, the Department will not be put to any expenditure and the total cost will be borne by the Municipality and, as has been suggested, the road would not be in a satisfactory position. In view of this, the Department is inclined to be of the opinion that the Municipality may not be anxious to construct the road as now officially surveyed and it is suggested that if this phase of the matter were presented to the municipal officials, they may see that they are unreasonable in requesting the Department to share part of the cost of the road in a new position.

Your obedient servant,

Secy. Treas.

As mentioned in previous correspondence the road now being used encroaches upon Fr.S# 3-19A-R5 W 2nd. I am unable to state the acreage involved which can only be determined by a survey. It would appear to me that either the Church or School funds should bear the cost of the settlement with the C.F.R. on this encroachment. In view of the fact that much of this land was purchased by the Department from the Church Authorities the matter was left unsettled and the misunderstanding came about in the first instance through the Church Authorities permitting their teams whilst working on the land to destroy the old survey.

Subsequently the road was moved back to its present location adding a narrow strip of land within the school fence and cutting off a like amount from the C.F.R. lands.

I am returning herewith Blue Print which will assist in the explanation of this.

Referring to the 5th paragraph of your letter 108-2-9 of the 31st October last I beg to say that if the Municipality were to establish the road on the original survey it would be a great inconvenience to the school and I do not think that the land under discussion is priced very high by the C.F.R. and I would strongly recommend that some arrangement be made for the purchase of this land if at all possible.

I also understand that if the matter were pressed by the Municipality the Church Authorities could be held accountable for the destruction of the original survey and I think that the matter would be more easily settled if the Church Authorities would pay for the encroachment and the Department would pay for the survey.

Your obedient servant,

J.E.S. Gatrander
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, 30th April 1934

Sir,

It has been ascertained that the road in use through the S.W. Sec.3-19A-5-W.2.M., is slightly to the North East of the actual position of the official surveyed road. The Rural Municipality of Grayson and the Principal of the Couesee Indian Residential School are desirous of having the road established in the position of the one in present use. To effect this it was the intention of the Department to donate the necessary land required in the S.W. Sec.3, which is part of the school property and I should like to be advised of the price per acre which your Company would demand for the land which would be required for the diversion through the S.E. Sec.3. The acreage required for the road right of way would be in the neighbourhood of four acres.

I am enclosing a blueprint, on which is indicated the position of the official surveyed road and the approximate position of the new location.

Your obedient servant,

(A.F. MacKenzie)

Dear Sir:

Re: Your file 108-2-9

In reply to your letter of April 30th in connection with new road diversion in the S.E.t 3-19a-5 W.2nd. According to my records the land lying between the road as it is actually located and the original surveyed location, has been used by the school.

In view of this, I am of the opinion that your Department should purchase this area, in addition to that required by the actual roadway, and I am prepared to sell this land at the price of $100.00, which I think is very reasonable owing to the fact that the Department of Highways pays us $20.00 per acre for all roads and cut-off areas.

When survey of the new location has been made, I shall be glad if you will have copy of plan forwarded to me, so that the exact acreage of the land in question can be determined, and arrangements for payment made accordingly.

Yours truly,

O. Kirkwold,
Superintendent of Sales.

Sir,

Ottawa, 21st July 1934

Memorandum

Schools Branch,

Please note my memoranda on file hereunder dated 10th Aug. 1932, 19th Sept. 1933 and 31st Oct. 1933. It appears to me from the correspondence that it would be a decided disadvantage to the school property to have the road through this property opened in the location of the official surveyed road and that it would be a decided advantage to secure the proposed revision.

I have ascertained that the Department could secure the land which it would be necessary to acquire from the Canadian Pacific Railway for the price of $100.00. The area to be purchased would be approximately 6½ acres, which the Agent values at $10.00 per acre, or a total of $65.00. The C.P.R. might possibly reduce their price to this latter figure. The cost of survey would be $175.00 and I think this Branch could arrange to defray the survey expenses from the present allotment, if your Branch is prepared to complete the purchase of the necessary land from the Canadian Pacific Rwy.

It should be realized that, if the Municipality insists, the provincial Department of Highways could demand the establishment of the road in the location as at present surveyed.

Chief Surveyor.
Ottawa, 25th July 1934

Sir,

Acknowledging receipt of your letter No.108-2-10 of the 10th ultimo, I beg to advise that the parents of this boy have again been to the office with a view to obtaining his transfer from the Crooked Lake to the Round Lake School. Mrs. McQuaid claims that at the time she took the boy to the Cowessess School she had previously been to the Round Lake School where Mr. Ross had informed her that he had no room. Having neither sufficient food or clothing at home and being under the impression that all Department schools were the same she proceeded to the Cowessess school where the Rev. Principal had the room and took the children in. Since that date the girl then admitted has been discharged owing to physical disabilities, the boy however was taken back to the school and while there was not well when the parents took him away and took him into Dr. Craig's Broadview, where he later developed pneumonia. In view of the parents actions with regard to taking the boy from the school in the first place the Rev. Principal kept the boy at school during the Xmas holidays.

This of course has again aroused the parents and they feel determined to go everything in having the boy admitted to the Round Lake School, both claiming that they know nothing of the Catholic faith have during their later years always attended the protestant church, both went to the Round Lake School, in fact Mrs. McQuaid was there during the greater part of her life and admitting that she made a mistake in taking the boy to Cowessess school as she did, she feels that cognizance should be given to her wish that she wants the children raised in the Protestant faith as she knows nothing of the Catholic faith. All of the foregoing is concurred in by her husband who was absent at the time the children were taken to Cowessess school and admitted. As it stands at present the parents did not have their boy home at the Xmas holidays and the father states that he was prevented from seeing the boy when
he recently visited the school.

In this connection I might add that I intercepted these people en route to Regina where they had intended taking this matter up through other sources, feeling that their former requests had not been favourably considered.

Am again referring their case for the Department's consideration as they both appear very sincere and determined to have the boy transferred to the Round Lake School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Eben A. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to Arthur Meduahquay, and we have also received your letter of the 9th instant enclosing Dr. Craig's report, which shows that this boy is now in good health.

After carefully considering your letters, it is considered advisable that this boy should remain in the Cowessess Indian Residential School at least until June 30th. If, in the meantime, the parents again urge his discharge, you should bring the matter to the Department's attention and favourable consideration will be given to allowing him to go home at the end of June.

Ottawa, March 5, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, regarding the request of W. J. Redwood, an Indian of the Cowessess Band, to have his twin daughters, Elsie and Alexine, admitted to the Cowessess Indian Residential School. It is noted that these girls are five years and eight months of age.

At the present time, the Cowessess School is allowed per capita grant for 65 pupils, while the last return received shows that there were 93 children in residence. If these girls were admitted the Department would not be prepared to allow supernumerary grant for them. Until there would be vacancies among the present pupils, the Department would not be prepared to favourably consider the admission of the two Redwood girls. We understand that the pupils at present in residence are all the dormitories can accommodate, allowing ample air space for each pupil.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
March 9th 1937

Re Peter Northwood, age 14 yrs., candidate for admission to Convent Indian Residential School, Crooked Lake D.R.

This boy is deformed badly and was taken (pending admission) by Father Chateaum into the School. He was badly neglected at home when he was five years ago. He was taken to the Hospital in Regina for three months. From there he was taken to the Sanatorium at Fort Qu'Appelle where he was treated for six years. He was discharged at the age of twelve, spent one month at Bible Hill Hosp. and came home to the Crooked Lake D.R.

He is bright mentally. I would urge that he be admitted to the Convent School. Father Chateaum is anxious to do all that is possible for him and he will get proper care.

Geo H. Craig M.D.,
Medical Officer,
Crooked Lake D.R.
Crooked Lake Agency
Broadview Sask.

Ottawa, March 16th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing application for the admission of Peter Northwind, an Indian boy of the Sakimay Band, to the Cowessess Indian Residential School. The report which you forwarded from Dr. Craig regarding his case is also received.

Owing to the medical history of this boy, the Department is in doubt if he would be a fit pupil to be admitted to a residential school. It is considered that he might prove a menace to the health of the other pupils. The Department considers that this boy should be examined by Dr. A. B. Simes, Medical Superintendent of the Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit, Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask., who should report regarding his present condition of health and also state if he would recommend that the boy be admitted to a residential school.

When we have Dr. Simes' report, consideration will then be given as to whether approval can be granted for his admission to the Cowessess Residential School or not.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,

Ottawa, March 22, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, returning the applications for the admission of Elsea and Marie Rose Redwood to the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that, in view of your explanation that there is accommodation for these two girls and they would not be in excess of the number for which grant is allowed, the Department will approve of their admission. However, as they are under the age limit, their admission is not to form a precedent.

I have also your letter of the same date requesting the discharge of pupil No. 0116, Mary Jane Aissiccan, who has reached the age limit. The discharge of this girl is approved.

Please advise the Principal of the admission of the two Redwood girls and the discharge of pupil No. 0116.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Cowessess Indian Residential School,
Marieval, Via Grayson, Sask.,
March 15th, 1937.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:-

Two weeks ago William Redwood, father of the above children, asked me to accept his children in school, giving reasons; wife sick, children in a serious need of food. I went to his home a few days after to take the children to the school; fifteen miles, bad roads. The children had nothing to wear; so I bought them shoes, overcoats, dresses etc. Last Friday I sent to the Indian Office the forms for admission duly signed by the Doctor, Mr. A. McKenzie, the Indian Agent, wrote me the following letter.

"I am in receipt of your letter with admission forms re the Redwood Twins and have to advise you that I have taken this matter up with Ottawa and they advice that your per capita grant is for 85 pupils and at the last return there were 93 on your roll.

They state that as your dormitories are full with all they can accommodate allowing sufficient air space for all pupils and inasmuch as these twins are only 5 yrs and 8 months old they will not sanction their admission at present."

Now, Sir, if you had taken a look on the roll, you would have notice that there were 6 children discharged and 4 were transferred to other schools during January.

Before returning the twins to their home, I am waiting an answer from you and I do hope that you will sanction their admission.

I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly,

P. Chatelain, O.M.I.
Principal.
Ottawa, March 23rd, 1937.

Yours truly,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.,
April 14th, 1937.

Dear Mr. McKenzie:

Re: Peter Keawayden or Northwind.

I regret the delay in replying to your letter of March 22nd, re- above named Indian boy. Unfortunately your letter was misplaced.

While I have not had an opportunity to examine this boy I beg to submit the following report in case the Department is waiting for this information before deciding whether or not he will be admitted to School.

From the information obtained from his files and my recollection of the case both legs are completely paralyzed and one deformed due to ankylosis of the knee. His only method of moving about was to slide along the floor on his buttocks unless carried by someone.

It is impossible to say that he would be a menace, from a health standpoint to the other pupils until he was examined, but even if his examination revealed no evidence of activity I would not recommend his admission to any School as I consider he would be a great mental menace on account of his physical defects.

While I do not consider the following is within the Medical jurisdiction, but as you have asked in your letter for my observations I will attempt to give them. Possibly I have wrong conception of the case, but this boy is fifteen years of age. He cannot ever hope to make any practical use of an education and at the most he has only one year to attend School for by then he will have reached the School age limit. He received some schooling while in the Sanatorium, how much I am not quite certain.

Mention was also made in your letter that he has been considerably neglected at home. From what information I have been able to obtain his parents are not old, decrepit or ruined, but enjoy good health and are well able to properly care for their invalid child. Previously to his discharge from the Sanatorium his parents interviewed Inspector W. Murison and wished their child home.
The Department released them of the worry of caring for the child as well as trying to restore him to health for almost six years at a cost of about $2000.00. Unfortunately the results obtained were not those anticipated.

If the parents are neglecting their duty I have not a doubt that the Department would back you up whole-heartedly in any proper action you may take to remedy this serious condition.

I will be pleased to examine Peter any time arrangements can be made to have him brought to Fort Qu'Appelle. As it is now going on four years since his discharge I think he should be examined as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

A.B. Sines, M.D.
Medical Superintendent,
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

Mr. E. A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent,
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broedview, Sask.

ABS:EL
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
March 22nd, 1937.

Dr. A.B. Simes,
Fort Qu'Appelle.

Dear Doctor:

Re: Peter Keewayden or Northwind

You will remember the above named lad was in
the File Hills Hospital for several years.

Since he came back he has been considerably
neglected at home and the Rev. Father of the Cowessess
School figured that they would look after him at their school
which would be much better for him than at home.

He appears to be mentally O.K. but physically
poor.

An application for his admission has been submitted
to Ottawa but before accepting the same they state as follows:
"The Department considers that this boy should be examined by
Dr. Simes who should report regarding his present condition
of health and also state whether he would recommend that the
boy be admitted to a residential school. Would he be a menace
to the health of the other pupils of the school."

You know the history of the case well and it is not
very convenient to get him over to you for an exam at this time
of the year and I was wondering whether you would be able to
give a report that would satisfy Ottawa on the matter.

I shall be pleased to have your observations.

Yours very truly,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.
Fort Qu'Appelle, Sask.,
April 14th, 1937.

Dear Doctor Robertson:

Re: Peter Keeneyden or Northwind

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter received from Indian Agent Mr. R.A. W.R. McKenzie re a medical certificate to permit the above named boy to be admitted to Cowessess Indian Residential School also a copy of my reply for your information.

This boy was admitted to the Fort Qu'Appelle Sanatorium at four years of age with extensive tuberculosis of the lungs spine and right knee on March 2nd, 1937. He remained there until October 1st, 1937 when he was transferred to File Hills Colony Hospital. On December 15th of the same year he was sent home from File Hills.

For some time previous to his discharge from the Sanatorium the disease was arrested and all the sinuses healed. On account of the extensive involvement of the spine with the healing of the lesion paralysis of both legs resulted. His condition was further aggravated by an ankylosis of the right knee in an unsatisfactory position. It was realized for some time previous to his discharge that he could not be benefited by further hospitalization. His recuperation was not forthcoming and whether he could not after his at home. After making an inquiry I found there was absolutely no reason why his parents could not give him the necessary attention, as really the only important item was keeping him clean.

I judge from Mr. McKenzie's letter that the main reason for his admission to the school is neglect on his parents part in looking after him properly. I can hardly think that he hopes to render him self-supporting by providing him with an education. On the other hand I do not think that it is the policy of the educational officials of the Department to authorize school grants for such cases as his.

With a full time nurse, farm instructor an Indian Agent who no doubt visits the house frequently there should be no reason for this child not receiving the small amount of care he requires.

If it is found that the parents are neglecting him and after being properly warned would not the Department expect the Indian Agent to take steps to see that they received the proper punishment for such an offense.

Your obedient servant,

A.B. Smith, M.D.
Medical Superintendent,
Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit.

Dr. T. Robertson,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:-

Re: Application to have Peter Keewayden or Northwind admitted to Cowessess School.

I am in receipt of the enclosed correspondence on the above subject, which I also discussed with Doctor Simes on Sunday last.

We both feel that this boy should not be admitted to school. He cannot be made self-supporting by any education he will receive there.

It appears to us that the Department is being asked to assume this expense, not for the benefit of the boy but rather to relieve his parents, who are well able to look after him, or his care and incidentally our officials of the necessity of seeing that he is properly cared for.

I would therefore recommend that this application be not granted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 4th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your 304-11B of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the application that has been received for the admission of Peter Keewayden to the Cowessess Indian Residential School.

In view of the information contained in Dr. Simes' letter, the Department is not prepared to approve the boy's admission to the Cowessess School and you should so inform Indian Agent MacKenzie.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

To whom it may concern,

Kind Sir,

Victor Pelletier, Grade IV, admitted in 1830, is not fit to mingle any more with his fellow classmates, giving annoyance, setting trouble by his disobedience, not considering the sad consequences for the whole class.

For over a year, all means possible have been taken up with him, striving to bring him back to better feelings, but alas, with no satisfactory result. Therefore, his discharge would be a great blessing for the good of all.

Please consider the matter.

Yours very sincerely and respectfully,

Sister Saint Janvier,
Teacher.

Sept. 13th, 1937.

Mr. E.W.W.R. McKenzie,
Agent, Crooked Lake I.R.

Dear Sir:

This letter deals with a charge made to you by certain Indians of the Crooked Lake I.R. that the children of the Cowessess School were infected with vermin.

This charge has been made by disaffected Indians on several occasions in the past and it should be hardly necessary to say that the present complaint is utterly unfounded and maliciously false.

I spent a whole day (Sept. 10th) at the school. On this occasion I examined every child in the school for Trachoma and thus had ample opportunity to observe the truth or falsity of this serious accusation.

Many of the children on their return to school on Sept. 1st after the holidays were badly infested, some worse than others.

No pains were spared to clean them up. The boys' heads were closely clipped and the girls were given special treatment. This has always been the policy of the school, and when the cleaning and disinfection has been completed, the greatest vigilance is exercised to see that the pupils remain clean.

The dormitories are spotless and each child has his own bed. The food is plain & good. No child in this school has ever suffered from undernourishment.

To say that such a charge as this is amazing, is expressing the case lightly. It reflects on the management of the school and also on its medical supervision. Besides it is most discouraging to those who have the welfare of the school and the Indians at heart.

I append a list of those children who came back to school Sept. 1st infected with vermin. They were given prompt and energetic treatment.

I would suggest that if ever again such a charge is laid against the school that the complainant be given every opportunity to justify his charges, and if they are proven untrue and false that some steps be taken to see that those responsible for the accusation be made to retract and offer suitable apology.

"George H. Craig M.D."
M.O. for the School.
D. A. MACKENZIE LL.B.
BARRISTER, SOLICITOR
NOTARY PUBLIC

ESTERHAZY, SASKATCHEWAN
CANADA
September 16th, 1937.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re Crooked Lake Indian Reserve (Sask.)

Reverend Father Chatelain O.M.I., principal of the Indian Residential School at Marieville has been in to see me regarding some matters that have arisen at the school.

It appears that in the past it has been the custom to grant the children a holiday at Christmas time. Recently, Fr. Chatelain received a circular letter from your Department announcing that there would be no Christmas holiday hereafter and that the summer holiday would be extended. Although Fr. Chatelain caused this information to be made known to the parents of the children a number of them nevertheless sent their children back at the time that the fall term heretofore opened. He was obliged to send them home and some of the disaffected parents started a rumour about that the circular letter from your Department was not genuine. Then when school opened they made a complaint—to the Indian agent, I believe, that the school was infested with vermin and that the food was not good. As a result, I understand that the Indian Agent had the Medical Officer, Dr. Craig of Broadview make an investigation—at least, if that is not so, Dr. Craig after making an investigation delivered a report to the Agent. I am enclosing a copy of this report from which you will note that the charges were entirely unfounded, and were obviously propounded through dissatisfaction because of your Department's decision in regard to changing the school holiday.

Fr. Chatelain fears that unless the Department takes a firm stand in the matter that there is going to be more trouble when December comes as the parents will be wanting to take out the children. It would appear that, in order to avoid such a situation arising, you ought now to give very definite instructions to your agent to take adequate steps in the matter. I would be obliged, therefore, if you would, at once, write Fr. Chatelain assuring him that this will be done, and at the same time send me a copy of your letter.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-10, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Mr. Holy,

I thought you would like to answer this letter attached in reference to file in which circular letter re holidays was written.

PP
Ottawa, September 29, 1937.

Reverend Sir:

I have for acknowledgment a letter addressed to the Deputy Minister of the Department by D. A. MacKenzie, Esq., LL.B., Estevan, Sask., in which Mr. MacKenzie refers to certain problems that you discussed with him, in respect to the administration of the Cowessess Residential School.

You are probably aware that the summer holiday period at Indian residential schools throughout the Dominion was extended, in response to a number of requests that had reached the Department from the church authorities. The representatives of the churches assured us that, in their judgment, it would be easier and less expensive to have the pupils returned to school if the holiday period was extended and brought into conformity with the holiday period at Indian day schools and also at provincial public schools. There are a number of objections to the holiday period at Christmas. The Department has always hesitated to expose the pupils in attendance at residential schools to the epidemics that are usually prevalent at that season of the year. In addition to this, the expense involved in having pupils return home at Christmas is almost prohibitive, and a great many Principals have experienced the utmost difficulty in securing their return to school when the holiday period had expired. It was the hope of the departmental officials that the new regulations, requested and approved by the church authorities, would prove satisfactory to all concerned. I am very sorry indeed to learn that a certain amount of dissatisfaction exists at your school.

I am today communicating with the Indian Agent

Rev. P. Chatelain, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Cowessess Indian Residential School,
Marieval, via Grayson, Sask.
and asking him to cooperate with you in the solution of the problem insofar as it is humanly possible to solve it. If there is anything, other than this, that the Department can do to help you, I want you to feel perfectly free to communicate with us again.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Heey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, September 29, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter received by the Deputy Minister from Mr. D. A. MacKenzie, LL.B., Esterhazy, Sask. This letter, you will note, is self-explanatory. I am also enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter written today to the Principal of the Cowessess Residential School.

It is scarcely necessary to add that the Department is anxious that you should do everything within your power to cooperate with the Principal of the School in any attempts he may make to satisfy the Indian parents and pupils with respect to the holiday period for which provision is made in the new regulations. The thought has occurred to me that, if a meeting of the Indian parents could be held and the new regulations fully explained to them, this action in itself might go a long way to satisfy them. You may be interested to learn that this is the only letter received by the Department, suggesting that any dissatisfaction exists with respect to the new regulations at Indian residential schools.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Encl.

E.A.W.R. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
Ottawa, September 29, 1937.

Dear Mr. MacKensie:

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter sent forward under today's date to Reverend Father Chatelain, O.M.I., Principal of the Cowessess Indian Residential School. This letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Enclosure.

D. A. MacKensie, Esq., LL.B.,
Barrister & Solicitor,
Esterhazy, Sask.
Sir:—

The Reverend Principal of the Cowessess I.R. School writes as follows:

"I hereby make application for admission of Peter George Smoker (116 Kahkewistahaw Band) into our school.

The father, Robert Smoker, is Presbyterian while the mother is Catholic. The boy was baptised in the United Church of Canada against the will of the parents. Mr. Robert Smoker urges me to accept the child in our school. I told the parents I would refer the case to Ottawa.

Will you please be good enough to send my request and forward full explanatory note."

Signed P. Chatelain O.M.I.
Principal

I would be glad to receive the Department's instructions on the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Eben. A. W. R. McKenzie
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
October 5, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of September 20th, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of Peter George Smoker to the Cowessess Indian Residential School at the present time.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 29th ultimo enclosing a copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Cowessess I.R. School with regard to Indian complaints as to the regulations respecting holidays.

In this connection the Indians claim that these were always the regulations but the Department made special provision for them and granted Xmas holidays to both schools in this Agency and they are of the opinion that the exception that was made in their case still stands, as it has not been withdrawn.

Both Principals are not in favour of these being granted as the children return to school after this period with colds and epidemics such as Flu, Measles &c. follow, which are contracted during the festive season.

Is it the Department's wish that the former exception that was made for these two schools be withdrawn and the children of these schools remain at school during Xmas the same as at other residential schools?

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.H. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa Ont.
Ottawa, November 5, 1937.

Dear Sir:-

I am in receipt of your letter of October 24th with reference to complaints received from Indians regarding the recent regulations in connection with holidays at Indian residential schools.

As you were informed in official letter of September 29th last, the new regulations regarding holidays are now in effect at all Indian schools in Canada. As you know, these regulations permit longer summer holidays, but make no provision for holidays at Christmas and you should so inform the Indians of your agency.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Sir:—

St. Pierre Wapamoose No.228, Cowessess Band wants to go out and work off the Reserve and wishes to take his boy 8 years of age, at present attending Cowessess School, to attend a day school where he is working, for which he is prepared to pay the tuition himself.

Is there any objection to his doing so as long as the boy attends school regularly?

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R.McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 21, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the son of St. Pierre Wapamoose, No. 228, Cowessess Band.

If the father is prepared to maintain his son and send him regularly to a day school, the Department sees no serious objection and he may be discharged from the Cowessess Residential School for that purpose.

It is understood, of course, that you feel assured that the father will send the boy regularly to a day school. If there is any doubt about this, I believe it would be preferable to leave the boy in the Cowessess school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
Sir:

Re: Louis Wapamoose No.164
Cowessess I. R. School

With reference to your letter 108-2-10
of the 21st. of July last concerning son
of St. P. Wapamoose, I beg to advise that
I have received a letter from the Chairman
of the Perley School District at Saltcoats
stating that they will take the son of
St.P. Wapamoose in as a pupil and I there-
fore beg to make application for his dis-
charge from the Cowessess I. R. School.

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R.McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Sir:-

Ye Francis Lerat #139 Cowessess I.R.School

The above named pupil has caused considerable trouble amongst the other pupils and the Revd. Principal writes as follows:

"I hereby make application for the discharge of Francis Lerat aged 15 on 8-12-36. He is a bad boy, disobedient and is not fit to mingle any more with the other boys of the school for he incites them to do wrong.

In view of this fact I recommend that he be sent to a reformatory for an indefinite period."

This lad has incited the other pupils especially the younger ones to grumble about the food un-necessarily, cause general trouble, and has instigated recently five pupils to run away from the school which in this kind of weather is likely to have very unfortunate results similar to the case when a boy was frozen to death running away from Round Lake School some years ago.

He seems unmanageable and especially in view of the fact that his mother and father are dead and his oldest brother George about 22 years old is trying to maintain the household and young children left by his parents and to ensure them a fair living have had to issue rations for the family from the Agency it does not seem right that his brother should be forced to keep him when they themselves need what food supplies they have without encouraging another boy to get him through misbehaviour.

I feel that the Revd. Principal's suggestion as regards sending the boy to a reformatory for a while a good one as no doubt otherwise he will continue his lack of discipline and control at home and will spoil the chance of his ever making a man out of himself. Possibly the reformatory discipline will fill in just what is needed and would be well worth the trial if only for a year. This establishes a precedent that if all a lad has to do to get expelled from school is to become a general nuisance which would set a bad example for any other pupils.

I would be glad to have the Department's instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ben. A. W. R. McKenzie
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6304, file 651-10, part 2)
Ottawa,
November 26, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant with reference to Francis Lerat, No. 139, Cowessess Indian Residential School.

It is noted that the Reverend Principal and yourself consider that this boy should be placed in a reformatory. Please let me know if either the Principal or yourself are aware of any such institution in the Province of Saskatchewan in which the boy could be placed. If so, you should ascertain what it would cost for his maintenance and also what steps should be taken to have him placed in the institution.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Broadview, Sask.
Sir:

Reference your letter 108-2-10 of the 26th instant concerning Francis Lerat I have been talking over the situation with his uncle as he has no parents and this uncle thinks if he was given a chance at the Muscowequan I.R. School he would do much better.

I have therefore written to the Revd. Principal asking him if he could take him in and if he replies in the affirmative I will write requesting his transfer.

I do not think there is a reformatory school in this Province and probably this action will solve the difficulty.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Ben. A. V.R. McKenzie
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
December 3, 1938.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 29th ultimo the Department approves the transfer of Francis Lerat from the Cowessess to the Muscowequan Residential School provided you can arrange with the Principal of the latter school to accept him.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa,
January 28, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 20th instant regarding the request that you have received for the admission of two children of Robert Smoker to the Cowessess Indian residential school. In this regard I would refer you to Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act. The Department is not prepared to favourably consider the admission of these children at the present time. I also note that there are approximately 94 children in the school at the present time whereas grant is only allowed for 85. Under these circumstances you would have no accommodation for the Smoker children in any case.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. V. de Varennes, O.M.I.,

Sir:

Referring to your letter 108-2-10 of the 5th October, 1937, I have to advise that Robert Smoker has again asked that his boy Peter George Smoker be admitted to the Cowessess I.R. School.

The mother is blind and the father very nearly so and this boy should have been in school some time ago but he has assisted in taking care of his mother and leading her where necessary. Younger children can now take on this duty.

They live much nearer the Cowessess School than the Round Lake I.R. School and the mother has attended services at the Cowessess Mission.

I therefore beg to recommend that their application be granted.

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

However it should be distinctly understood that the boy should not be placed in that school until you receive definite instructions from us to that effect.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Commiss

0124 - Henrietta Harallee - 17
0127 - Evelina Deforme - 17
Ottawa,
February 21, 1940.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Cowessess Indian Residential School shows the following pupils over the age of 16:

No. 0124 Henrietta Lavallee
" 0127 Eveline Delorme

No application for retaining these children in your school has been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. V. de Varennes, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Cowessess Indian Residential School,
Marieval,
via Grayson, Sask.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupils mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Marieval, Sask.
March 1 1940

Mr. Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division
Mines & Resources Dept
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am thankful to you for your information and I must confess that I have not seen the Indian Act Section 10 (1) regarding the discharge of such children 16 years of age.

In consequence, I beg the favour of discharging the said children Henriette Lavalle who already left the school last month, and Eveline Delorme who may get married after Easter.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Rev. V. de Varennes
Principal

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Quarterly School Return of the Cowessess Indian Residential School, together with Requisition for School Material needed.

The discharge of Henriette Lavallee #0124 and Eveline Delorme, #0127 is requested and I would recommend this.

The Reverend Principal informs me that there are some 13 children at this Agency between the ages of 9 and 8 that are not now attending school and to accommodate some of these he has asked if certain of the older pupils could not be discharged before they reach the age of 16.

The pupils he suggest are as under:

0152 Mary-Alice Sanguis

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of April 5, 1940 in which I asked if certain of the older pupils of the Cowessess Indian Residential School could not be discharged before they reached the age of 16, and Departmental letter #108-2-10 of April 10 instructing me to inform the Principal that the discharge of the pupils he suggested had been approved.

I notified the Principal as instructed but he was under the impression that these pupils would not receive their discharge until the end of the present academic year and he informed me yesterday they are still in school.

As no new pupils were taken in I understand to replace these pupils, the Principal is asking if the grant could not be allowed for these pupils until the end of this month.

Your obedient servant,

G.A. Havre,
Clerk

FORM 411
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,
Oct. 9th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose Quarterly Returns of the Cowessess Indian Residential School for the quarter ending September 30th, 1940.

The Rev. Principal asks for permission to transfer pupil No.0163 Antoinette Lavallee to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School, Lebret, Sask. He also asks if the Department would consider the admission of May Marguerite Rainville, daughter of M.Rainville, Sakimay Band. The girl is an orphan, the mother died last November, and she has been kept at the school since that time. She was born June 20th, 1935.

Your obedient servant,

W.J.D.Kerley,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Application for new pupil Required

0199 May M. Rainville

Dear Sir:

The discharge of pupils 141, 020 and 0136 is approved.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Victoria Still, Pupil No. 0121, of the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Marieval, who died at Cowessess School (place) on Feb. 5, 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? Monday, 3rd.

2. At what time of day? 4 p.m.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? To Sister Saint Martha at 4 p.m.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Lemon tea, sulphur foot bath.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Tincture applied every hour.

6. When was the doctor called? Tuesday at 9 a.m.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport?

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? She was taken to the hospital at the school.

9. Add any other useful information here.

Rev. O. C. Maclean, M.M.
Principal.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED
THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Victoria Hall from Feb. 5th 1936
to Feb. 5th 1936. The immediate cause of death was
Basal meningitis.

The contributory cause of death was Influenza.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

This pupil was ill less than forty-eight hours. There was no cough and no sore throat. The child was in good health up to 4 pm Feb. 5th when she reported sick.

Geo H Craig M.D.
C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Victoria Sloc have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

Chairman—Indian Agent.
Crooked Lake Agency,
Broadview, Sask.,

I beg to enclose a report duly completed in connection with the death of Victoria Still, pupil at Cowessess School on February 5..

Broadview, Sask. November 5th. 1940.

Agent's REPORT FOR MONTH OF OCTOBER

Health: The Health of the Indians was generally fairly good. There were three births and two deaths. Wm. Alexson died in hospital from pneumonia and Gerald Trottier died at the Cowessess Residential School of heart disease.

W.J.D. Kerley,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honor to make an application to your Department in connection with an industrial school in Saskatchewan, based on the following:

1. That there is a great number of Native children on the reserves of Battleford, Pemeta Chief, Mosserin, Sweet Grass, Pond Martin and also at Deer Lake, Battle Lake, Wabamun, Snake River, Fort Lacome etc. That it is very difficult to send these children to the distant industrial schools or to offices and other places - I am convinced that such a school would have from 50 to 80 pupils and perhaps more.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 18th, 1892.

My Lord,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's of the 21st ultimo in reference to the establishment of an Industrial School at Buck Lake.

In answer I may inform you that up to the present time the Department has been expending, as Your Lordship is doubtless aware, large sums of money for the education of Indian youth in Manitoba and the North West Territories, and it is thought that the commodious buildings already erected in various parts of the country should be sufficient for the present. At any rate until they are filled and urgent demands for more accommodation are made the necessity for additional school buildings just now is not apparent. However, as His

My Dear Reed,

I enclose for your information a copy of a letter received from the Bishop of Saskatchewan, (R.C.), and a copy of my reply thereto, relative to the establishment of an Industrial School at Duck Lake.

You will recollect that in September 1890, in a letter addressed to Bishop Grandin, I stated, inter alia "I will also recommend to my colleagues the advisability of establishing an Industrial School in Your Lordship's Diocese, and from my own personal knowledge of the country I would suggest one point which you mention, namely, Duck Lake, as being a convenient point, etc."

CANADA
To the Hon. S. Dewdney
Minister of the Interior
& Agent General

I was pleased to hear from you acknowledging the receipt of your letter dated the 18th January, 1852.

I thank you for the hope you have given me, but I think it right to state to you that what we want is a regular Industrial School, one on the same footing as that of St. Boniface or of High River. A simple boarding school would not answer our purpose nor meet the Breton wants.

I am writing to the Rev. Father Gendre, who will communicate with you on this subject.

I have the honour to be,

+ Albert Pascal, M.D.
