PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, March 5th, 1892.

My Lord,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter relative to the establishment of an Indian school at Duck Lake. I regret to say that the very best that we can do at the present is to endeavour to begin in a small way the establishment of a Boarding School at that point, which could in time be increased. Even this I am not yet quite sure whether we shall be able to accomplish or not, on account of the very large expenditure that we are obliged to make at other points where there are more children and greater demands for educational facilities. However, I shall be glad to do all I can in the matter.

Yours sincerely,

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert.
Ottawa, 31st March, 1892.

Dear Mr. Dewdney,

I enclose you a letter herewith which I have received from Bishop Pascal in reference to the establishment of an Industrial School for the Saskatchewan district at Duck Lake. Will you kindly let me know what reply I can send to his Lordship, and oblige,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Hon. E. Dewdney,
Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 2nd, 1892.

Dear Mr. Macdowall,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing a letter from His Lordship Bishop Pascal, in reference to the establishment of an Industrial School for the Saskatchewan District at Duck Lake.

I have already had considerable correspondence with both His Lordship the Bishop of St. Albert and the Bishop of Saskatchewan about this matter, and have promised to do what I can in the way of obtaining a grant for the establishment at least of a Boarding School at that point, which might probably in time develop into an Industrial School. I return His Lordship's letter herewith.

Yours sincerely,

D. H. Macdowall, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Comme réponse à une diverses demandes, je crois que la somme de £2,000 a été allouée dans les lettres supplémentaires. C'est un premier pas; mais que peut-on faire sur une somme si petite!

Donne depuis deux ans l'héritier de cette partie du Diocèse de St-Albert que nous appelons Vicariat de la Saskatchewan, je me vois chargé d'un nombre croissant qui augmente par le jour par l'immigration: ajoutant, je ne dois pas perdre de vue la civilisation de ces nombreux sauvages qui nous entourent et qui par leur vie primitive, leurs mille superstitions, font le désordre du pays et le scandale de l'Europe. Un grand nombre sont encore infidèles. Les beaux résultats obtenus dans le Manitoba, l'Ontario, l'Alberta, je les décrirais aussi pour la Saskatchewan. Ces distances trop grandes ne nous permettent pas de faire participer les enfants de nos sauvages au bénéfice des écoles catholiques de qui appelle ou de High River. Il y a bien sans doute de petits écoles dans chaque réserve, mais l'expérience apprend de plus en plus que le moyen est bien insuffisant pour civiliser l'indien. Quelques heures d'école ne transforment pas l'indien qui a tous les jours sous le yeux la vie et les exemples de ses vieux parents. Il faut lui donner des idées de religion pour les filles, de maîtres dévoués pour les garçons, pour inoculer dans l'esprit et dans le cœur du sauvage les principes et la pratique du bien, de la propriété et de l'industrie.

En réclamant pour mon Vicariat une école industrielle, je prévois les nombreuses difficultés, les grands sacrifices et les déboires qui m'attendent; mais je ne peux avoir d'autre ambition que de voir disparaître totalement pour le boucher de ceux que j'appelle mes enfants et pour la prospérité de ma patrie d'adoption.
Le grand crédit dont nous jouissons,
Hon. Monsieur, et l'Autorité nationale
pourront être levée, ajouté à la
bienveillante charité de votre cœur,
patriotique ou non, espérer un
le bonheur résultant de ma demande
de vous priez la prendre en
considération auprès de M. le Doyen
et du Dépôt.

En espérant ainsi vous avoir convaincu
puissamment au bien de la pauvre
humanité et attiré favorablement
celui qui aurait offert les meilleurs
bénéfices de respectueux commerci-
aux de Dieu et de tout dévoué.

+ Albert Pascal - o.m.s.

via ap. de la Secte

À l'Hon. J. Thompson.
Ministre de la Justice
à Ottawa.
Prince Albert, le 1er octobre 1892.

À l'honorable E. Deynery,
Superintendent général du Département Indien.

Honorable Monsieur,

Permettez-moi de vous offrir mes remerciements pour avoir pris en considération la demande que je vous faisais relative à l'école industrielle ou Boarding School pour les sauvages catholiques du Vicariat de la Saskatchewan. La somme de $2000 allouée dans le dernier supplément ne me permet pas sans doute de commencer une construction de ce genre avec les dépendances nécessaires, pour quelque modeste qu'elle soit à son début. Aussi, j'ose espérer que votre département ira plus loin. Il me faudrait au moins $7000 pour bâtir ; $2000 pour aménagement et fournitures ; $1000 pour l'entretien des enfants la première année. Avec la somme ci-dessus, je pourrai faire construire une maison de 40x30 ft et une cuisine attenante dont je vous enverrai le plan plus tard.

J'ai fait visiter et pris des informations sur les 16 acres de terrain que votre Honneur a fait réserver à Duck Lake. Laissez-moi vous dire, Hon. Monsieur, que ce terrain est loin de me satisfaire. Il n'y a ni bois, ni fonte, ni eau en été, et les buttes de sable y sont nombreuses. En outre il est à deux milles environ de la Station Hobart.

À la vue de ces grands inconvénients, voici après beaucoup de recherches ce que je veux vous soumettre.
Trouveriez-vous des inconvénients à me laisser établir au nord de la branche nord de la Saskatchewan à 7 milles de Prince Albert près du pont qui traverse la Riv. Coquille (Shell River)? Un grand chemin y conduit. Outre le bois, le four, la bonne eau, le poisson qui y abonde, je trouve un terrain léger mais assez bon.

La dans un pays isolé, entouré de bois et de marais, je vous demanderai une demi-section ou 320 acres; une partie des sections 32-33 Tp 49 - 26 et une partie des sec 1 4-5 Tp 50 dans le même rang, à l'ouest du 2e méridien.

Outre ces avantages immenses, celui de me trouver au centre des réserves n'est pas à dédaigner. Agence de Battleford 6 réserves. Agence de Carlton 7 réserves; tandis que dans l'agence de Duck Lake j'en vois que 6.

Vous objecterez peut-être que je serais trop près de l'école de l'Église anglicane au collège Emmanuel. Je peux vous assurer Hon. Monsieur; que l'objection n'en est pas une bien difficile à résoudre. Ces messieurs n'ont qu'à s'occuper de leurs sujets et nous des nôtres seulement. Nos églises sont voisines à Prince Albert et nous vivons en parfaite harmonie. Nos efforts réunis ne seront pas trop grands pour lutter contre la barbarie et de l'infidélité tant de sauvages qui nous avoisinent et pour aider efficacement le Goût dans le noble travail de la civilisation des Indiens.

J'ose espérer de votre Bienveillance que ma requête sera fort en considération et que je pourrai en voir la réalisation bientôt. J'ai l'honneur d'être

Hon. E. Dewdney
S.G. du Dept. Indien
Ottawa
Honorable Sir,

Permit me to offer you my thanks for having taken into consideration the request I made relative to the Industrial or Boarding School for Catholic Indians in the Saskatchewan Vicariate.

The sum of $2,000 allotted in the estimates without doubt does not permit me even to commence a construction of this kind with the necessary outbuildings, however small they may be in the beginning. Therefore I trust that your Department will do more. I should require at least $7,000 to build; $2,000 for furnishing and $1,000 for the support of the children for the first year. With the above sum I could construct a house 40 x 30 feet with a kitchen adjoining which I would send you a plan later on.

I have obtained information concerning the 160 acres of land that your Honor has reserved at Duck Lake and have had it visited. Allow me to inform you, Honorable Sir, that the land is far from satisfying me. There is neither wood, hay, nor water in summer; sand hills are numerous; besides it is situated about two miles from the Hobart Station. Seeing these great inconveniences and having well weighed the matter I wish to submit to your Honor the following points:

Would you find it inconvenient to allow me to establish this school on the North side of the North Saskatchewan seven miles from...
Prince Albert near the bridge that crosses Shell River? A high road leads to this spot. Besides wood, hay and good water, fish abound there. I find the soil light but good enough. There is an isolated locality surrounded with woods and forests. I would ask if you a half section or 320 acres; a part of Secs. 32-33, T.p. 49-26 and a part of Sec. 425 T.p. 80 in the same line to the west of the 2nd Meridian.

Besides these immediate advantages that of finding myself in the centre of reserves is not to be set aside. There are six reserves on the Agency of Battleford and seven in that of Carlton while in that of Duck Lake I see but two.

Your Honor will perhaps object that I should be too near the Anglican Church School at Emmanuel College. I can assure you, Honorable Sir, that this need not be any objection. These gentlemen have to occupy themselves only with their own flock and we with our old churches are near at Prince Albert and we live in perfect harmony. Our united efforts will not be too great to draw from barbarism and infidelity all the savages that surround us and to aid the government efficaciously in the noble work of civilizing the Indians.

I venture to hope in your goodness that my request may be taken into consideration and that I shall soon see my hopes realized.

I have the honor to remain

Honorable Sir,

[Signature]

CANADA
My dear Lord Bishop,

I have your letter of the 1st instant, in reference to the Industrial or Boarding School for Catholic Indians in the Saskatchewan Vicariate, and stating that the amount voted in the Estimates was very inadequate to meet the expense of constructing such a building; also representing that the 160 acres of land reserved at Duck Lake was not very satisfactory.

As to the smallness of the grant made in aid of the building, I can assure you I would have been glad had it been possible for the Government to have made a more liberal grant, but so many were the demands of a similar nature made upon it from other quarters that it was a very difficult matter to obtain the amounts desired.

However, I shall take care to note your Lordship's representations, and see what can be done in the direction of meeting your wishes when next year's Estimates come up for consideration.

I shall also endeavour to see whether some exchange of land can be arranged, and a reserve made which will be

Bishop of Saskatchewan,

Prince Albert.
be more desirable than the one selected. I am now in communication with Commissioner Reed on the subject, and will see that you are advised promptly as soon as I am in a position to do so. I shall also see that the site proposed by your Lordship is fully enquired into.

Believe me,

My dear Lord Bishop,

Yours very sincerely,

Sd. E. Dewdney.
Dear Mr. Vankoughnet,

I received a semi-official communication from the late Supt. General, dated 3rd October, enclosing copy of letter dated 1st of same month, addressed to him by the Bishop of Saskatchewan (R.C.), relative to an Industrial or Boarding School proposed to be established in his diocese, also a copy of Mr. Dewdney's reply.

In connection with the latter I was asked to report regarding the Bishop's proposal to change the contemplated site in the vicinity of Duck Lake, to one on the North side of the North branch of the Saskatchewan, some seven miles from Prince Albert.

Since

L. Vankoughnet, Esq.,
Deputy of
Supt. Genl. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Since then I have received direct from His Lordship a copy of the letter sent to Mr. Dewdney, under cover of another in which he urges upon me the necessity of a regular Industrial Institution.

I regret that I cannot see my way clear to concur in His Lordship's view as to the desirability of the site proposed by him, which would place the Institution in immediate communication with several Protestant Reserves.

To prevent encroachment by Churches upon each other's Indian Missions may be beyond our power but over the establishment of Schools at a distance from Reserves control can be exercised, and I am very much averse to anything likely to lead to dispute between various Denominations.

Actuated by the same views I induced in days gone by, the representatives of the Episcopalian Church to relinquish their strong desire to establish an Industrial School at Duck Lake, and more recently saved for a time at least, the Roman Catholic Mission at Alexander's Reserve, from encroachment at the hands of the Methodists who had determined to open a Boarding School there.

It
It has been suggested to me that an arrangement or understanding might be arrived at between the Churches concerned, which would remove the objection which I have just stated as in my opinion existing, to the site proposed by His Lordship, and if I can carry out my intention to visit the District before long and it can then be clearly shown to me that an arrangement can be made to provide a satisfactory safeguard against the disputes and trouble the danger of which I anticipate, I may then view the matter differently.

Since however, the question of cost (whatever may be decided about the site) will apparently have to be considered before the completion of the Department's "Estimates". I think it will be well in the meantime to explain my views relative to the class of School to be granted.

I am not aware that it was ever contemplated to allow anything more to His Lordship than a Boarding School at Duck Lake.

The wisdom of increasing the number of Industrial Schools already, or about to be established, seems open to question especially in view of the amount which the expenses
expenses of education now aggregate. The wiser policy seems certainly to be in the direction if necessary, of enlarging already existing Institutions, rather than in that of increasing their number.

But even if it were deemed advisable to establish another Roman Catholic Industrial School, experience has shown that the location should be in the vicinity of some centre of civilization more extended than Duck Lake is likely to be for long enough to come if at all, to say nothing about the locality spoken of on the North side of the North Saskatchewan.

I may state that this matter was discussed upon the occasion of the Minister's recent visit, and he appears to concur in the views herein expressed.

I will be glad to learn the result when a conclusion shall have been arrived at in the matter, as I will then be better able to frame a reply to the Bishop's letter to myself, and the class of School would have a hearing upon the choice of a site.

Any provision for this School will have to be made in
in a Supplementary Estimate as it has not been considered in those forwarded to the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Hayter Reed
Department of Indian Affairs

Mr. Peel then spoke his views relative to the idea of school to be created. In these views, Mr. Peel concurs. Mr. Peel does not approve of Rock Lake as a site for a Roman Catholic Lutheran school where it decided to establish another of these institutions, as that region, he considers, is not sufficiently near a centre of civilization to justify the Government in establishing an institution there, and the same remarks apply.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 8th ultimo, respecting the proposal to establish a Roman Catholic Institution, of either the Industrial or Boarding School type, within the Diocese of the Bishop of Saskatchewan and in the eastern part of the said Diocese, I beg to inform you that, having submitted all the facts to the Superintendent General, with respect to this question, he has decided that the Roman Catholic authorities have been given sufficient reason to expect that at least a Boarding School would be established somewhere in that locality; and he has directed that the amount be included in the Estimates to be submitted to Parliament at its next Session, to cover the cost of erecting a building for a Boarding School, for which he considers $2000.00 to be ample; also, for the maintenance and tuition of the children for the first year. The total amount, therefore, to be included in the item for the above Institution would be $4000.00.

I have now, with reference to the site whereon the building is to be erected, to request
that you will communicate with the Church authorities and report to the Department where it will be best to erect the same.

It is noticed that you state in your letter that you propose visiting the Saskatchewan at an early date, when you will perhaps be able to report whether an arrangement could be made to provide a satisfactory safeguard against the disputes and trouble which would arise were this Institution to be placed in proximity to Reserves principally occupied by Indians belonging to Protestant denominations.

Yr. Obt. Svt.
My Dear Lord Bishop,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, stating that you were given to understand that the Roman Catholic Church has received the promise of an Industrial School to be erected at Duck Lake, and pointing out that among the few Indians on the Reserve likely to be most affected by such a school only a dozen or so are Roman Catholic, and recommending that if a school be erected it be undenominational, and controlled by the Department.

In reply I may inform Your Lordship that some two or three years ago the Roman Catholics were promised a school at Duck Lake, or in that vicinity. From what I can gather it was considered that in view of the large Industrial School established at Battleford, which has been drawing pupils from the Reserves within the Carlton Agency and the Reserves East of Prince Albert, and the aid which the Government was extending to Emmanuel College, the Protestant Indian children within these districts were not suffering from the want of educational facilities. On the other hand the nearest Roman Catholic Institution was at Fort Qu'Appelle, and there being a considerable Roman Catholic population on One Arrow's, Beardy and Okemasis', Muskeg Lake, Mistawasis, and Attakakoop's Reserves, roughly speaking over 200, according to the Census returns, it was concluded to comply with the request made at that time, and begin in a small way the establishment of a School at Duck Lake. A small sum has been voted for a commencement, but whether anything has yet been done by the Church authorities I am not aware.

Yours sincerely,

T. Mayne Daly.

His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan and Calgary,
Bishop's Court,
Calgary.
REGINA, ASSA. June 9, 1893.

Dear Mr. Daly,

I am glad to understand that the Roman Catholic Church here needs the services of an industrial school, to be located at Duck Lake; and I wish to point out that among the few Indians on the Reserve, likely to be most affected by such a school, say a dozen or so are Roman Catholics. An industrial school at Duck Lake should be able to draw pupils not only from all the reserves in that agency, but from those in the Carlton agency.

REGINA, June 6th, 1898.

Dear Mr. Daly,

Referring to the matter of placing a Boarding School which eventually may be turned into an Industrial Institution under the patronage of the Roman Catholic authorities, I have just been interviewed in the matter by Mr. Mitchell a member of the Legislative Assembly and of the Executive, who resides at Duck Lake.

He tells me that the Indians are not really Roman Catholics, although claimed by the Church and that the Protestants feel that the Government should not grant this privilege to the Roman Catholics but if an Institution is placed there that it be non-denominational.

There are three churches, Roman Catholic, Church of England and Presbyterian, at Duck Lake, with their resident Ministers.

In

Hon. T. Mayne Daly,
Minister of Interior,

OTTAWA.
In this connection I might say that from the first I was averse to anybody having a like Institution at Duck Lake as we have not as yet our larger Institutions filled, but the promise having been made by Mr. Dewdney, I suppose it has to be carried into effect.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, 28th March, 1896.

Rev. Sir,

Replying to your queries during our personal interview last Monday, I have to make the following replies:

As to Bishop Pechal's desire to open a school at Prince Albert until the building at Lake Louise is completed, I think it would be better if such were not done, as I fear it would only tend to excite suspicion and ill-feeling on the part of others; and as it will be but for a few months, I think you will agree with me that, for the sake of that short time it had better not be done.

As regards the dormitory in the Fish River School, I am authorizing an expenditure in order that this may be made suitable for the little boys of the institution and thus increase the accommodation. I shall also instruct that the staircases inside the building be always kept perfectly clear and that the doors open outwards from the rooms; further that a fire-escape be made from the outside of the dormitory, as in other institutions.

As to the printing press, I find that a new one will cost between four and five hundred dollars. This, of course, includes the type, but, I fear, is a larger sum than
our means will allow us to expend, for the present. Still,
I will be on the lookout for some second hand press. Would
you kindly do likewise? Possibly in your tour through
the country you would be able to come across some suitable
press which would do the work equally well as a new one.
The most likely part, I fancy, for this would be in the west
where towns are increasing in size and printing establish-
ments are dispensing with the old presses.

In connection with the High River School, I have
just read a lengthy and exhaustive report of Inspector
McGibbon's; and I find that if all the indebtedness has been
charged in the books, the school will not be behind more than
six or seven hundred dollars, and possibly less than that
sum, when it is considered that the fuel will be greatly
saved from now until the end of the fiscal year. This being
the case, I have instructed Regina Office that every
economy must be practiced in order that the vote be not
exceeded, even to the extent of reducing or temporarily dis-
pensing with the services of the staff. The Government is
becoming more than particular relative to the over-expendi-
ture of any vote. Consequently, we must use drastic measures.

As regards the Onion Lake School, as promised I
am directing that the order for the re-building of this
school be given by the agency, and as much work as is pos-
sible for them to give to be given by the employees.

I find that we have estimated for 20 pupils to
be paid in money for the Onion Lake Institution, but if any
more are here, I think I can safely promise, at all events to
a reasonable number, that aid will be given to a limited extent by way of provisions as heretofore.

For Lac la Biche we estimated for 18 pupils; for St. Albert 50 pupils at $100.00. As the Estimates are printed, I fear I cannot promise more now; but as time goes on an opportunity may be offered to aid you more in the direction His Lordship and yourself desire.

For the same reason, I fear no hope can be held out to you now as regards a Boarding School at Bear's Hills.

I beg leave to remain

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Rev. Father Lacombe,
St. Peter's Church,
Montreal.
To The Honourable Thomas M. Daly,
Minister of the Interior,
Supt. General of the,
Indian Department.

Honourable Sir:

As your Department has already been informed, the Boarding School of Duck Lake has been established. The Rev. Father Paquette, officially named Principal of the establishment, has for the last two months, received twenty children at his own expense. The delay caused in the completion of the works has been much felt. It required all the zeal and also the resources of the Rev. Father Paquette to triumph over the numerous difficulties which are inevitable at the commencement of such institutions. Among these difficulties the privation of water, on account of the dryness of the season, was not one of the least. To-day I am happy to tell you, as also your Department, that all works well now. The children are satisfied and happy, and we are satisfied with them. Let me be allowed, Honourable Sir, to thank you for all that has been
been done up to the present.

And now I wish to apply to your Department for the enlargement and amelioration of this newly founded Institute, the only one I possess for Catholic Indians in the Vicariate of Saskatchewan.

The following are the reasons, which I have put forward in support of my demands:

1st. The Rev. Father Paquette has been authorized to accept only twenty children; as the building has not been constructed to receive a great number. Therefore, what is the consequence? 75 children have been refused admittance. The Principal embarrassed in his choice, confined himself to receiving orphans, and the most abandoned children. As you understand; here, it is not necessary to press the Indians to give up their children, we displease them in refusing to take them for want of accommodation. Why should we not establish immediately an Industrial School, such as exists in the other Dioceses? If you do not wish to give it this title, at least enlarge the building in such a manner as to allow us to double or even to triple the number of children next summer.

We find this necessary for this reason:

2nd. That experience shows us, more clearly every day, that the small Day Schools attached to the Reserves, are but a feeble and inefficient...
inefficacious means of improving and forming the Indian child. It is absolutely necessary that they should be separated from their families, in order to bring them up as we desire.

3rd. At the same time I cannot help calling your Honour's attention to the difficulty, I could almost say, the impossibility, we are under of continuing this work, so useful, with the small resources which are allowed us by the Department. It is easy to see, it seems to me, that it is difficult to furnish food, clothing, fuel, light, &c., in fine, to wash and provide for twenty children also to pay six or seven persons employed for the instruction of the children and the management of the house, with the sum of $1400.00 a year. The Rev. Father Paquette assures me that notwithstanding all his vigilance and his economy, he will have at the end of the term a deficit of at least $300.00. Permit me, therefore, Honourable Sir to entreat your Department to be pleased to raise the $72.00 a head per annum to $125.00 or at least to $100.00.

Could not the $300.00 paid to the Teachers of the Schools on the Reserves be given to this Institution in proportion as these Schools are given up?

2. Vote a reasonable subsidy for the enlargement of the building capable of admitting 100 children. We have shown our good will in accepting
accepting this work under conditions so disadvan-
tageous, that we could not hope for good re-
sults, and for that reason we consented to give
up to the Department 100 acres of excellent
land and in one of the best sites of the Sask-
atchewan. It appears to us that we have on
our side the right, that the Department should
help us to continue this work of true civiliz-
ation, which does it so much honour.

Receive Honourable Sir, my respectful
wishes, with the assurance of my highest es-
teem.

x Albert O.M.I. Ev. de Mosynopolis, Vic.
Apost. de Saskatchewan.

We cordially and warmly endorse the foregoing and be-
speak for it the most favourable consideration of the
Minister of the Interior.

St. Michael's Boarding School,
Duck Lake,
12th Decr. 1894

To Sir Adolphe Caron,

Honourable Sir—

Though I do not know you personally, allow me to write to you briefly asking your kindness on my behalf.

As principal of the boarding school at Duck Lake, the government has built too small a house for me to lodge therein about fourteen children. You understand, Honourable Sir, that it is ridiculous to shut up a priest in a school with such a small number of pupils. I have, however, succeeded in obtaining from the government permission to receive thirty children instead of fourteen; and if the house were larger, within six months...
I could have more than two hundred young Indians in my school. Having been a missionary in the midst of these tribes for more than twenty years, I am known by all and all wish to entrust their children to me. It is now and always will be impossible for me to maintain my school on a good footing with the small sum the government allows me for this purpose—$72 per annum for each child, and I must board and clothe them, pay two schoolmasters—one for the boys and one for the girls—and also pay all the other expenses of the house. To sum up, they tell you that $72 for each child will not pay half the expenses. If I had from 150 to 200 children I might, perhaps, get back what I pay out; but
thirty children only are the cause of considerable expense to me, as they require the same attention as I do would.

I have just received a letter from Mr. Macdonald, our Member for Prince Albert, whom no doubt you know. He tells me to write and explain the circumstances to you so that you may be able to support your request when he brings up the question in the House.

I earnestly desire that my boarding school be changed to an industrial school and that it enjoy the advantages and privileges of industrial schools such as those at Red Appelle and Battleford.

In the hope that you will receive my request favorably, I am confident that you will do all you can to obtain this end for the
great good of the Indians
and the honour of the
Government.

Praying you to accept
in advance my most sincere
thanks for all that you
will be kind enough to do
in order to accomplish the end
in view.

Please accept, Honorable
Sir, my respectful regards

M. J. P. Laguette
President, O.M.
Principal.

Sir Adolphe Caron,
Postmaster General,
Ottawa.

À Sir, Adolphe Caron,

Cher Monsieur,

Bien que je ne puisse pas être présent de vous connaître personnellement, permettez-moi cependant de vous écrire quelques mots pour vous faire savoir que j'ai bien voulu me confronter à votre situation.

Principal de l'école Boarding School de Duck Lake, le gouvernement m'a ordonné de louer une toute petite maison pour y loger au moins 14 enfants. Vous comprenez honnêtement que ce n'est pas possible de tenir une telle enfant dans une école pour un si petit nombre de personnes. J'ai pourtant réussi à obtenir du gouvernement la permission de recevoir 30 enfants au lieu de 14, et si la maison était plus grande, je pourrais à moins de six mois avoir plus de 200
Sir, petits Sauvages dans mon école, missionnaire depuis plus de 20 ans au milieu de ces tribus, tous me connaissent et tous désirent me confier leurs enfants. Il m'est donc impossible de tenir mon école sur un bon pied avec la petite somme que le gouvernement m'a donnée à cet effet. 72 priastres pour chaque enfant par année, et il me faut les nourrir, les vêtir, payer deux maîtres d'école, un pour les garçons et l'autre pour les filles, et enfin payer toutes les autres dépenses de la maison, en résumé, je vous disais que 72 priastres pour chaque enfant ne paye pas la moitié des dépenses. Si j'avais 150 à 200 enfants je trouverais peut-être une attaque sur le nombre, mais 80 enfants seulement ne sont une cause de dépenses...
Sir, considérable, au qu'il me faut les mêmes engagés pour 30, qu'il m'en faut obéir pour 200.

Je viens de recevoir une lettre de Mr Macdonald, notre membre du Prince Albert, que vous connaissez sans doute. Il me dit de vous écrire et de vous expliquer les choses afin que vous puissiez l'appuyer lorsqu'il s'agira de cette question en Chambre. Je désire ardemment que mon école Boarding School soit changée en école industrielle, et qu'elle jouisse des avantages et privilèges des écoles industrielles du gouvernement, comme celles de Drayton et de Battleford. Dans l'espoir que vous recevrez un accueil favorable à ma requête, j'ai la confiance que vous ferez tout votre possible afin d'obtenir ce com-
Sir, des Sauvages et l'homme du gouvernement.
Vous priant d'accepter par avance mes remerciements les plus sincères, pour tout ce que vous daignerez faire pour mener cette chose à bonne fin.

Veuillez agréer
L'honorable ministre
mes hommages respectueux

M. J.P. Paquette

Ottawa, December 27th, 1894.

Dear Sir Adolphe,

With reference to the Rev. Father Papineau's letter of the 12th instant, requesting your assistance towards getting more accommodation and increased per capita grant for the Boarding School at Duck Lake, I feel sure that when I tell you I am making provision in the Estimates for next year to increase the number of pupils to 50, and to expend $1000 on additional accommodation for their reception, you will, with your knowledge of the position, recognize that I am doing all I can to meet your wishes, consistently with any prospect of getting the consent of Council. The superiority of Industrial Schools is recognized, but only a proportion of Indian children manifest ability to take such advantage of the training given them as would justify
justify their cost, were that a less serious consideration than it is, and if there be found children worthy of greater educational advantages than can be expected for the annual per capita grant of $72 given to the Boarding Schools, they must be drafted to the existing Industrial Institutions as vacancies occur.

The Department has instituted all the Industrial Schools it can for the present, in face of the large aggregate expenditure on education of Indian children has reached, and has endeavoured to divide them among various churches desirous of conducting them, that with perhaps the exception of the Presbyterian Church, all have received a justly proportionate share.

The Department had, notwithstanding strong pressure, recently to refuse to give the Church of England an Industrial School at Prince Albert, in the same district.

Yours faithfully,

Sir A. P. Caron,
K. C. M. G.,
Postmaster General,
Ottawa.

5e Janvier 1895

Mon cher Sir,

Je viens de recevoir votre lettre confirmant votre visite de l'Éducation Indienne. Dab et Caron, grands mercis pour votre trouble.

Il est beau et bon que l'on se réjouisse de nos enfants, mais ce n'est pas là notre but. Le Département devrait comprendre qu'il ne civilisera jamais les Sauvages avant qu'il enlève les enfants des parents et qu'il ferme toutes les petites écoles des réserves. Ces écoles ne sont bonne...
n'en grand début si le gouvernement ne veut pas que mon école soit industrielle, qu'il la laisse Boarding school mais qu'il me permette de recevoir au moins 100 enfants, il y a tant de petits sauvages qui causent les loges et le bois comme des petits bêtes, tandis qu'ils devraient être bien formés et intelligents s'ils étaient élevés dans une école.

Allons, mon cher Mr Macdonald, il ne faut pas nous regarder comme vaincus et dormir en paix. 1900 piastres ne suffisent pas pour l'agrandissement de mon école, on accorderait ailleurs de 15 à 20 mille piastres par année pour une école, et ici même nous pouvons par même avoir 2000 piastres pour construction. La chose me paraît tout à fait injuste qu'on donne tous à l'appelée et à Regina et qu'on ne donne presque rien à Prince Albert et à Duck Lake. Ces sauvages doivent être aussi considérés que ceux des autres provinces.

Si il vous plaît de vous efforcer de faire connaître les choses au gouvernement et de lui prouver que toutes les écoles Boarding schools
lui coûte moins cher que l'entretien des sauvages qui sont sur les réserves.

Je demeure cher Monsieur votre très humble

M. J.J. Paquette

Prince Albert

My dear Daly,

I enclose a letter from Father Paquet which explains itself. Dear Macdonald,

With further reference to yours of the 5th instant, I find that on the 27th ultimo I sent you copy of letter to Sir Adolphe Caron, in which I told him what we are doing to meet Father Paquette's views. I observe that this does not seem to the latter to be sufficient, but while we would gladly do all that is asked for his district, and indeed all over, we have only a limited amount of funds, and endeavour to apportion them as fairly as possible, and to the best advantage. In Father Paquette's own interests it would not seem advisable to risk having the whole provision for extending his school thrown out by asking Council for too much at one time.

He seems to forget, in arguing as he does, that although Industrial Schools must be located in certain Districts, they are open to eligible children from
from other Districts, his own included.

To close Day Schools on Reserves and substitute Boarding Schools at a distance is our policy, but it must be remembered that the saving of a Teacher's salary made by shutting up a Day School will go but a short way towards maintaining an Industrial or Boarding School.

The policy is, moreover, when Boarding School accommodation can not be provided for all children of an Agency, to let those of the Reserve upon which the Boarding School may be established attend it as day scholars, and take those from more distant Reserves in as boarders.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

D. H. Macdowall, Esq., M.P.,
Prince Albert,

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to lay the following matter before you and to state that as you know I have proceeded with a visit. I feel sure your attention has been drawn to the good work we are undertaking and the many difficulties we have to contend with.

1. That the Boarding School may be established as an Industrial Institution.
2. That the Grant be increased to One Hundred Dollars a year per head, as I find after one year's time it almost impossible to clothe, board, teach and dress up the children in a proper way that will only be in accordance with the School Rules and the Indian Department.
3. Closets are much wanted in the house for winter as it is not safe for young children to sleep out doors at night during the cold weather.
4. A lister is greatly needed to collect...
Salt water as the well water is too hard and unfit for washing and also for use in cases of fire to be of very recent.

No. 5. A surgeon is always much required, as not only is the store system very inconvenient but is dangerous by reason of the stop pipe.

No. 6. An ice house is very much needed to keep meat fresh.

No. 7. A barn for the horses as it is dangerous in case of fire to have it blowing about outside.

No. 8. A play yard for girls and boys separated by a walled fence.

No. 9. The school ground to be fenced in order to preserve building and gardens from intrusion of stray cattle.

No. 10. A carpenter's shop and a shop for shoe makers to work in is very much needed.

Thanking you for your most kind and interest. Almost you will consider the pressing and I will come to see did and take it. I say I have refused from bringing the matter up before Mr. Judge Robert, or Mr. Daly as I have very faith in your kindly aid.

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you that I have been at One Arrows Reserve, Duck Lake Agency today, and baptised twenty-two children of the same reserve. All the adults requested to be baptised too, but I judged it necessary to make them wait until they should receive some instruction.

After the ceremony all these Indians brought me sixteen of their children, who are of school age to be admitted into my school. As you understand I was obliged to refuse them, not being authorized by the Department.

These Indians were greatly disappointed when I told them so, and they did not seem to understand why I could not receive their children at once.

I was sorry for them as my power and my purse were smaller than my heart. If I had authority I would not hesitate to put them in my own room, and even give them my own bed. Now I beg you will kindly obtain from the Department the necessary permission to place these children in my school as soon as possible.

I know quite well there is no money voted for that purpose this year, but the Department can refund me the money later on, which will be the same to me.

The Indian Agent.

Duck Lake
I have every confidence that you will do all in your power to obtain my request.

I remain, etc

sgd M.M.P. Paquette Pte. O.M.I.

In April 1892 writing to D. H. Macdowall our member of Parliament he said "I have promised to do what I can in the way of obtaining a Grant for the establishment at least of a Boarding School, which might probably in time develop into an Industrial School".

2nd. The first part of the promise is realized for which

I

I owe to your Department and to the Government my praise and thanks, but when will the Second be accomplished?

3rd. Thanks to the devotedness and intelligence of the Rev Father Paquette the Principal, thanks also to the wise advice of the Agent Mr Mackenzie the Boarding School cf Duck Lake has developed in an astonishing way (in every respect) The forty five children that this school shelters make great progress and are very happy. The Indians of the Agencies of Carlton and Duck Lake incessantly beg of the Rev Father Paquette to receive still more.

In spite of the refusal of the Principal, the Indians of Batoche left eleven of their children in the snow at the door of the School. The Rev Father Paquette found himself obliged (though before being authorized to do so) to receive them in order to prevent their dying from hunger and cold. In less than a month one hundred and fifty children could be found, if there were the necessary accommodations.

More recent still, the Honourable Mackenzie
Mackenzie Bowell, Premier; T. M. Daly, Minister of the Interior and Superintendent General of the Indian Department; Hayter Reed Commissioner of the Indians etc etc during their visit to the North West were greatly pleased with the children of Duck Lake Boarding School seeing their rapid progress, which they had not expected.

In consequence, I earnestly ask that the title of Industrial School, and whatever results from this title, be granted without delay to this Institution. The Vicariate of Saskatchewan has not yet an Industrial School for our Catholic Indian children.

The Rev F Paquette (Principal) merits this encouragement and this school in which, I myself am deeply interested will be an honor to the Government.

I dare to hope in your kindness Honorable Sir, that my request may be taken into consideration and that my legitimate hopes will not be frustrated.

I have the honor to be,

Honourable Sir,

Your humble Servant,

My Lord,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of a communication addressed to the Superintendent General, Commissioner for Ontario and the North-West Territories, by Your Lordship, applying for the reasons given, for the recognition of the Duck Lake Boarding School, as an Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that the previous promise of the establishment of a Boarding School at Duck Lake has been fully redeemed. It was opened in '92 with provision for fourteen pupils, which number was increased to thirty in '95, and in further mark of the Department's appreciation of the excellent work done at this school since its establishment, it has increased the number of pupils to be provided for in the Estimates for the next fiscal year by forty, which will make provision for seventy in all, or more than double the number included in this year's grant. In so doing the Department feels that it is showing substantial recognition of the progress made by the children at this school under the successful management and supervision of the Rev. Father Prequette, but for the following reasons it cannot see its way to carry out what you imply, was a second promise made by Mr Dewdney to Mr McDowall, namely to probably develop in time the Boarding into an Industrial School.

Rt-Rev: Albert Pascal, O.M.I., Vicar-Apostolic of Saskatchewan

CANADA
There are now a number of Industrial Schools in Manitoba and the Territories, which have been in existence for some years, and as many of the pupils at these schools have now attained an age when it will be necessary for them to leave, the question of providing for them is forced upon the Department, and is a matter for serious consideration. Many of the pupils at these schools have been taught trades such as printing, making, tailoring, shoemaking and others which would be of no practical use to them should they have to go back to their own homes. The Department will therefore have to look out for employment for them in their respective trades, which can only be found in business centres, and unless it can place them satisfactorily, the time and money spent upon their industrial training will be practically lost.

The number of trades pupils that will, in the near future, be turned out annually, it is feared exceed the demand for such class of skilled labor. It is not therefore thought that it would be wise to increase the number of our Industrial Schools, but rather to provide increased accommodation, needed the present capacity, at the existing Institutions.

Industrial schools in the vicinity of thriving towns possess greater advantages than those in isolated localities, as pupils at such schools are brought into closer contact with the white population and from their social environment more readily acquire civilized habits. There is also this additional advantage—pupils can be taught more trades and have freer scope for the exercise of any particular aptitude they may exhibit for one or other of the trades not taught at the school, as they can be and often are apprenticed to
to local tradesmen who are always glad to secure their services, and by whom they are well cared for and instructed. Printing, tinsmithing and harness-making are thus acquired by pupils, while some are clerks in shops who if placed in a school on a Reserve, could not have similar opportunities and advantages.

The expenses connected with the maintenance and management of Industrial Schools are necessarily very high on account of the number of skilled instructors at high wages which are required on the staff, while the receipts outside of the work charged against the Institution are small, if any. While the staff required to carry on a Boarding School is small in comparison, besides which such schools are primarily missionary undertakings and are therefore managed at much less cost.

From past experience the Department is forced to admit that the results obtained by Indian Day Schools in the Territories have been in most cases of little practical value and for this reason it is assisting liberally in the establishment of Boarding schools where the children can be removed from the harmful influences of the camp environment and religious training and instruction which will fit them for their future life on the Reserve.

It should be the aim of such schools to furnish a rudimentary education and inculcate habits of thrift and industry in the children committed to their charge. The pursuit of agriculture should form the calling of the boys who should also be taught the use of simple carpenter tools, while the girls are taught sewing, knitting and general housework. The education and training received at these schools should
should suffice for the greater number of the present generation of Indian children, and they should also be used as feeders for the existing Industrial Schools thereby causing a saving in time and money, and would enable the Industrial Schools to devote more attention to the teaching of handicrafts. A more healthy and intelligent class of pupils could be placed in the latter schools than is now possible.

In conclusion I beg to say that the Department has no objection to this school assuming the title of Industrial School upon the express understanding that no claim will be made for an increased grant on that account.

I have the honor to be

Your Lordship's most obedient servant,

Deputy Supt:Genl:
of Indian Affairs.

Sir:

For the last two years your Duck Lake Boarding School has been opened, and several times since then, the Indians of the Saskatchewan district have asked me to teach their children different trades, as they do in all Industrial Schools. Having refused their request several times and finding it impossible to make them understand the difference between Boarding and Industrial Schools, I have been obliged, in some measure, to consent to teach their children, as we do in such Institutions.

There is a Protestant Industrial School at Battleford, and one training school at Prince Albert, and only this Boarding School for Catholic Indians in this district. I should think therefore it would be only fair for the Department to give to these Catholic Indians an Industrial School with all the privileges attached to such an Institution.

Hoping

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter and Circular of the 26th March, No. 0154, I beg leave to say that we will do all in our power to conform to it.

As a reply to the desire expressed that the aid of the Department afforded for the support of the boarding schools should not be employed otherwise, nor diverted in any manner, I can assure you that there is no need to fear this at Duck Lake, and I can only give you the best proof of it, in telling you that I have been obliged to come to its assistance, for I have spent out of my own funds, the sum of $1300.00 (one thousand, eight hundred dollars) for keeping up the prosperity of the school and if the work has made such rapid developments, in so short a time, and at present causes the admiration of visitors, it is in a great measure owing not only to the zeal and industry and to the resources of the Principal, but above all to my own money.

I am much surprised that the Department,

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina.
which is aware that there is not a single catholic industrial school in Saskatchewan, and notwithstanding our reiterated applications, for almost the last five years, has not yet deigned to raise this one to the rank of industrial school, by giving it the means of meeting the obligations which they entail. Nothing would do it more honour, and this would be the best encouragement to give to the Rev Father Paquette and to all those who are interested in this institution.

To the Honorable Clifford Sifton, Minister of the Interior and General Superintendent of Indian Affairs:

Honorable Sir,

I have the honor to apply to your Department to obtain the erection of an Industrial School for the Roman Catholic Indians of the Saskatchewan. The Diocese of St. Boniface, Manitoba, Alberta, and New Westminster, B.C., have both Industrial and Boarding Schools; and for years I have been asking myself, why the Diocese of Saskatchewan does not enjoy the same privilege. Are its wants fewer? Have the Indians here less right to the favors of the Government than elsewhere? I do not, nor can I believe it.

I find in the Diocese five agencies, which comprise 31 Reserves. 1st, the Agency of Battleford, with 7 Reserves; 2nd, the Agency of Carlton, with 9; 3rd, the Agency of Duck Lake, with 6; 4th, the Agency of the Pas, with 7. We have, moreover, the Reserves of Lake La Ronge and Montreal Lake, which are ruled by a special treaty.

With the exception of two or three Reserves, where there are but few Catholic Indians, all the others contain a great number of Catholics, and several have an overwhelming majority. Now these Indians are the children of the Dominion, they are, therefore, entitled to the same favors and privileges as their eastern brethren. Wherefore I, the Bishop of the Diocese of Saskatchewan, their father and pastor in the Faith, come once more to plead the cause of the poor Indians.

Catholics must be treated on a perfect footing of equality with the members of other religious denominations. Protestants have an Industrial School at Battleford, towards which the Government has shown great liberality. They have also a Training School at Prince Albert. Catholics alone have none, and why they are left in the background we cannot understand. They had to fight for six years in order to obtain a simple Boarding School at Duck Lake.

When I took charge of the Diocese in 1891, I found among the letters of the Conservative Government, then in power, strong recommendations made by the Hon. E. Dewdney to Bishop Grandin, then in charge of the whole Diocese. Seven years have since elapsed, and nothing more has been done. Since my appointment as Bishop, I spared neither time nor exertions to obtain the fulfillment of these hopes, which would be but an act of justice. I had the honor to present a petition to the Government in 1891, another in 1894. I likewise presented others in 1896 and in 1897. Seeing the uselessness of my efforts, I decided to come once more to the front in the present year. All that I have so far obtained is the establishment of a Boarding School at Duck Lake, with the hope that later on that school would become Industrial. These hopes are attested by a letter I had the honor to receive from the Hon. E. Dewdney on the 2nd of April, 1892. With full confidence in these promises, I have authorized the Principal of the school of Duck Lake to devote more than ordinary care to the development of this establishment, on grounds that have since become the property of the Government, by the deed drawn up in its favor. We have incurred private building expenses above $10,000, as is proved by our vouchers and receipts. We have not refused to incur such expenses, as they were necessary to insure the success of the school, the only one in the Diocese. I may say, to the honor of the Department, that the school of Duck Lake is an object of admiration to all visitors.

Wishing to comply with the desires of the Indians, and to meet the views of the Department, we have prescribed in the school the teaching of joinery and agriculture, there being no industrial school in the Diocese. Knowing the government to be animated with a strong desire of advancing the education and civilization of the Indians, and desiring Catholic Indians to be on the same footing as other denominations, I therefore beg the Government to give me an Industrial School in the Saskatchewan.

If the Government is not willing to transform the school of Duck Lake into an Industrial school, well, be it so; but then let the Government give us, without further delay, an Industrial School, either at Battleford or elsewhere. Protestants having two, by all means we must have at least one, otherwise we will never cease to complain and to cry injustice.

May I venture to make a suggestion?

I have in present a beautiful large brick building at Prince Albert, with every desirable convenience—heating apparatus, plentiful supply of water, large grounds adjoining. This house was built expressly for a first class Boarding School by the Nuns, who for several reasons were obliged to leave it, and we now offer this fine building to the Government at a very nominal price, to be used for an Industrial School.

I hope, Hon. Sir, that this my sixth petition, will receive more consideration than those presented in the past, and that the Government will see how very essential it is that I should have at least one Industrial School in my Diocese of Saskatchewan.

I have the honor to be, Hon. Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

OTTAWA, 7th March, 1898.

Right Reverend Sir,

I am directed by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's printed letter in which the suggestion is made that the Department should take over a brick building formerly occupied as a boarding school by the nuns and convert the same into an Indian industrial school. The Superintendent General directs me to say in reply that he has decided not to assist in the erection of any new industrial schools at present and he regrets, therefore, that he cannot entertain Your Lordship's proposition.

I have the honor to be,
Your Lordship's most obedient servant,

S.D. McLEAN

Rt.Rev.Albert Pascal,O.M.I.,

Sask.

CANADA
To the Honorable Clifford Hilton, Minister of the Interior and General Superintendent of Indian Affairs:

Honorable Sir,

I have the honor to apply to your Department to obtain the erection of an Industrial School for the Roman Catholic Indians of the Saskatchewan. The Dioceses of St. Boniface, Man., St. Albert, Alta., and New Westminster, B. C., have both Industrial and Boarding Schools, and for years I have been asking myself why the Diocese of Saskatchewan does not enjoy the same privilege. Are its wants fewer? Have the Indians here less right to the favors of the Government than elsewhere? I do not, nor can I believe it.

I find in the Diocese five agencies, which comprise 31 Reserves. 1st, the Agency of Battleford, with 7 Reserves; 2nd, the Agency of Carlton, with 9; 3rd, the Agency of Duck Lake, with 6; 4th, the Agency of the Pas, with 7. We have, moreover, the Reserves of Lake La Ronge and Montreal Lake, which are ruled by a special treaty.

With the exception of two or three Reserves, where there are but few Catholic Indians, all the others contain a great number of Catholics, and several have an overwhelming majority. Now these Indians are the children of the Dominion, they are, therefore, entitled to the same favors and privileges as their eastern brethren. Wherefore I, the Bishop of the Diocese of Saskatchewan, their father and pastor in the Faith, come once more to plead the cause of the poor Indians.

Catholics must be treated on a perfect footing of equality with the members of other religious denominations. Protestants have an Industrial School at Battleford, towards which the Government has shown great liberality. They have also a Training School at Prince Albert. Catholics alone have none, and why they are left in the background we cannot understand. They had to fight for six years in order to obtain a simple Boarding School at Duck Lake.

When I took charge of the Diocese in 1891, I found among the letters of the Conservative Government, then in power, strong recommendations made by the Hon. E. Dewdney to Bishop Grandin, then in charge of the whole Diocese. Seven years have since elapsed, and nothing more has been done. Since my appointment as Bishop, I spared neither time nor exertions to obtain the fulfillment of these hopes, which would be but an act of justice. I had the honor to present a petition to the Government in 1891, another in 1894. I likewise presented others in 1896 and in 1897. Seeing the uselessness of my efforts, I decided to come once more to the front in the present year. All that I have so far obtained is the establishment of a Boarding School at Duck Lake, with the hope that later on that school would become Industrial. These hopes are attested by a letter I had the honor to receive from the Hon. E. Dewdney on the 2nd of April, 1892. With full confidence in these promises, I have authorized the Principal of the school of Duck Lake to devote more than ordinary care to the development of this establishment, on grounds that have since become the property of the Government, by the deed drawn up in its favor. We have incurred private building expenses above $10,000, as is proved by my vouchers and receipts. We have not refused to incur such expenses, as they were necessary to insure the success of the school, the only one in the Diocese. I may say, to the honor of the Department, that the school of Duck Lake is an object of admiration to all visitors.

Wishing to comply with the desires of the Indians, and to meet the views of the Department, we have prescribed in the school the teaching of joinery and agriculture, there being no industrial school in the Diocese. Knowing the government to be animated with a strong desire of advancing the education and civilization of the Indians, and desiring Catholic Indians to be on the same footing as other denominations, I therefore beg the Government to give me an Industrial School in the Saskatchewan.

If the Government is not willing to transform the school of Duck Lake into an Industrial school, well, be it so; but then let the Government give us, without further delay, an Industrial School, either at Battleford or elsewhere. Protestants having two, by all means we must have at least one, otherwise we will never cease to complain and to cry injustice.

May I venture to make a suggestion?

I have at present a beautiful large brick building at Prince Albert, with every desirable convenience—heating apparatus, plentiful supply of water, large grounds adjoining. This house was built expressly for a first-class Boarding School by the Nuns, who for several reasons were obliged to leave it, and we now offer this fine building to the Government at a very nominal price, to be used for an Industrial School.

I hope, Hon. Sir, that this my sixth petition, will receive more consideration than those presented in the past, and that the Government will see how very essential it is that I should have at least one Industrial School in my Diocese of Saskatchewan.

I have the honor to be, Hon. Sir,

Your obedient servant,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

CANADA
Ottawa, 8th March, 1898.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of the petition signed by his Lordship Bishop Paschal, having reference to the erection of an Industrial School for the Roman Catholic Indians of the Saskatchewan. In reply I beg to say that while there may be a great deal of truth in the statements made by Bishop Paschal yet it is a matter which it is absolutely impossible to take up during the present year. The large amount of money which has been expended on Industrial Schools during the past few years has led the Department to hesitate before authorizing any further expenditure in this regard at least until the question as to the merits or demerits of the system of Industrial Schools has been fully considered.

In the meantime, therefore, the application of Bishop Paschal will be placed upon file in the Department, and consideration given to it during the coming year.

Yours very truly,

T. O. Davis, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

Deputy Supt. General.

--- Notice of Motion ---

Mr. Davis.

On Monday next --- Enquiry of Ministry ---

What was the cost of maintenance of the Indian Industrial School at Duck Lake, Saskatchewan, for the last fiscal year? How many pupils are there in the school? What is the cost to the Government per capita per annum?

Ans. 1. Cost $4,050.80.

2. Present attendance 72. Average for Fiscal year 1895-7-93.

Ans. 3. The per capita allowance for maintenance is $72.00 per annum; but there are expenses such as medical attendance which are paid in addition to the allowance, and so during the last fiscal year the cost was $76.05 per capita per annum.

This Institution is what is known as a Boarding School, not an Industrial School.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of

I have the honour to inform you that Principal Charlebois called here yesterday afternoon and reported that an outbreak of Diphtheria had occurred among the children of the Duck Lake Boarding School. I at once sent a team to Rosthern for anti-toxin, and secured what the druggists here had. I got in all 46,000 units, and will get by tomorrow's train 79,000 more. It will take 100,000 units to inoculate all of the children, and 25,000, or may be required for those who now have the disease. On Sunday afternoon there were three cases at night four, this morning eight cases. I have thought it advisable to call in Dr Reavley of Rosthern—who has had very considerable experience with this disease—to get his opinion on what has been done, and his advice on the whole matter. I will meet him this afternoon. If the disease spreads a doctor should live at the school, and I will act accordingly. I will report again tomorrow.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
IN YOUR REPLY REFER TO
No. 105
ALSO
TO DATE OF THIS LETTER.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 5th, No 105, I have the honour to inform you that last night one other case of Diphtheria occurred at the School. Thinking the matter sufficiently grave I wired the Dept of Public Health Regina, asking that they send a Doctor to take charge and live at the School. They replied this morning that they could not get one to come up. I received today sufficient Anti Toxin, so that by now I expect all have been inoculated, if no more cases occur within the next 24 hours I think we will have the outbreak under control. I saw Dr Touchette an hour ago, when he told me that all of the nine cases are in a favourable condition. The outlay for Anti Toxin has been very considerable, but unavoidable. The nine cases have been placed in a large isolated house, and the nursing is of the very best.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your Obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, November 5th, 1909.

Memorandum for file.

In a personal letter addressed by Rev. O. S. Charlebois to the Superintendent of Indian Education that gentleman asked consideration of a plan whereby pupils, both boys and girls, of the Duck Lake Boarding School may during their last year be sent out to service in the homes of the neighbouring white people. The Principal's object is to give them a more practical training in conditions more nearly approaching those under which they will have to work when they leave the school. During this period they would still be under the control and supervision of the Principal.

Father Charlebois thinks that during this period the school should be allowed half the grant, or if no grant is paid that they should be allowed to substitute others, if such are in residence. The earnings of the pupils are to be funded for them, except perhaps a small percentage that they might require for personal expenses. The Principal is to see that the homes they are placed in are satisfactory and that they are well used during their time of service, otherwise they are to be called back to the school.

Superintendent of Indian Education.
Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I return herewith the list of drugs which are required for the Duck Lake Boarding School, and I have to inform you that you may purchase the same. It is desired, however, to draw your attention to what appears to be an error in the list, viz:- the request for 2 lbs of laudanum. If this is a mistake it should be corrected.

I have to remind you that in future drug requisitions should be submitted in duplicate.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. Macarthur, Esq.,

Ottawa, November 18th, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to the correspondence had between yourself and the Superintendent of Indian Education in regard to allowing pupils of the Duck Lake Boarding School to be placed in service during the whole or a portion of their last year, I beg to say that the Department is prepared to try the experiment.

These boys and girls are to remain on the roll of the school and under the direct control of the Principal, but no grant will be paid for them during the time they are in service. The Department will, however, permit you to replace them as grant earners from the pupils on the roll in excess of the number provided for, if there are such, or by new recruits.

The Department will expect you to see that only good homes in which to place these pupils are selected; homes where they will receive proper treatment and not be overworked, and the agreement with those engaging them should be that the Principal will have the authority to recall them to the school at any time, should circumstances in his opinion warrant such action.

They should be paid wages commensurate with their earning powers and the money earned should be funded by you for them, with the exception of an allowance for personal expenses. A separate account should be kept for each pupil, showing amounts earned and expended.

Rev. O. Charlebois,
Principal,
Duck Lake Boarding School,
Duck Lake, Sask.
A report showing the name of the pupil, the nature of the work, the name of the proposed employer, rate of wages and full particulars should be submitted to the Department for its approval before any agreement is closed, unless in cases where delay might be the means of losing a good situation. Under such circumstances the matter is left to your discretion, the report to follow in due course.

The Department trusts that under your care and guidance this experiment will prove eminently satisfactory, as, if so, steps will be taken to extend the system to other localities.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.
Duck Lake Boarding School,
Duck Lake, 1 December, -09.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo and in same time to inform you that today, December 1st, I have engaged two girls who are in their last school year. One is Flora Thomas, No. 45, who will work for Doctor Touchette in charge of this School and of the Reserves. He is a married man with young children. It is a good and honorable family where she will be as safe as in our School.

She will be employed to general house work such as cooking, washing, sewing &c. with the help of the mistress.

Her monthly wages will be $6.00 payable at the end of each month. The agreement is that I can recall her at any time should the circumstances necessitate her return.

The other girl is Eliza Eyshpaise, No. 0.45. She is hired by Mrs. Alphonse Archambault, a widow with three young children. She is Doctor Touchette's sister-in-law. Her moral character is irreproachable.

She is engaged under the same conditions as Flora Thomas.

I took the liberty of engaging these girls before sending you my report as these persons have been waiting long ago for servants and would have been annoyed had they not had them at the beginning of this month.

Trusting that will give you satisfaction,

I remain,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary of

Principal

Department of Ind. Affairs.

P.S. The term of the engagement of the two girls will be for six months about that time they will be discharged.

Rev Père,

Je suis satisfait de voir être bien Monsieur Comte Mercant. Mais je suis convaincu que pour le former il est bien à faire les voyages du voyageur et lui faudrait au moins une année et demi de plus pour pouvoir obtenir des résultats en avant de temps que lui conviendrait le plus grand avantage par l'ami.

Duck Lake Boarding School,
Duck Lake, 22 Feb. -10.

Dear Sir,

I was about to send you my report on the two girls, Flora Thomas and Eliza Eyhnpise, whom I placed out on service, when I receive your favor of the 15th inst., asking for the same.

I am pleased to say both girls have given satisfaction so far. Flora specially would deserve a first class mild certificate if she was not so slow and timid. That's the only reproach that can be given her. She received many complimentary mentions for her nice sewing. Her behaviour is perfect, and she likes her position well.

Eliza deserves about the same testimony, only she is much slower and more timid and this keeps her of being as agreeable to her mistress as her companion; but she is willing to work and she is obedient. She likes her position fairly well too, although she suffers sometimes when she does not succeed to be agreeable to her mistress on the points mentioned.

On Sundays the two girls come and have dinner at the school where they meet their former companions and teachers. We take the opportunity then of giving them some good advice, so they go back with better courage.

You see, so far our attempt has been quite a success, but to have it complete, I think, the idea suggested by the Dr. Touchette in his letter attached to this, is a very good one; that is, I shall should be allowed by the Department to keep them under my authority for at least another year. It will complete their formation in private housekeeping, and it would prevent them from going home where they get spoiled while waiting to get married.

Their parents will surely take them home as soon as they get their discharge, and that time is near at hand now as it is in April next.

So for their greater benefit I ask you to mind in my
control for one year more over these two girls and over two other ones, Josette Kamiskishaw No. 0.38 and Madeleine Amans No. 0.74 who have to be discharged also in April. I will also find a place for these two last mentioned and I promise to do my best to have a good result with them. My only aim is to protect our pupils against the influence of their old parents.

I hope you will grant me a favorable answer. In this case, please, notify the Agent of the same, so that he may be in position of certifying to the parents that my control is maintained over their children for another year.

I remain,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

Principal.

The Secretary,
Department,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

P.S.— I forgot to tell you that I have in fund $12.00 for Flor. Thomas and $10.50 for Elize Eymaule.

Dear Sir,

With the authority granted to me by your letter of March 2nd No.119695/1, I placed at service the two following pupils: Josette Kamiskish, No.0,38, and Madeleine Ananas, No.0,74.

The first one is at Mr. Gervais, one of the best families and farmers in Duck Lake. So far she has done very well. She is much appreciated for her knowledge of sewing and cutting dresses. Her wages are $5.00 per month to begin with. If she continue to give satisfaction her wages will be raised up to $6.00 per month.

The second girl is at Mr. Lamotheville, another good family and farmer. She has given satisfaction till now. Her mistress is very proud of her. She has the same wages and conditions as the above.

The two other girls, Flore Thomas and Elise Eyholtz, continue to please her employers and they are even much appreciated for their knowledge of general housekeeping as well as their ability in sewing, cutting and fitting all kinds of garments.

The trouble now is that their parents claim them and want them home. Because the usual time for their discharge has come, and they do not want to leave them any longer under my control and at service. What am I to do?... It would be a pity to send them home where they will find nearly nothing to do and where they will spoil themselves.

On the other hand it is hard for me to resist alone against their claims. Of course you give me full authority, but the parents do not believe it. They think that my object in keeping their children at service is my own interest I am seeking, and not theirs.

I wish you will tell me what you think the best to do. If you decide that I must keep them under my control, please send me a letter in which you will clearly oblige me (not only authorize) to keep them.
And also you will ask the Agent, Mr. Macarthur, to be kind enough to make the parents understand that I am forced by you to not let go their children. The Agent can help me very much were he willing.

In case you prefer I should give them their liberty to go home, you have only to let me know I will do it, although I will be very grieved because, I know, it will be a draw back for these girls.

I remain,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

The secretary of

the Depart. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of

No. At a meeting of the Indians of the Beardy's and Okemassis reserves, held here on the 20th instant, they requested me to write you protesting against their children being kept, after they are of age, at the Duck Lake boarding school. I explained to them the Principal's good intentions in so keeping them, but they claim that they can take just as good care of their own children as the Principal can, and that it was neither fair nor right to keep them against their own and their parents' wishes. They all object to children who are in their last year at school, being sent out to work, saying that they are not sent there to work for others, and that if they are through with school they should be allowed to return home.

I explained to them that the subject was one affecting the Department and the Principal, and with which I had nothing to do, but that I would forward their complaint.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 14, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo in which you state that the Indians of Beardys and Okemasis reserves have protested against the retention of their children after the age of eighteen years in the Duck Lake Boarding school and also against the girls being placed at service during the last year.

In reply I beg to say that this matter received careful consideration and the Department, in taking the action it did, was actuated only by a desire to promote the welfare of the pupils. The greatest care is exercised to see that they are placed in suitable homes where they will be well used and the money earned, with the exception of an allowance for personal expenses, is funded for them. The main object is to give these girls a few months' training in the houses of white people under conditions more nearly resembling those under which they will have to work in their own homes in so far as management, etc., is concerned.

The Department has no wish to carry out this policy in opposition to the wishes of the parents. It is not, however, a new departure and good results have been obtained in the past.

Kindly lay before the Indians the attitude of

J. Macarthur, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.
of the Department, at the same time assuring them of the good wishes for the welfare of their children and expressing the hope that they will concur in the action taken, at least till such time as the experiment has been given a fair trial under the supervision of Father Charlebois.

Should the course of training not prove agreeable to the pupils and beneficial to the extent expected and should the Indians at a later time reasonably object their wishes will be respected.

The Department hopes that your influence with them will overcome their present objection and that the results will speak for themselves.

Your obedient servant,

secretary.
