June 28, 1910.

Referring to your letter of 14th instant,

No. I9695/I, I have the honour to inform you that I have explained to the parents of those girls who are working out, as carefully and plainly as I could, the object desired to be obtained; that all is being done in the one desire of assisting the girls; but I have totally failed to get the parents in any way to consent or approve of them working out. I have hitherto refrained from expressing my personal opinion on the subject, either to the Indians or to the Department, but being on the spot, it is probably my duty now to do so. It may be taken as beside the question that Principal Charlebois is acting entirely in what he believes to be the very best interests of the girls; and the Principal is an able and earnest man. It should not be forgotten that these girls have been at school for 12 years; they know how, and can do household work just as good as white girls of their age; they can wash and iron, make or repair clothing. Indeed, in all this, as far as knowledge of the work, they are ahead of the average white girl. Now, this being so, what further object can be gained by placing them with strangers to work for a wage against their willing

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6305, file 652-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
willing consent? To my mind it is akin to slavery.

If twelve years of careful training has failed to make them competent to take up their life's work, a few months of compelled service will not mend matters. The principal is looking for results which will hardly be visible before another generation—Just yesterday I was round the Beardy's reserve with Farmer McCloy; as we passed an Indian's tent I pointed out to the Farmer a young woman who had been educated at the Duck Lake boarding school; why, said the Farmer, she looks as if she has not washed for a week. A little later we passed another ex-pupil riding in a wagon with her husband; she had a shawl over her head, and was just as dirty and untidy as the other. Now both of these young people can do any household work as well as any white girl; more than that, they can take a piece of dress stuff, cut it out, make and fit a dress just as good as a dress-maker. In fact, they are exceptionally clever girls. Yet, after all this training, after twelve years of a life of cleanliness and comfort, they return to the life of their parents without the least desire to improve their surroundings. Now, there are occasionally exceptions, but the above is the general rule. I do not wish to convey the impression that all the labor, time and money has been wasted. On the contrary, it is the necessary foundation for the future, but to expect that in one generation you can turn this class of girl into anything approaching a white girl is as absurd as to expect to make a "silk purse out of a sow's lug". Those girls, who have to some extent made good are, as a rule, only nominally Indian, having far more white than Indian blood in them.

Two of the Indians have specially asked me to again write the Department regarding their daughters, One,
Sandy Thomas, says he wants his girl at home, she has been away twelve years. He had in the past other two girls at this school, both of whom, while there, became mothers. He does not want this to happen to the third, and claims that he is just as able to look after her as the Principal is, and that it is altogether wrong to keep the girl away from him.

Then Eyahpaise wants his girl home as her mother is a helpless invalid, being bed-ridden for years. While this girl will not be 18 until November, she is working out. That being so, she should be at home taking care of her mother.

I have written at this length, not from any desire to interfere with the work, but because of the constant complaints of the parents, that the Department should know my opinion and because I sympathize with the girls and their parents.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 7, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you state that you have been unable to obtain the approval of the Indian parents of the action of the Principal of the Duck Lake Boarding School in placing their girls at service during their last year at school.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the attitude of the Indians and your remarks on the subject, the Principal has been instructed to recall these girls from service and grant the final discharge of those who have reached the age of eighteen years.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

J. Macarthur, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.
Ottawa, July 7, 1910.

Rev. Sir,

Protests have been received from the parents of the Indian girls placed at service by you within the past year with the concurrence of the Department. In May, last, when the first communication was received, a letter of explanation was written in which the motives actuating you and the officers of the Department were fully dealt with, and it was hoped that no further objection by the parents would be forthcoming, but neither their consent to nor approval of the continuance of the system can be had.

In view of the attitude of the Indians of your district generally towards residential schools it is not considered politic to place their girls in service against their wishes, nor to retain them in the school beyond the age of 16 years, unless there are in any particular case exceptional circumstances which would warrant such action.

The greatest care must be taken not to antagonize the Indians, as all efforts to recruit will prove futile. For this and the further reason that they are quite within their rights in raising the objections it has been decided to recall to the school those girls who have not reached the age of 16 and grant the final discharge of those who have attained that age. To those to be discharged honourable

Rev. O. Charlebois,

certificates will be granted, if you so recommend.

Be good enough to advise the Department of the actions taken by you.

This is to inform you that the Rev. O. Charlebois, Principal of the Duck Lake Boarding School, has recently been elected Bishop, and will be charged by the mission of Terratin.

I have therefore the pleasure of requesting you to accept the Rev. V. Gabillon, C.M.S., as successor to the Rev. O. Charlebois. The new Principal can speak the English and Cree languages fairly well, and I am positive that he will follow in the footsteps of his predecessor, and will take the same interest in the prosperity of that Institution of which the Government has every reason to be proud.

Ottawa, October 5, 1910.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 29th ultimo advising the Department of the resignation of Rev. Father Charlebois as Principal of the Duck Lake Boarding School and nominating for the position Rev. V. Gabillon.

In reply I beg to say that the appointment of Rev. Father Gabillon is approved.

The Department, while pleased to learn of the appointment of Father Charlebois as Bishop, regrets his removal from the principalship of the school, where he has attained a large measure of success. It is sincerely hoped that the standard of the school will be maintained and with this object in view I have to ask Your Lordship to be good enough to impress upon the new Principal the necessity of devoting his best energies to the work, so that future reports on this institution will show continued advancement.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

VERY POOR COPY
Sir,

Referring to your letter of

In connection with the enclosed report on the Duck Lake Boarding School, I have the honour to inform you that the death rate in this school is again returning to its high mark, two of the inmates having died during the year and two others dying. For a time after the introduction of the steam heating and the excellent ventilating system provided by the Department the death rate was low, and I was in hopes that it would remain permanently so. Everything that can be done is done to keep the scholars of this school in health, but in spite of all, the above is the result. I have always been of the opinion that the building was not suitable for the purpose as it has altogether too many dark corners and a lack of light. I understand that Tuberculosis Bacilli dies in a very short time if exposed to sunlight, but will live on indefinitely if kept in the dark. It may be thought that the children catch the disease while visiting their parents, but it must be remembered that they only visit for a month of the year and that too in the summer, when they spend their time on the open prairie and sleep in tents. Eleven months of the year is spent at school, and no one responsible can get beyond the sad fact that those children catch the disease while at school.

To find how our day schools compared with this report on the

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
the Duck Lake Boarding school, I have looked back over the past 10 years with the following result, viz.- In 1900 there were 19 children from the One Arrow's Reserve at the Duck Lake Boarding school. Of these, 10 are living today and 9 are dead. Of 23 children on the roll of the LaCorne north school in 1900, 17 are alive today and 5 are dead; and of 15 on the roll of the La Corne south school in October 1903, 14 are today living and one is dead. While, in the latter case, the pleasing result may not be altogether due to the teacher, no doubt her motherly care materially helped to procure the result. It may be thought that the James Smith's people are, on the whole, more healthy than the One Arrow's people, but I find that during the past 10 years the average duration of life on the James Smith's was 25 years, while on the One Arrow's reserve it is a fraction over 27 years notwithstanding the heavy toll taken by the Duck Lake Boarding school.

I have written the above for various reasons, all of importance. The Department should realize that under present circumstances about one-half of the children who are sent to the Duck Lake Boarding school die before the age of 18, or very shortly afterwards, and that because they are kept in a building whose every seam and crevice is, doubtless, burdened with Tuberculosis Bacilli.

A further expenditure to provide waterworks is, I understand, under consideration. Before being sanctioned, a thorough examination of the building should be made.

I have also made the report in the interests of the parents of both, Beardy's and One Arrow's reserves. They have asked for day-schools, and while they cannot very well get up and tell you just why, I know it is because so many of their children die at the Boarding school, or come home from the Boarding school to die.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Sir,

The Department has received a letter from Indian Agent Macarthur, dated Dec. 27th., a copy of which is enclosed herewith. The question dealt with in this letter is worthy of serious consideration and I have to request that you will give the matter your personal attention. It is possible that one cause which increases the death rate at this school is the lack of care in examining prospective pupils. If the medical attendant does not exercise great care and is not possessed of considerable experience in detecting the presence of tuberculosis, it may be quite possible that he is passing pupils who could not possibly be admitted under the restrictions laid down by the admission forms.

The impression exists that the dormitories and school-rooms of the Duck Lake school are properly lighted. The dark corners and lack of light which Mr. Macarthur refers to may be in other parts of the building. The outside closets which are certainly most unsanitary, should be replaced by a more modern system and that end a Civil Engineer presented a plan for improvements, but he omitted to make profile sketches so that it was impossible to say whether the fall from the house to the proposed cess pools was sufficient. The school authorities have under consideration the advisability of purchasing the property, in which case they would under the new arrangement be expected to provide sufficient space.

Would you kindly report fully on Mr. Macarthur's letter.

Referring to your letter of the 12th inst., enclosing copy of a letter from Agent Macarthur dealing with sanitary matters in connection with the Duck Lake boarding school, and requiring a report on the conditions referred to therein, I have the honour to state that on the 16th inst. accompanied by Mr. Macarthur I visited the school and consulted with the reverend Principal and the Sister Superior, and inquired into all matters affecting the health of the pupils, and now beg to report.

Agent's statement.

1. The statement made by the Agent regarding the death rate among pupils and ex-pupils of the school for the past ten years is based on accurate information gathered from the certified quarterly returns of the school.

Unsanitary conditions.

2. The conditions that might act as a protection for germs, and thus tend to the propagation of disease, are as follows:

(a) The basement, with clay walls and floors, the latter deep with dust, in which the dried sputa of pupils engaged there from time to time at various kind of work must accumulate not only for days but for weeks and months, as there is simply no way of cleaning the place except by a process of further

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
excavation. Sufficient quantities of fresh air find access to this basement, but no light whatever.

(b) Floors.

(b) The floors throughout the building are of B.C. fir or spruce. In some parts they were originally well laid, in others not so well; but in every part there are the usual cracks between the boards, where germs are liable, indeed certain, to be harbored.

(c) Walls.

(c) The walls throughout are of plaster, either painted or kalsomined; but in the older portions of the building there are numerous small cracks in the plaster, in which dust and germs are liable to collect.

(d) Lighting.

(d) There are a few passages and rooms on the ground floor and up-stairs that are but poorly lighted. The dining-room, which was at one time decidedly dim, is still only moderately well lighted, having but four medium sized windows all facing toward the east and screened in some measure by adjacent buildings. These windows receive but a very limited share of the direct rays of the sun. On dull days the room is dimly lighted, while on bright days there is all the light that the eye requires.

Between the dining room and the senior class-room there is a passage between 30 and 40 feet long which is almost without light.

The two hospital rooms, which are of the dimensions of large bed-rooms, have but one window each, and are not well suited in this respect for their purpose, but are the best the building in its present arrangement affords.

The clothing rooms, which are approximately 14 x 28 feet, have but one window each and are not sufficiently well lighted.

The class-rooms are each 24 x 35 feet and have four windows each, two on each side of the room.
(e) Closets.

The outside closets, which on account of their unavoidable proximity to the school and for other reasons are a serious menace to the health of the pupils.

Remedies suggested.

3. In order to remedy as far as possible the conditions above described I would make the following suggestions:

(a) Basement.

There is a shallow stone foundation under the entire building. A basement the full dimensions of the building is not required; but I would recommend that further excavation be made under the central portion of the building, so as to make the basement the full width of the building, 40 feet, and about 120 feet in length; and that the present surface foundation be under-built with stone or concrete to the full depth of the cellar. This basement should at the same time be deepened about three feet, as it was found necessary to sink the steam boilers nearly that depth when installing the present heating plant, in consequence of which they are very inconveniently situated in a hole. A cement floor would, of course, be an indispensable part of the improvements. Light sufficient for working requirements could at the same time be provided.

(b) Floors, etc.

For the disinfection of the floors, baseboards, wainscots, and other woodwork, a mixture should be frequently be employed consisting of -

1 part bichloride of mercury,
2 parts muriate of ammonia, and
500 parts water.

Painted plaster might be washed with a dilution of formalin; and the same disinfectant might be mixed with kalsomine in cleansing other portions of the walls.
(c) Cracks in the plaster should in connection with the process of disinfection be effectually closed with plaster of Paris or other suitable material.

(d) Lighting.

An additional window should be inserted in each of the sick rooms and clothing rooms. An additional window might with advantage be inserted in each of the class-rooms on the left of the pupils, from which side light should mainly be admitted to a school-room.

A limited provision of borrowed light only could be obtained for the dark passage between the dining room and class-room. This might be a convenience but would be of no value for purposes of disinfection.

(e) Waterworks.

The installation of a system of waterworks, with provision for the disposal of sewage, would be a sanitary measure of the very highest importance. The matter is one that requires to be gone into thoroughly by an expert. One of the first difficulties that requires to be solved is the source of the water supply. I have an impression that a well dug to a depth of about 120 feet and with a diameter of 8 feet would afford the requisite supply; and the water would be suitable for all purposes except those of the laundry, for which it is very poorly adapted. Of other sources the nearest is Duck Lake, a shallow lake, with water of inferior quality.

As for the disposal of sewage, if ordinary cesspools were employed they would require to be situated at some distance from the school and the wells, and hence at considerable depth in order to give the necessary fall, as the land is perfectly level; while if septic tanks were installed they could with safety be located somewhat nearer.

In connection with the question of a water supply I may say that a soft water cistern of a capacity of 500 barrels was constructed several years ago. This
is of great value; but it does not store half the available supply of rain water from the roofs of the main buildings, and its contents are insufficient for laundry use alone. All other water to be obtained here is extremely hard; and I would recommend that in connection with improvements to the basement four galvanized iron cisterns of large capacity, say 150 bbls. each, be provided for the storing of a further supply of soft water.

General character of building.

4. The building is a plain and inexpensive one, but not on the whole an unsanitary structure, (apart from the basement and the want of waterworks), except for the fact that it has now for 16 or 17 years been occupied by pupils a number of whom are known to have suffered for months from tuberculosis.

Heating and ventilation.

5. The improved system of heating and the system of ventilation installed at the same time, two years ago, have given complete satisfaction. The weather was severe at the time of my visit; but the building was comfortable throughout; and the air was everywhere fresh and free from odor.

Condition of dormitories.

6. The dormitories, which are the most important rooms of the institution in regard to the health of the pupils, are particularly free from objection. They are large and airy, and free from nooks and irregular walls. They have abundance of light, from the east and west sides, which reaches every part. The walls and floors are in good condition; the rooms are sufficiently furnished, but there is not a superfluous article to be seen; and everything is clean according to every visual test.

General condition.

7. So far as the efforts of the staff can avail evidently nothing more could be done in the interest of the health and well-being of the pupils. The visit of Mr. Macarthur and myself was made without the
slightest previous intimation, and conditions throughout the building were undoubtedly normal. The most perfect state of order and cleanliness prevailed everywhere. All soiled clothing was at the laundry; clothes that required repairs was in the sewing room; and all other clothing was in perfect order on the shelves of the clothing rooms. In the dining room after each meal when the dishes are washed the tables are set for the next meal, and then each table is spread over with a cover of lawn, which protects the dishes from flies in summer and from dust at all times.

Medical examination.

8. I was not able to see Dr. Touchette; but his attendance at the school is entirely satisfactory to the principal and to the staff. I am also informed by the Sister Superior that his examination of pupils at admission is made with evident thoroughness and care.

Dr. Reid, of Prince Albert, and other physicians inform me that tubercular disease would be very slightly developed indeed if it were impossible to discover it by a careful examination of the lungs, the glands of the neck and chest, and the bones and muscles of the limbs. They agree with the suggestion that some help might be obtained in connection with the examination of pupils for admission by an inquiry into the health record of their parents and other near relations. There is no doubt that with the aid of information of this nature, which the Agent would always be able to furnish or obtain, some pupils of this and other schools would have been excluded who were admitted and died, and who during the progress of the disease no doubt helped to spread infection in the school. Such pupils may not have actually been suffering from the disease when admitted,
but the tendency to it was too strong.

Calisthenics, etc. 9. Calisthenics and breathing exercises are practised regularly under the direction of one of the sisters who has made a study of these for the purpose. An evidence of the attention given to the matter was furnished in a series of exercises performed by the boys under the leadership of one of their own number, and a similar performance by the girls under the guidance of the Sister.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
To be placed on file 109-1-1
Jan. 1912
Though the Duck Lake Boarding School Buildings appear to be in an unsanitary condition, yet it is doubtful whether this defect is the chief cause of the excessive mortality at the school. The present medical attendant of the institution may be careful in his examination of candidates for admission as pupils; but if I remember rightly there have been several changes in that officer for the school since it was opened, some of whom, I fear, were not very careful in this matter. In the early days, too, when the school was in process of organization, the church authorities were very eager in canvassing for recruits, and the Indian parents more readily consented to permit their delicate children to go to the Boarding school than the stronger ones, whom they wished to retain for home work.

Further, in regard to the buildings, I do not think a few dark corners and passages, which are only momentarily occupied, are the real danger to the health of the pupils. The dormitories appear to be well lighted and ventilated; and the class-rooms also seem to be fairly satisfactory. The hospital-rooms, however, are insufficiently lighted and ventilated, and should as soon as possible be exchanged for more suitable rooms. The condition of the basement is an illustration of the unwise method school authorities usually adopted in former years of starting to build a school without proper plans. Want of funds in some cases may have led...
led to laying insecure foundations and providing a suitable basement, a neglect which is difficult to remedy when later additions and improvements are made to the building.

But the principal cause of the unsanitary condition of the school is doubtless the want of a sufficient supply of pure water and a proper disposal of the sewage. Outside closets near the schools are a great nuisance and should be abolished as soon as possible. But in providing for the disposal of the sewage I would not discharge it into ordinary cess pools. They are now almost everywhere discarded as they saturate the earth at a depth where there is no aeration and thus often infect wells though not in their immediate vicinity. The conditions at the Duck Lake School are pretty much the same as those at the Elkhorn Industrial School, and the system of sewage disposal which is to be adopted at the latter ought to be suitable for the former school.

Dear Sir,

In addition to the last letter about the day school at the farm around Duck Lake, I believe it is proper and safer to name the farm from which we intend to recruit children for our Boarding School. Plan as: Ora Amos, Beatty, Markay Lake and the other farms depending from the Duck Lake and Carlton Agencies.

As we have a mission at Beaver Lake, we should be given leave to recruit from this Mission also.

Before undertaking the improvements on our school at Duck Lake I will wait your answer about the day school, and your promise to give instructions to your agents that they should come the following fall, the Boarding School is sufficient for their needs. Otherwise it would be useless to incur such heavy expenses with the perspective that in a few years our school would have to be closed for lack of pupils.

Dear Sir,

In the conversation I had with Mr. F. Oliver just before going to your office, I drew his attention to the fact that the Indians around the Boarding School have made a demand on the Department to establish Day schools on their reserve, as well as Watotoe's and other small reserves. I told the Minister that if these schools were opened, it was useless to try to maintain the Boarding School, as the Indians would much better like to send their children to the Day school than to the Boarding School. I expressed also my opinion based on experience at Saddle Lake and other reserves that Day schools as a rule did not give any good results, and the Honorable Secretary answered me that he was more than myself wanted Day schools on the above mentioned reserves. Last week I heard at Dewar Falls that the Indian Agent was keeping the Indians under the impression that they could or could get Day schools if they wanted them, and as an immediate result of such conduct, the Indians refuse to send their children to the Boarding School where we have not just at present the full number of pupils. Will you please give instructions to your Agent at Dewar Falls, that we may know before making expensive improvements in the school, that we are sure of getting pupils for the same.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H. Grayling

I am sorry to have to say that the talk about day schools on the reserve is
weeping on as if there was no promise from the Dept., that no such school should
be opened on the reserve near the school. In my interview with the Honorable
G. Oliver, he assured me that the Dept. not only would not from the establishing
of day schools on the near reserve, but that on the contrary they would stimulate the
Indians from asking for them. I do not wish to blame any one, but I am afraid
that same way or other the Indians are under the impression that the Dept. would be
glad to grant their request for such schools. I had better say that the im-
pression produced in some way on the Indians is that the Dept. would be
glad if the Indians could insist on their having day schools on their reserve.
You will agree with me that such a state of things is not very encouraging
for us. I must return before long to Quick Falls, and may have better
news to give you back in the mean time. I confess that I do not know what
to think and consequently I am not over anxious now to start on a big
undertaking that may be unduly valuable before many years.

I have the honor to be

Edmonton, Alta., June 13th, 1901

Mrs. Duncan,
Indian Department,
Ottawa

Sir,

Immediately after my return from Ottawa, I went to the Blackfoot Indian School and called in a civil engineer from Prince Albert to have his opinion about the water to be installed in order to come up to the requirements of the Depot. After a careful survey made in my presence, Mr. Cole declared that it would be impossible to establish in the school a good system of water. The fall was too small and the pipe lines could not be built on account of the water coming from every side. In rainy seasons the whole flat south-west of the school is completely flooded. I asked this engineer to write a full report of his work and of his opinion; but so far I have not been able to obtain it. We wrote to him, tried to see him, but he is always too busy and cannot make his report. I gave orders to have at least an artesian well bored near the school, but at the time of my last visit last week Brother Babillon had not found in Prince Albert, Norburn and other places along the line, a man willing to undertake this work. I hope that this difficulty will be overcome before long, but I do not know what to do about the water works and sewer system. The Rev. Sister Superior told me last week she would prepare a plan of water closets that would remove the obnoxious state of the present state of things. I hope she will be able to do so as I hate any the present system.

Do you remember the promise to send me a copy of Mr. Christie's report? I do not remember clearly enough all of his recommendations, and so I should feel any such obligation to you if you would kindly send me a copy of this report.

I have ordered the windows in the infirmary which were recommended by the Inspector, to be opened promptly.

The question of opening a day school on One Arrows Reserve has been held in abeyance.

I have lately received from Pierre Albert an agreement in duplicate for the maintenance and management of the Duck Lake Boarding School. As these documents are addressed and made in the name of the Right Reverend Albert Pascal Bishop of Pierre Albert, I cannot sign them. It was well understood between the then Minister of the Division, the Honorable T. Oliver, and Mr. D. Scott, that the school was under the sole management of the Oblate Fathers, and it is by the head of this Order that I purchased the site of the school and became the owner of all that pertains to said school. The agreement here should be altered so that I may sign it on the representation of the Oblate Fathers.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 9th instant I beg to enclose herewith an agreement, in duplicate, between His Majesty the King, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and Les Reverends Peres Oblate de Marie Immaculée des Territoires du Nord Ouest, for the future maintenance and management of the Duck Lake Boarding school. I have to request that you will be good enough, as the representative of the Oblate Fathers, to sign this document in the presence of a subscribing witness and to affix the official seal of the order thereto and to return same to the Department at your earliest convenience.

On the return of these documents, the signature of the Deputy Superintendent General will be affixed and a copy will then be sent you. I may inform you that the per capita grant, at the increased rate of $125.00 for each of one hundred pupils has been paid this school from the 1st April, last.

This Agreement made this Seventeenth day of January, one thousand nine hundred and Twelve, by and between His Majesty The King, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada, of the first part, (hereinafter called the 'Superintendent General') and Les Reverends Pères Oblats de Marie Immaculée des Territoires du Nord Ouest, of the second part, (hereinafter called the... Management).

WITNESSETH that the said parties have covenanted and agreed, and by these presents do covenant and agree, to and with each other as follows:

1. The... Management... for and in consideration of the compensation hereinafter named agree:

   1. To support, maintain and educate, in a manner satisfactory to the Superintendent General, at the Boarding School at Duck Lake, in the Province of Saskatchewan, Canada, known as The Duck Lake Boarding School, not more than One Hundred (100) Indian pupils, and not to allow more than an excess of one pupil for every twenty or fraction of twenty of the above number of pupils to remain in the said school at any one time.

   2. (a) That no child shall be admitted to the said school who is under seven years of age.

      (b) That no child shall be allowed to remain in the said school who is over eighteen years of age unless by special permission of the Superintendent General.

3. That no child shall be admitted to the school by the... Management... until, where practicable, a physician, to be named by the Superintendent General, has reported that the child is in good health and suitable as an inmate of said school, and the Superintendent General has authorized the acceptance of such child.

4. (a) That no child shall be admitted to the said school without the special authority of the Superintendent General unless he or she is the child of a duly enrolled member of... A Recognized... Band of Indians of the Duck Lake or Carlton Agencies... now under the supervision of J. Macarthur and T. Borthwick, Indian Agents, respectively.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6505, file 652-1, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
(b) That no Half-breed child shall be admitted to the said school unless Indian children cannot be obtained to complete the number authorized by Article I, Sec. 1, and Sec. 4 (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II, Sec. 1 of this agreement nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever.

5. That no child who has been in attendance at any other boarding school during the twelve months preceding the date of the application for admission to the said school, though otherwise eligible, shall be admitted to the said school without special authority from the Superintendent General.

6. That the said school shall be conducted under such regulations as may from time to time be approved of by His Excellency the Governor General in Council.

7. To provide for the said school such sufficient number of teachers, officers and employees as may in the opinion of the Superintendent General be necessary for its satisfactory conduct and management.

8. Not to employ except on probation for a period not exceeding six months at said school any teacher or instructor until evidence satisfactory to the Superintendent General has been submitted to him that such teacher or instructor is able to converse with the pupils under his charge in English and is able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly and possesses such other qualifications as in the opinion of the Superintendent General may be necessary.

9. To provide at the said school teachers and officers qualified to give the pupils religious instruction at proper times; to instruct the male pupils of the said school in gardening, farming, and care of stock, or such other industries as are suitable to their local requirements; to instruct the female pupils in cooking, laundry work, needlework, general housewifery and dairy work, where such dairy work can be carried on; to teach all the pupils in the ordinary branches of an English education; to teach calisthenics, physical drill and fire drill; to teach the effects of alcoholic drinks and narcotics on the human system, and how to live in a healthy manner; to instruct the older advanced pupils in the duties and privileges of British citizenship, explaining to them the fundamental principles of the government of Canada, and training them in such knowledge and appreciation of Canada as will inspire them with respect and affection for the country and its laws.

10. To supply the pupils of the said school to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General with suitable and sufficient clothing, subsistence, lodging accommodations, and all other articles necessary to their personal comfort and safety; also to supply the said school with mechanical tools, seeds and all other articles and equipment necessary for its proper conduct except as hereinafter otherwise provided.

11. To keep the pupils clean and free from vermin both in their clothes and persons.

12. To keep and maintain the school buildings and premises, to supply proper sanitation and sanitary appliances, and to keep the buildings free from flies, insects and vermin.
13. To maintain the buildings at the said school and the school premises when they are the property of the Management in good condition and repair, the whole to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General.

14. To observe appropriately the King's Birthday, Victoria Day, Dominion Day and Thanksgiving Day at the said school.

15. To have school-room exercises on five and industrial exercises on six days in each week, legal holidays excepted; and excepting also a vacation not to exceed one month between the first day of July and the first day of October in each year, unless some other course is expressly sanctioned by the Superintendent General. During the vacation the pupils may, in the discretion of the Management, be permitted to visit their homes, but the Superintendent General will not pay any part of the cost of transportation either going or returning.

16. To make to the Superintendent General such reports upon the said school as he may from time to time require.

17. To permit the Superintendent General and any person or persons named by him for that purpose to inspect the said school, school buildings and premises, and to afford the Superintendent General and such person or persons every facility for making such inspection thorough and complete.

18. To make any change or alteration in the school building or premises or in the management or control of the said school rendered necessary to comply with the intent and spirit of the agreement, and to remove for cause from the said school any teacher, officer, employee or pupil when required so to do by the Superintendent General.

19. Not to assign this contract or any interest therein without first obtaining the written consent of the Superintendent General.

II. The Superintendent General, in consideration of the faithful performance by the Management of the above covenants and stipulations, agrees:

1. To pay the Management at the rate of One Hundred and Twenty-five Dollars ($125.) per annum for each pupil, but the number of pupils so to be paid for shall not exceed One Hundred (100) in accordance with the restrictions hereinbefore set out; the payments shall be made quarterly and each quarterly payment shall be computed on the average attendance of each pupil; provided, however, that the said grant shall be allowed and paid during the vacation; but no payments will be made until returns have been received by the Superintendent General duly certified by the Indian Agent in charge of the Duck Lake Agency that the said school has been maintained and managed according to the true intent and meaning of this contract.

2. To provide the pupils of the said school with medicines, school-books, stationery and school appliances.
3. To maintain the buildings at the said school and the school premises, when they are the property of the Government, in good condition and repair, and provide for proper sanitation and sanitary appliances.

III. The Superintendent General shall have the right to cancel and rescind this contract if in his opinion the Management has failed to comply with any of the covenants and stipulations of this contract by giving six months' notice in writing to the Management and such notice shall be sufficiently served by sending it by registered mail addressed to the Les Reverends Peres Oblats de Marie Immaculee des Territoires du Nord Ouest at Edmonton, Alberta.

IV. Pursuant to the statute in that behalf, it is hereby expressly agreed that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall have any share or part in this agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

V. Should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment by the Superintendent General of the grant for each pupil in the said school hereinbefore provided for or towards payment of anything to be supplied, provided or done by the Superintendent General under this contract, be at any time expended during the continuance of this contract, the Superintendent General may give the Management notice to that effect, and thereafter the Management shall not be entitled to any payment under this contract, and the Superintendent General and His Majesty shall not be liable to supply, provide or do anything under this contract for which the expenditure of money may be necessary, until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf, and in no event shall the Management have, make or prefer any claim against the Superintendent General or His Majesty for any damages or compensation.

VI. In this contract the word Management shall mean and include the Les Reverends Peres Oblats de Marie Immaculee des Territoires du Nord Ouest and their successors and assigns; and the words 'Superintendent General' shall mean the Superintendent General or acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs for the time being; and the words 'His Majesty' include His Majesty's heirs and successors.

VII. This contract, unless rescinded by the Superintendent General under the provisions hereinbefore mentioned, shall continue in force for a term of
Five years to be computed from the first day of April, A.D., 1911.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the undersigned have hereunto subscribed their names and affixed their seals the day and year hereinbefore written.

WITNESS:

For the party of the First Part.

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

For the party of the Second Part.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith my report of a visit to the Duck Lake Boarding school.

In connection with the school, I beg to say the demand for admission exceeds the number discharged, which means that before long it will be necessary to refuse admission in order not to exceed the number of grant earning pupils allowed.

After examining the building, not the slightest doubt have I, that the number of pupils allowed could be increased by ten or fifteen.

The class rooms, dining room, recreation rooms are quite large, and the dormitories, both boys and girls, could easily accommodate eight or ten more without overcrowding, whatever. The ventilation system in these dormitories is very good, and they are very well lighted by a large number of windows.

I would recommend that the number of pupils in this school be increased.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Schmidt of Duck Lake in his report on the Duck Lake Boarding School states that the applications for admission to this school are far in excess of the number discharged and that, as they have now over the number of pupils allowed them, they are obliged to refuse applications, although they have accommodation for ten or fifteen additional pupils.

There are 104 pupils on the roll and Mr. Inspector Chisholm, who inspected this school on the 9th and 10th instant, reports that there are several children under the age of seven years who are resident in the school and attending classes, but who are not as yet grant earners. In speaking of the accommodation Mr. Chisholm states that the dormitories afford between 580 and 600 cubic feet of air space for each occupant and that the class-rooms and dining-room are of correspondingly liberal dimensions. Mr. Chisholm states that the large attendance from some of the reserves, viz., Beardy's, Petaquakay's and One Arrows, is due to the fact that the population of these bands is made up to a considerable
siderable extent of ex-pupils of this and other residential schools and the parents who are themselves ex-pupils are so anxious to have their children enrolled that they bring them themselves to the Principal as they soon as they are eligible for admission. The school according to Mr. Chisholm's report is doing excellent work and, as they have accommodation for thirty pupils more according to Mr. Chisholm's figures, I think the Department would be quite justified in allowing them to take in twenty or twenty-five additional pupils. Mr. Chisholm states that the revenue of the school for the current year will be about $4,000 below that of the proceeding year through the failure of last year's crops.

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 4, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant reporting that you visited the Duck Lake Boarding School and found that there is ample accommodation for ten or fifteen more pupils and recommending that the number of grant earners be increased.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the fact that the school has accommodation for more pupils and of the favourable reports concerning the work done there, the Department has decided to allow them ten more pupils. This will bring the number of grant earners up to 110 and the increase will date from the first of January, 1915.

Your obedient servant,

Duck Lake, Sask.
Duck Lake Boarding School,
Sept. 5th, 1917.

To the Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir,

I am by duty bound to acquaint you, and through your mediation, the Department of Indian Affairs; of certain events that have transpired at our school. Accidents of the kind must be conveyed to your knowledge.

In the spring of 1916, a few boys planned the destruction of the house by fire. The seniors surmising the mischief, routed the culprits and the plot fell through.

In the Fall of the same year, 1916, some little fellows were found in the act of setting fires. They were severely punished. At that time I intended asking the Department that I claim today; but my health impaired forbade me the accomplishment of any strenuous work; in fact I had to absent myself from home to take the rest I needed so badly.

Behold! on the 28th of August at 2 O'Clock A.M., one of the staff was awakened by a crackling noise from the window. A light reflected on the church. In a moment, the alarm was given, the whole household including staff and children (106) was on foot and out of the building. We feared an explosion; the fire having been set under a window near the gas plant. The night before at about 8 O'Clock a boy had been seen lighting a match at the very spot. Caught in the act he blew on the match and probably thought it was out, but the fire had caught between the boards at the far paper making it's way slowly but surely until a light breeze fanned it to a flame.

The fire was mastered with a few pails of water. If we escaped the disaster it is through a pure providential protection of which we cannot be too thankful.

You realize, dear sir, the consequences; useless to comment.

Does it not seem just and even necessary that we should take means to protect ourselves against such attempts? It is impossible for us to proceed without the help and sanction of the Department.

This case, silent, would be tacitly encouraging the children in their criminal propensities and expose the lives of many. To send the guilty once back to the different reserves would be helping them to attain the goal; they would set fire at the first feeling of homesickness, sure beforehand of being expelled.

In my opinion such a child should be sent to jail or to a reformatory school. Such an example would prove beneficial to ourselves and other schools.

Among Indian children as among white there are characters who are not subdued, even by severe correction.

Of the boys who attempted to set the fires in 1916, one alone did not repent, and he is the most guilty. Today I dread him and it is for him alone that I would beg of the Department to decide his case and prosecute as soon as possible.

Respectfully yours,

(Signed) Rev. H. Delmas, Pte. C.M.I.,
Principal.

E. Pant Schmidt, Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith copy of a letter received from the Reverend H. Delmas, Principal of the Duck Lake Boarding school here, in which he reports upon a matter, which from a serious point of view, can hardly be surpassed.

The report is such that no comment from me is necessary. I trust however, that the Department will lose no time in advising me what steps to take in order to remove the danger that threatens the school, and the lives of those residing there.

Apparently the boy referred to in the last paragraph of the Principal's letter is undoubtedly in need of some punishment that would at least deter others from attempting to follow his example.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

REFERENCE MY LETTER TENTH INST RE FIRE DUCKLAKE BOARDING SCHOOL TWO COMPLICATIONS SINCE STRAW STACK BURNED ON THE ELEVENTH AND YESTERDAY FIRE DISCOVERED IN BOYES RECESATION ROOM UP-STAIRS LEADING TO DORMITORY AT FIVE PM FIRE EXTINGUISHED WITH SLIGHT DAMAGE

Ottawa, September 18, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant and your telegram of the 18th instant, in which you inform the Department that certain boys at the Duck Lake Boarding School have been attempting to set fire to the buildings.

Before advising you of what action to take in this matter, the Department would like to know the names and the ages of the boys to whom the principal refers in his letter. On receipt of this information the Department will be in a position to advise you what further action you should take in the matter.

When replying you might also give a brief report on the present conditions at this school and state if the discipline is all that it should be.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

C. P. Schmidt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.
Sr.,

Confirming my telegram of the 17th inst., which reads, "Reference my letter tenth inst. re. fire Duck Lake Boarding School. Two conflagrations since. Straw stack burnt on 11th, and yesterday fire discovered in boys recreation room under stairs leading to dormitory, at 5 p.m. Fire extinguished, small damage."

I have the honour to inform you that on Tuesday, the 11th inst., at 8 p.m., after the hired man and the boys had returned to the home from their evening chores, a straw stack situated about two or three hundred yards from the stables was seen to be burning. The staff turned out, and while unable to save the stack, kept the fire from spreading. The origin of the fire is unknown.

On Sunday, the 16th, at 5 p.m., one of the pupils heard what he thought was the crackling of a fire; he called other boys, and they discovered smoke coming from under the stairs in the boys recreation room. This stairs leads to the boys' Dormitory, this stairway is enclosed and the doors were locked.

The boys at once gave the alarm and the fire, which was yet small was extinguished. Some damage was done by chopping holes in the floors, and by the amount of water, two lines of hose having been turned on the fire.

The origin of this fire, is also a mystery. The Principal of the school and the staff are greatly distressed by these occurrences which in view of the report recently submitted, can hardly be wondered at.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ont.

EDMONTON, ALTA. September 17th, 1917

D. Scott Superintendent general
of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

Father Delmas principal of the Duck Lake Indian school has informed you of conduct of one of his pupils, who tried to set the school on fire. As it is not for the first time that this same boy has shown such bad feelings, do you not think that some severe measures should be taken in order to prevent the recurrence of such criminal tendencies. It seems to me that this boy should be sent to some reformatory or even to jail, as if he is allowed to go free again, others may be tempted to imitate him, and by so doing endanger the lives of all the inmates of the school. The Indians themselves would understand the necessity of such punishment, as they know that if not checked such actions might imperil the lives of all their children.

Believe me, dear Sir,

Yours respectfully

September 22nd, 1917.

Dear Father Grandin,

I have your letter of the 17th instant with reference to the Duck Lake school. I am really alarmed at the state of affairs at this institution and I think some drastic steps must be taken. The responsibility, however, lies with the school authorities and I have today wired the Indian agent as follows:

"Your letter tenth and wire twenty-first
no Departmental action called for, principal of
school should take action by laying information
against culprits before a magistrate for offense
under Criminal Code and have them prosecuted."

I think this is the best course of action to pursue as these boys must be given a salutary lesson.

Yours very truly,

Rev. H. Grandin, O.M.I.,
Edmonton, Alta.

Deputy Superintendent General.

In reply to your letter of the 18th ultimo No. 119695-1, asking me for the names and ages of the boys who attempted to run away from the Black Lake Boarding School, I have the honor to inform you that the boy referred to by the Principal in the last paragraph of his letter is Harry Paul, aged fourteen years, who comes from the Assiniboia Reserve, Manitoba Agency.

As regards conditions at the school or the state of discipline I do not think there is anything left to be desired. The children are well clothed, well fed and seem happy. The discipline is good, a better one will be hard to find, and those who work at the farm and stocks also will assure you of their fitness for work.

I will refer you to your telegram of the 2nd ultimo regarding the above case.

MEMO.

With further reference to your letters of Sept 18th, your telegram of Sept 22nd and your letter of Oct 16th last No 119695/1 regarding certain boys of the Black Lake Boarding School who attempted to set fire to the said school I have the honour to report that the Principal of the school laid information before a Justice of the Peace against one of the boys Harry Paul. This is the boy referred to in my letter of Oct 16th last. I have just returned from the school having been summoned there as a witness in this case. The case was tried at the school by Miss Ethel MacLachlan a Justice specially authorized by the Dominion and Provincial Authorities to deal with juvenile delinquents under the juvenile delinquents act.

Harry Paul pleaded guilty admitting he had made and put it in a hole in the wall where the fire was discovered. His reasons for doing
MEMO.

So sure that he was bad. However, the justice Miss Maclellan consented to have him in the care of the Superintendent of neglected children at Regina, for the purpose of placing him in the reformatory school at Waskesiu, for an unspecified term.

Should the boy conduct be good and the principal of that institution report on him favorably, I would recommend that after a few months, that he be taken from the reformatory and placed in the Winneboujou Industrial School in Alberta. Mr. Redman Principal of the Blackfoot Boarding School, has also given advice and has asked me to accompany James.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, in which you state that Harry Paul, who set fire to the Duck Lake Boarding School, was committed by the Justice, Miss MacLachlan, to the care of the Superintendent of Neglected Children at Regina for the purpose of placing him in the reformatory school at Wolseley for an unspecified term and recommend that, should the boy's conduct be good and the Principal of that institution report on him favourably, he be taken from the reformatory after a few months and placed in the St. Joseph's Industrial School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of your recommendation in this matter and he may be sent to the St. Joseph's Industrial School after a few months, if his conduct is good.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

G. F. Schmidt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.
Dear Sir,

During the time of war, the newspapers carry us from time to time, the wording of new regulations; such as those issued by the Canada Food Board, with regard the flour. Bread is the vital nourishment of our children; and of it, they have never been rationed. How can we and how must we submit to such law?

Then the Canada Registration Board demands that all people, male and female above the age of sixteen have to register! Our boys can help. According to the desire expressed by the Dept., in letter 150000/26, dated Feb. 19th, six four of our boys are working on the reserves and four are hired out to farmers. But our Indian girls are not fit to go out and work for white people. Experience has proved us that the Indian Girl when discharged from School, must be well taken care of and protected in a special manner until her marriage.

But could not our girls, those of the School as well as those discharged and living in the neighborhood, help to win the war? Could not the Depar send us wool with directions and they would knit socks, mitts, mufflers etc.? A slight compensation for the labor would be acceptable as a help towards the support of the School.

Of course the above is a mere suggestion but could it not be realized for the benefit of our Canada & comfort of our soldiers?

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6305, file 652-1, part 1)
Our girls would then be contributing their mite to win the war.

I respectfully submit the whole to your consideration.

An answer will greatly oblige me.

Very sincerely yours,

Vonda, Sask., 1918

Je suis informé qu'à l'école indienne de Quet Lalo Sask., l'école est sous le contrôle du Roi. Par conséquent, il n'est pas encore en mesure de faire une éducation. La direction de l'école nous assure que des ordres ont été reçus du département à cet effet.

Si cela est vrai, et si le fait que ce soit un établissement de protection contre les faits qui sont commis, une violation flagrante de l'acte d'union.

Cette école est subventionnée par le gouvernement fédéral. Nous avons une sollicité le gouvernement fédéral. Comme le français est bien encore langue officielle, il est donc cette circonstance, le même fait a été envoyé et parlé aux petits Indiens par l'anglais.

Nous espérons donc que des ordres seront rapidement donnés à cet effet, et s'il en était autrement, nous aurions à faire savoir à l'Assemblée de cette question par l'un de nos amis.

Espérant un accueil de réception, nous

Pour l'Association Interprovinciale

Raymond Perre - Secrétaire
Vonda, Sask., July 4, 1918.

The Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I am informed that at the Duck Lake Indian school, which school is under the control of the Rev. Father Delmas, not a word of French is taught to the Indian pupils.

The management of the school assures us that orders have been received from the Department to this effect.

If this is true, and it certainly seems to be so, we must protest against a circumstance which is above all a flagrant violation of the Act of Union. This school is subsidized by the Federal Government, and is only maintained thanks to the subsidies from the Federal Government, and as the French language is certainly still an official language, it has in this case the same right to be taught and spoken to the little Indians as English.

We hope that orders will rapidly be sent to this effect, and if it is otherwise, we would have to bring the matter before parliament through one of our friends.

Hoping for an acknowledgment, we remain

Yours truly,

L'Association Interprovinciale

Secrétaire département des Indiens

Ottawa

Monsieur,

Cette réponse du 27 juillet me disait qu'il n'était pas la politique du département de favoriser le français dans les écoles indiennes en dépit de la loi. Je ne peux pas être plus clair.

Le français est une langue officielle au même titre que l'anglais. L'argent qui est investi dans ces écoles indiennes devrait être utilisé pour la population canadienne française tout comme pour la population de langue anglaise. Cette politique serait une violation de la Constitution, en même temps qu'une violation du pacte de la Confédération.

Je vous demande donc au nom des associations canadiennes que je représente, de bien vouloir m'avoir que cette politique sera modifiée. Si nous faisons appel directement au Ministre de l'Intérieur lui-même, en même temps que je confirme le document officiel que je passe à M. Roy, je serais heureux de cette question.

Bien cordialement,

[Signature]

Sir,

Your reply of July 27th informing me that it is not the policy of the Department to have French taught in the Indian schools outside of Quebec, fills me with surprise and indignation.

French, from a federal point of view, is official just the same as English. The money that maintains these Indian schools comes from various taxes levied on the French-Canadian population just as much as on the English speaking population.

Your policy is, therefore, a flagrant injustice as well as being a violation of the agreement of Confederation.

I ask you, therefore, in the name of the French-Canadian Associations which I represent, to kindly advise me that this policy will be modified. If not, I shall have to appeal direct to the Minister of Interior himself, and further I shall give over the official documents that I possess to Mr. Rudolph Lemieux, who will bring this matter to the attention of Parliament.

Yours truly,

Raymond Denis.
Ottawa, August 29, 1918.

Dear Sir,

I have an interesting case to put before the Department today.

No. 121 Paul Arcand has been working for a certain A. Pajot, Carlton P.O., for the past three months. While hired there, a life insurance agent accompanied by A.B. Stewart M.D. (employed by the Department) presented themselves and succeeded in making said P. Arcand take a policy. The medical examination was passed and the papers were signed when A. Pajot came in. Without reflection he writes out a check for $64.90 to pay the premium, on the insurance policy of said P. Arcand.

This accomplished, A. Pajot arrives to demand gives me the receipt of the $64.90 as a proof of the salary paid to P. Arcand. I refused it. This was of doing things being contrary to the regulations laid down by Department and against our mutual agreement.

Therefore to conform myself to our regulations I exacted the full amount of the salary. Having worked 3 months and 4 days at $60.00 a month, I received of said Pajot $188.00 of which I gave to P. Arcand $133.10 keeping the $54.90 of the insurance policy. This was arranged amongst ourselves, the three interested.

Now I come to the point; this is what I would like to know.

Is this agreement re-insurance valid? The boy being an Indian and under 18 years.

Can the Department cancel such a contract to protect the boy and turn against the Insurance Company? The doctor knew perfectly well that the boy was still under the control of the Principal of the School.

To whom must I return the $54.90? To the boy or to A. Pajot?

Hoping to hear from you soon; I remain, Dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Three months ago I hired as farm hand a young Indian of the Duck Lake School. In the course of that time while I was out threshing he took an insurance policy for two thousand dollars and it was only when he was examined by the doctor that I knew it. He asked me to pay for the premium as I owed him some money.

I did not know just what to do nor did not like to stop him for I thought it would be a good way to make him save his money. The next day I went to Duck Lake and told Father Delmas about it and he told me that should not have paid that money without consulting him for and would not accept the receipt. I have settled Father Delmas since and paid the fifty four dollars over again.

Now I would ask only one question am I entitled to the money which I paid twice if I am Father Delmas said he would return it.

Yours very truly, Andre Pajo.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to Paul Arcand, a pupil of your school, who was working for a farmer by the name of Pajot, and note the circumstance with respect to the payment of the insurance premium and your inquiry regarding the same.

In reply I beg to say that if this boy had given a promissory note or other promise to the company to pay the amount of the premium it does not appear that the company could have enforced the payment, but the payment having been made it is not thought that it could be recovered from the company.

Since the boy's wages were, it appears, to be paid to you Mr. Pajot should not have paid the insurance premium without your consent, and you were quite within your rights in insisting on the payment of the wages in full. However, Mr. Pajot appears to have made this payment on the boy's request and in good faith and it hardly seems fair that he should lose this amount. This insurance ensues to the benefit of the boy and as the premium was paid at his request it seems to the Department that the said sum should properly be repaid to Mr. Pajot.

A copy of this letter has been sent to Mr. Pajot in reply to one received from him.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. H. Delmas, O.M.I.,
Principal of the Duck Lake Boarding School,
Duck Lake,
Sask.

ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL.

Duck Lake,
Sask., Sept. 23rd, 1921.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir,

I went to Regina last week to consult you concerning Duck Lake Boarding School. Unfortunately you were away and today I beg leave to state in writing the purpose of my visit.

The need of larger and more up-to-date buildings is well known to you personally, and to every officer of the Indian Department who has visited the school. During your first visit to the school three years ago you were struck by the dilapidated condition of the school.

We thought the time inopportune to ask the Department for new buildings because labor was scarce, the cost of building exorbitant, and the attention and efforts of the Government were absorbed by the all important problems of the war.

Now that conditions are normal again, labour plentiful and price of building has considerably decreased, the Very Rev. Fr. Grandin, President of the Order of the Oblate Fathers, the Directors of the School, has petitioned the Department for new buildings.

To justify our request we submit to your consideration the following facts -

1. The reports of the Inspectors show that since its erection in 1894, the School has a splendid record and has done excellent and efficient work.

2. Since 1909 the School has been self-supporting and this is the first time we are asking for any financial assistance.

3. The character of the training given by the School is shown by the number of former pupils who enlisted during the war, as well as the marked and increasing thrift and industry displayed by the pupils of the Reserves.

4. The fact that the school is always full to its capacity shows that it enjoys the full confidence of the Indians.

However, the Oblate Fathers see opportunities for more efficient work and greater assistance to the Department in training and educating Indian children, if they had an up-to-date building that would accommodate 150 pupils.

Most/
Most of the boys leave the Delmas and Onion Lake Schools at the age of fifteen or sixteen, that is before they have acquired fixed habits of work, thrift and industry. Could we receive them here we are in a position to give them a thorough training in mixed farming and domestic science.

We have 1500 acres of land for farming and stock raising. This land was bought by the Oblate Fathers for the exclusive use of the School. We have a good water supply and the farm is equipped with ample machinery and barns. All we need now, to have a first class and up-to-date Indian School, is a larger and more modern building.

The Oblate Fathers are not in a financial position to erect such buildings, this is why we are petitioning the Department for assistance.

Knowing dear Sir, the special interest you take in the welfare of our Indian children, your long experience among them, and the great influence you enjoy with the Department in your capacity of Indian Commissioner, I confidently ask you to approve and recommend our request.

Yours truly,

Rev. H. Delmas.
Principal.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that I personally visited the Duck Lake Boarding School on the 17th of this month.

The school was scrupulously clean from basement to garret, in fact I never in all my experience with Indian work saw such a well kept home and this condition is found in the face of the fact that the building they are occupying is obsolete. There are twelve Sisters looking after the institution. There are ninety-six children on the roll, half boys and half girls.

All the butter used for these hundred children is made at the school, there are from eight to fourteen cows milking all the time and the children get an abundance of milk. About one hundred head of cattle are kept as well as eighteen work horses. They have an excellent farmer who is assisted occasionally by one of the Brothers. The school is working 470 acres of land and nearly all the work is done by the larger boys. The flour used in the institution is ground in the local mill from grain grown on the farm.

The children were very tidy and appeared to be in splendid health, they are happy and contented and the class room work that I saw was excellent and above the average of an Indian School.

The building is in such a state that I consider it would be a waste of money to make any extensive

The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
repairs, the time has arrived when the question of erecting a new school should be seriously considered, in fact I doubt very much if they can carry on much longer in the present building. I would like to see an amount placed in the Estimates this year for the erection of a school at this point next year.

The children here do all the washing and baking of the bread by hand. I wish the Department to take particular note of this as I consider it is very important that the girls leaving school should have a knowledge of washing in tubs and how to bake bread.

The farming done is excellent and the oats this year ran close to 100 bushels to the acre and the wheat over 30.

Nearly all the clothes used in the institution are made by hand and hundreds of garments have been made from old worn clothes shipped from the warehouse here from time to time, stuff that would be considered junk. I saw stockings and mitts that had been made from the wool balaclavas, the wool having been unravelled and re-knit into these articles. Nothing is wasted here.

The Department have an institution at Duck Lake that they might well be proud of and the Principal, Father Delmas, is alert, business like, turning out good material and deserves encouragement. If he can do the work he is doing with the handicap he is now under, he certainly will do a great deal better with a modern building to carry on the work.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. GRAHAM,
Indian Commissioner.

MEMO FOR FILE:

RE: DUCK LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This institution opened for pupils in 1894, the buildings having been erected by both Church and State and the institution classed at that time as Government-owned Boarding School. Grant was paid for the first time during the fiscal year 1894-5. In 1906-7 the Church Authorities spent about $10,000 on plant.

In 1911 there was a change in status. The Church was given title to the 100 acres on which the institution was built - the consideration to the Crown being $500. The land which the Department sold to the Oblate Fathers for this sum was L.S. 3 and 4 and W. & L.S. 2 of Sec. 4 T. 24 R. 2 W. 3rd. The authority for this transfer was P.C. No. 991 dated May 10, 1911. Of course the State equity in the buildings was transferred at this time. A total capital expenditure of $20,775 had been made by the Department at this time.

For 12 years the Duck Lake Residential School has been church-owned and has received the grant for that type of institution. Only $315 has been spent on plant by this Department in this time. Our total capital expense since the start of the school has been $21,091.

The Oblate Fathers are now requesting the Department to purchase the outlying land of 700 acres. The main building is worth nothing and the only valuable structure is the horse stable, which is but two years old. The farm equipment and stock are also of considerable value. Some 300 acres owned by the Oblates at or near this school is cultivated. It is understood that this cultivated land is on the 700 acres which they propose to sell to the Department.

It should be noted that in 1894, when the Department secured the 100 acres on which the buildings were erected, the Church received as a consideration some 320 acres worth roughly $960, by the authority of P.C. No. 345 dated February 22, 1897.

Considering our $21,091.00 capital expense, the Church should allow for barn, small buildings, stock. We might purchase the 700 acres at a nominal price, say $10 per acre.

R.V.B.
OTTAWA, Ont., January 18th, 1924.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the rebuilding of Duck Lake Indian Boarding School I take the liberty of bringing the following propositions before the Department of Indian Affairs.

WHEREAS the Department of Indian Affairs intends to build at its own expense a large residential school to cope with the present situation of the Western Provinces and also with the advanced state of civilization of the Indians of the said Provinces;

WHEREAS in the past as also in the present the success of the Duck Lake Indian Boarding School has been achieved mainly through urging the Indians to develop the industries of their country, viz: agriculture, gardening and stock raising;

WHEREAS the Corporation of the Oblate Fathers will not and cannot bind itself for an indefinite time to keep for the use of the school the 700 acres that it possesses and which have been exclusively used for the purposes above mentioned;

WHEREAS the said land is absolutely necessary for the ends we have in view in carrying on our work with the Indian population:

The undersigned in the name of the Corporation of the Oblate Fathers respectfully requests from the Department to purchase from the said Corporation the 700 acres of land presently utilized for the school with the following buildings and chattels situated thereon; Granary, horse stable (entirely new and modern with accommodation for 20 horses), carpenter's shop, blacksmith's shop, 2 artesian wells (for the inmates and the stock), concrete septic tank (modern and most up to date), concrete cellars of the present buildings (to be used as vegetable cellars), all the farm implements and machinery, horses and cattle, all the beds and bedding in good order, school desks, chairs and teachers' desks.

HOWEVER lo-The Corporation of the Oblate Fathers would reserve the right to keep on the above offered property the present graveyard which could be enlarged if necessity would require it and a parochial church for the exclusive use of the Indians living on the neighboring reserves,

2o-The Corporation of the Oblate Fathers would reserve the right to take down, sell or remove the present buildings which will not become the property of the Department.

I leave the above propositions to your judicious attention with the hope of a favorable consideration.

Respectfully Yours,

[Signature]

Ottawa, April 2, 1924.

Dear Father Delmas:

I have given careful consideration to your letter of January 18th, with reference to the transfer to the Crown of the property at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. This question has been discussed with the Very Rev. Father Blanchin and Father Guy and I am now writing to ask you to secure from the Oblate Fathers a definite proposal which I can place before the Honourable the Superintendent General.

Prior to 1911, when the institution with 100 acres was transferred to the Oblate Fathers for a nominal consideration, the Department expended more than $20,000 for buildings and equipment. I propose that you offer the site of the school comprising 100 acres, the outbuildings, stock and equipment, on condition that the Department arranges at the first opportunity for an appropriation to purchase from the Oblate Fathers the remainder of the farm, some 600 acres, at a fair price.

If this proposition commends itself to you and to Father Blanchin, I shall be pleased for an early reply so that work on the new building may commence as soon as possible. The price for the 600 acres should be mentioned, and during your deliberations in this connection I request you to keep in mind that the school has grown in size and value in the past 30 years, during which time the institution was largely financed by per capita grants from parliamentary appropriation. I consider that the 600 acre farm should be offered to the Crown for a very reasonable price.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
