**PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading “Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter”.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the “Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter” by the “Total number of days in quarter”.

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the “Average attendance of pupils during quarter” by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Principal Rev. G. Chenevien

**ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES**

**CANADA**
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1951.

Principal

Dated: March 31, 1951

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated: APR 16, 1951

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Duck Lake School for the Quarter ended Sept. 30, 1951.

Principal: [Signature]

Dated Oct. 15, 1951.

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

[Signature]

Indian Agent

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Write Principal
0497 1-5
Bird
L.M.
June 24, 1952.

Mr. A.R. Nixon,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Duck Lake, Sask.,

The Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School when completing the March Quarterly Return claimed eighty-three days grant for pupil # 097 Della Bird. He further stated in the Remarks Column as follows: "Gone home to help sick parent". He has neglected to indicate the dates when the pupil left residence and later returned and no indication is given that this girl has attended class during the quarter.

Please advise as soon as possible when this girl left the Duck Lake Indian Residential School to help her parents and if she has returned to school please advise the date.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the Duck Lake School for the Quarter ended March 31st 1952.

Principal

Dated April 1st 1952

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at INDIAN AGENCY APR 9 1952 this BUCK LAKE, SASK. 19

NOTE

Principals will please be guided by the instructions printed on the last page.

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I hereby certify that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the St. Michael's Indian Residential School for the Quarter ended March 31, 1952.

Principal

Dated April 8, 1952

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

Indian Agent

Dated at Alert Bay, B.C.

this 8th April 1952

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the School for the Quarter ended Sept. 30, 1952.

Principal: [Signature]

Dated Oct. 5, 1952

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

THIS AGREEMENT made and entered into this thirty first day of May one thousand eight hundred and ninety four

By and Between

of the town of Prince Albert in the Judicial District of Prince Albert of the First Part (hereinafter called the Contractor) and the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada represented by of the Second Part (hereinafter called the Proprietor).

Witnesseth:

First. The said part of the First Part DOES HEREBY for himself heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, COVENANT PROMISE AND AGREE to and with the said part of the Second Part, his successors, administrators and assigns, in manner following, that is to say:

That he shall or will, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, on or before the day of in the year one thousand eight hundred and ninety four, well and sufficiently execute and perform, in a true perfect and thorough workmanlike manner, the work required in the erection and completion of an Indian boarding school.

for the part of the Second Part on lands and premises situated in the town of Saulteau in the District of Prince Albert in the North-West Territories, agreeably to the plans, drawings and specifications prepared for the said works by Architect, to the satisfaction and under the direction and personal supervision of and will find and provide such good, proper and sufficient material of all kinds whatsoever as shall be proper and sufficient for completing and finishing of all the works of said building according to the said plans and mentioned in said specifications, and signed by the contractor within the time aforesaid, for the sum of Dollars of lawful money of Canada.

Second. The said part of the Second Part DOES HEREBY for himself heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, COVENANT PROMISE AND AGREE to and with the said part of the First Part, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, that he the said part of the Second Part, as specified, well and truly pay or cause to be paid unto the party of the First Part, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, the sum of Dollars of lawful money of Canada, in the manner following: per cent, to be paid by on account of the contract and all additional works, as the work shall proceed, on the value of the same, which value shall be in proportion to the amount to be paid for the whole of the works and additional works, the balance of the contract and all extras to be paid within days from the completion of the said works, and after the Contractor shall have rendered to the statement of the balance due to AND it is further understood that in the case
Provided, that in respect of the said payments, a progress certificate shall be obtained from and signed by the Architect, and that he consider the payment properly due, said certificate, however, in no way lessening the total and final responsibility of the Contractor, neither shall it exempt the Contractor from liability to replace work if it be afterwards discovered to have been badly done, or not according to the drawing and specifications, either in execution or materials.

And Provided Further, that if required, in each case a certificate shall be obtained by the Contractor from the Registrar of the District where mechanics' liens may be recorded, and signed by said Registrar, that he has examined the records and finds no mechanics' liens or claims recorded against the land of the Proprietor, on account of the said Contractor; and thereupon, and on or before the said day after the completion of the said works, a final certificate shall be obtained from and signed by the Architect, and that he consider the payment properly due, said certificate, however, in no way lessening the total and final responsibility of the Contractor, neither shall it exempt the Contractor from liability to replace work if it be afterwards discovered to have been badly done, or not according to the drawing and specifications, either in execution or materials.

And it is Herby Further Agreed, by and between the said parties as follows, that is to say:

First. The Specifications and Drawings are intended to co-operate, so that any works shown in the Drawings and not mentioned in the Specifications or vice versa, are to be executed the same as if mentioned in the Specifications and set forth in the Drawings, to the true intent and meaning of the said Drawings and Specifications.

Second. The Contractor, at his own proper cost and charges, to provide all manner of labor, material, apparatus, scaffolding, utensils, carriage of every description useful for the due performance of the several works, and render all due and sufficient facilities to the Inspector, Superintendent and Clerk of the Works, for the proper inspection of the work and materials, and which are to be under their control; and they may require the Contractor to dismiss any workman or workmen who may be incompetent, the workmen and Contractor being equally bound to see that the work is executed in the proper execution of the works. The Contractor shall and will during the whole time of building give due personal attention, either by himself or by a competent foreman for each Trade as may be required upon the execution of all the works aforesaid, and take effectual care that the same be carried on, executed, and performed without expense and despatch, to be in every respect completed by the day provided for the completion thereof, subject only to such provision for an extension of time as is herein provided. The Contractor shall deliver up the works to the Proprietor in perfect repair, clean and in good condition, when complete. The Contractor shall not sub-let the works or any part thereof without the consent in writing of the Architect.

Third. Should the Proprietor, at any time during the progress of the said works require any alterations or additions or variations from additions or omissions in the said plans and specifications, he shall have the right and power to make such change or changes, and the same shall in no wise affect or make void the contract, but the value of work omitted shall be deducted from the amount of contract by a fair and reasonable valuation, and for additional work required in alterations, the amount to be paid therefor shall be agreed upon before commencing additions, and such agreement shall state also the extension of time (if any) which is to be granted by reason thereof; provided that in estimating the cost of such alterations or additions, regard shall be had to any loss, outlay or damage, necessarily and reasonably sustained by the Contractor in the preparations to comply with the original drawings and specifications.

Fourth. In case the works are not carried on with such expedition and with such materials and workmanship as the Architect, Superintendent, or Clerk of the Works may deem proper, then, with the special and written consent of the Proprietor, the Architect shall be at liberty to give the Contractor days' notice in writing to supply such additional force or material as in the opinion of the said Architect may be necessary, and the Contractor failing to supply the same, it shall not be lawful for the said Proprietor to dismiss the said Contractor, and to engage other persons to finish the work, or in such manner as the Architect may direct, and in accordance with plans and specifications; and all payments made on account thereof shall be deemed a payment on account of the contract, but without prejudice to the right to recover any money in excess of the contract price, which may be paid for so finishing the works, or any other damage caused by breach of this contract. But if any balance on the amount of this contract remains after completion, in respect of work done during the time of the defaulting Contractor, the same shall belong to the person legally representing him.

Fifth. Should any question arise respecting the true construction or meaning of the drawings and specifications, or should any dispute occur from any cause whatever during the continuance of this contract, the same shall be referred to the award, order, and determination of the Architect whose award shall be final and conclusive, subject only to the exception provided for in clause sixth in reference to the value of any claim for extras or deductions.
SIXTH. Should any dispute arise as to the value of any claim for extras or deductions after the acceptance thereof, the same shall be referred to two arbitrators, one to be chosen by the Proprietor and the other by the Contractor; and in case of disagreement the two arbitrators shall appoint a third arbitrator, whose award and decision or that of any two of them, shall be final and conclusive, and binding upon all parties to this contract, the submission and reference to be in writing under seal, and to be signed by the Proprietor and Contractor and the third arbitrator; and the said award of the arbitrators or any two of them to be also in writing, duly signed, sealed, and delivered, shall be subject to the rules of the Supreme Court of the North-West Territories, when so submitted to and decided by competent authority. Where the Proprietor or Contractor shall apply for an arbitration, the application shall not be entertained until security to the amount of two hundred dollars has been given by the applicant to cover the costs of the arbitration, and the arbitrators or any two of them shall decide as to the payment of the costs of the arbitration and award, and in case of a balance remaining due from the Contractor according to the certificates of the arbitrators, the same may be received only against the said security of two hundred dollars, or even the costs of arbitration. In case either party refuses or neglects to appoint an arbitrator within two weeks of his being notified to do so, the Judge for the time being of the Supreme Court of the North-West Territories shall appoint one for him.

SEVENTH. All figured or written dimensions on drawings or specifications to supersede the measurement by scale.

EIGHTH. The Proprietor will not in any manner be answerable or accountable for any loss or damage by fire or otherwise that shall happen or may happen to the said works, or any part or parts thereof, or for any of the materials or other things used and employed in finishing and completing the said works, or for injury to any person or persons, either workmen or the public, or for damage to adjoining property from any cause which might have been prevented by the Contractor or his workmen or anyone employed by him, against all which injuries and damages to persons or property the Contractor having control over such work must properly guard against and make good all damage, from whatever cause, by fire or otherwise, being strictly responsible for the same.

NINTH. The Proprietor shall insure the building from time to time to the extent of at least two-thirds of its value during the course of erection, the amount of the premium to be assessed pro rata on the several trades, and in case the Proprietor should not insure, he will be required to run all risks of loss so far as regards the value of the works.

TENTH. All work and material as delivered on the premises, to form part of the works, are to be considered the property of the Proprietor, and are not to be removed without his consent; but the Contractor shall have the right to remove all surplus material after he has completed the works herein contracted for.

ELEVENTH. Should the Contractor fail to finish the work as set forth in this Agreement, he shall pay to or allow the Proprietor—by way of liquidated damages—the sum of $—dollars per week for each and every week thereafter the said works shall remain incomplete due allowance to be made for extension of time for additional work or alterations as laid down in clause number three of this Agreement.

TWELFTH. Should any work be delayed beyond the time mentioned in this Agreement by the inclemency of the weather, or by reason of general strikes of a particular trade, the Contractor shall have full power to extend the time for the completion of the works, making a just and reasonable extension for that purpose.

THIRTEENTH. The Proprietor is not to be responsible to any Contractor for the non-completion of a prior Contractor's work, or any particular portion thereof, at the time named, but in case a Contractor is unable to get possession on account of the failure of a prior Contractor to complete his work within the time limited in his Contract, such subsequent Contractor shall be entitled to have for the completion of his Contract such additional time as the Proprietor may deem necessary or just, and such extended time shall be substituted for the time for completion named in this Contract.

FOURTEENTH. All drawings and specifications in possession of the Contractor shall be returned to the Proprietor by the Contractor before the final certificate is issued.

FIFTEENTH. The Contract to be in duplicate if so desired by either of the contracting parties.

In witness whereof, the said parties to these Presents have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above written.

Signed, Sealed, and Delivered,

IN THE PRESENCE OF

24-7-94 M.M.
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of yesterday's date which reads as follows:

"Well for Duck Lake School absolutely necessary will cost $6 per foot inside building and $4 outside including stone cribbing one foot above water line balance wood pump inserted complete for use, think will not exceed 25 feet. May I authorize".

In reply I beg to inform you that the Department regrets that it has no funds for this purpose; and it would be glad to know why the well in connection with the mission cannot be used.

Your obedient servant

Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs

The Assistant Indian Commissioner
Regina N.W.T.,
Boarding School Duck Lake
Stobart P. O. Sask. N. W. T.
August 13th 1894.

To the Indian Commissioner

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 8th ultimo Reference 1378, I beg to state that the Mission well is not sufficiently near the school premises to be used by both. It cannot furnish quantity of water required. I am positive to say that in case of fire it would be impossible to master it. The Mission well is at one hundred and fifty yards from the school.

Believe me

Sir

Your obedient Servant

(Signed) M. J. P. Paquette, prêtre
O. M. I.

Indian Commissioner
Regina.
Boarding School August 15th 1894
Stobart P. O., Sask., N.W.T.
via Duck Lake.

To the Indian Commissioner
Regina
N.W.T., Assa.

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you that I am arrived at Duck Lake since only six days ago and there is no water already in the Mission Well. We will be obliged to go to the town and make more than one mile to have a pail of water.

Believe me

Sir

Your obedient Servant

(Signed) M. J. P. Paquette
O. M. I.
principal

Indian Commissioner
Regina
Office of the Indian Agent
Duck Lake Agency
16th August 1894

Indian Commissioner
Regina

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 1378 of the 30th ultimo informing me that there was no funds for the purpose of sinking a well at the new boarding school at Duck Lake.

In this connection I may inform you that the well in connection with the mission is small and the supply of water is very limited, in fact it is almost dry and could not possibly supply the school. I am of opinion a new well will absolutely be required and I think it could be built outside the building for about $4 to $4.50 per foot.

I have &c

(Signed) R. S. McKenzie
Indian Agent

CANADA
Legislative Assembly

Regina, 29 Aug 1894

Dear Sir,

Father Ouellette has written me a long letter asking me to intercede for him with the Dept. regarding the building of water closets and digging a well for the Indian Industrial School at Regina. He states that he has seen 20 pupils and needs the above necessary conveniences. The well at the school being dry he is obliged to send water from the town. It is useless to say that the absence of closets is also very objectionable.

I trust you will see fit to grant sufficient money for the construction.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6305, file 652-5, part 1)
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of a copy of a letter from Mr. Agent MacKenzie in which he states that the water supply at the Duck Lake Mission is not sufficient to meet the requirements of the new Boarding School there; and in reply I have to inform you that the well may be dug the cost of the same not to exceed that stated by the Agent, namely $40 to $60 per foot.

I beg also to state that the water closets also required for this school may be constructed in accordance with the plan and specifications herewith enclosed.

Your obedient servant

Deputy Superintendent
of Indian Affairs.

The Assistant Indian Commissioner,
Regina, N.W.T.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Commissioner's Office,
Regina, S.W.
September 14th 1894

My dear Mr Reed:

Bishop Pascal and the Rev Father Paquette are still assailing this office with letters making requisitions for various things for their Boarding school at Duck Lake, which I have resisted on the ground of want of funds.

I am glad, however, to see that the Department has seen its way to authorize the building of water closets and the digging of a well. They are now, among other things, pressing for the erection of stables for horses, cows, sheep and poultry and also for a store house; as there is no room in the main building for storing clothing and provisions. These are all very necessary to the Institution and I can only hope you may be able to come to the rescue.

Yours faithfully,

Hayter Reed Esq.
D.S.G.I.A.
Ottawa
My dear Forget,

In reply to your note of the 14th instant stating that the Church authorities are pressing for the erection of stables and a storehouse for the Dug Lake Boarding School, I have to say that in the absence of an estimate of the cost I cannot write definitely but will see what can be done so soon as you give me such estimate. If you can give me any idea of what their views are as to the description of buildings to be erected I would be glad.

Yours sincerely,

A.H. Forget; sq:
Asst: Indian Commissioner
Regina, N.W.T.

The writer of this letter has received a wire from Mr. J. W. Wilson, of the Saskatoon Brick and Supply Company, Limited, asking him to call on you with reference to having sand lined brick used in the Duck Lake School in Saskatchewan. Dear Dr. King:

A friend of mine by the name of Mr. J.W. Wilson, who is the owner of the Saskatoon Brick and Supply Company, has manufactured sand-lime bricks—white, red, buff and other colors.

We have used this brick for inside work in a good many of the buildings in the City of Saskatoon, especially school buildings and they have some of the best school buildings in our Province. We also used it for inside work for our Normal School in Saskatoon and I understand they have sold twenty-four million bricks in Saskatoon and the surrounding country, in the last fifteen years.

I notice you intend building an Indian School at Duck Lake and that you specify clay bricks for inside work. Now this brick is just as good as any clay brick and in fact we have found it better. I do not know whether this comes under your Department or not and it may come under the Indian Department but I wish you would take the matter up and allow your contractor to use the sand-lime brick—provided it is as cheap and as good as the clay product. We are building a Sanatorium at Saskatoon and we are allowing them to use the sand lime brick for the inside work. Anything you can do for Mr. Wilson I will appreciate very much.

I understand the contractor who tendered the lowest on this school building, is the same contractor who tendered on our Sanatorium at Saskatoon and who is building same—Smith Brothers and Wilson. They are one of the leading contractors in the Province and they built a lot of the University Buildings in Saskatoon.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Minister.

Dr. King,
Minister of Public Works,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Transferred to the Deputy Superintendent General Department of Indian Affairs.

June 21, 1924.

Dear Mr. McNab:

I have yours of the 18th instant recommending that the brick required in connection with the erection of an Indian School at Duck Lake be obtained from Mr. J. W. Wilson, owner of the Saskatoon Brick and Supply Company.

In reply, I beg to advise you that the construction of Indian Schools comes under the Department of Indian Affairs, and I have, therefore, transferred your letter to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs for attention.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd.) J. H. King

Hon. A. P. McNab,

The following is a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by his Excellency the Governor General on the 21st June 1924.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 13th June, 1924, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that, it having been decided to erect a new Indian residential school at Duck Lake in the province of Saskatchewan, tenders were called for, receivable up to noon of the 5th day of June, 1924, and the following were received:

| Tenderer                                      | Location       | Amount        |
|-----------------------------------------------|----------------|---------------|
| Albert Amyot, Bennett & White Construction Co.| Calgary        | $184,000.00   |
| H.G. Macdonald, Hamilton Construction Co.     | Edmonton       | $149,694.00   |
| Alex Ferguson, Shannen Bros.                 | Moose Jaw      | $142,000.00   |
| S. Brown, Wilson & Wilson, Ltd.              | Saskatoon      | $159,990.00   |
| Claydon Co., Ltd.                            | Winnipeg       | $159,900.00   |
| Poole Construction Co.                       | Regina         | $139,700.00   |
| A.W. Cassidy & Co., Ltd.                     | Winnipeg       | $135,970.00   |
| James Priel, Smith Brothers & Wilson, Ltd.    | Saskatoon      | $134,565.00   |
| Smith Brothers & Wilson, Ltd.                | Regina         | $126,840.00   |

The Minister recommends, pursuant to the requirements of Sub-section 2 of Section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the contract be awarded to the lowest tenderers, Smith Brothers & Wilson, Ltd., for the amount of their tender as above cited, namely, $126,840 the same being reported by the architect of the Department as a fair and reasonable price for the work, and money having been provided therefor in the vote for Indian Education No.279.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re Duck Lake Indian School:

Following is confirmation of telegram sent you "Night Lettergram" on June 22nd:

"SAMPLE CLAY BRICK WILL BE EXPRESSED TOMORROW
SAND LIME WILL BE FORWARDED FROM SASKATOON
STOP CONSIDER CLAY BRICK WE PROPOSE USING
SHOULD BE USED ON EXTERIOR BEST FOR THIS PURPOSE CAN USE SAND LIME IN INTERIOR THEY ARE
GOOD BRICK ESPECIALLY FOR INTERIOR WORK STOP
VERY ANXIOUS TO RECEIVE YOUR INSTRUCTIONS TO
PROCEED PLEASE WIRE DIRECTLY YOU CAN DO SO."

We have asked the Prince Albert Brick Co., Ltd., to forward you a sample of the clay brick which we propose using. This is a good brick. We have examined buildings where this company's brick has been used. Some of the buildings have been up for years and bricks have stood up extremely well.

We might say this is a Saskatchewan product and is equal to any other Saskatchewan clay brick.

You will note what we said in our wire regarding sand lime brick as manufactured by the Saskatoon Brick & Supply Company. They are a good brick. We would have no hesitation whatever in using these in the interior. We consider, however, the Prince Albert Brick would stand up better for exterior work.

You will also note how anxious we are to receive instructions to proceed. We do so want to place our orders
for materials, as it is possible that in some lines, especially lumber, prices may advance. Of course, at the low price we have quoted on this building, we do not want to be forced to pay more than what we have figured on.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.,
per

L.B. Secretary.

Dear Sirs:

We are in receipt of your cheque No. 1069 (Vote No. 286)
value $9.87 dated June 17, 1924 and would beg to say our
account as rendered amounted to $13.23.

Your insertion order No. 7741 called for 47 line advertise-
ment to be inserted three times for which you have paid us
seven cents a line on your measurement whereas the advertise-
ment measured 63 lines as set in the ordinary body type of
The Herald.

As pointed out in our letter to you dated September 29, 1923
if we charge on your lineage the rate is 12¢ and 8¢ but if we
charge seven cents as per our rate card the seven cents is charge-
able on the actual measurement as printed in the ordinary body
type of our paper.

We enclose herewith copy of our account for your information
and would point out there is still an amount of $3.36 debited
against you on our books.

Yours very truly,

THE HERALD PRINTING COMPANY LIMITED,

Dear Sir,

If you could also let us know the total amount of the contract, the unit prices bid, and the names and addresses of all bidders, we would be much obliged to you.

Sir,

Ottawa, July 2, 1924.

Dear Sir,

As advised by telegram today you may proceed with the work on the new Duck Lake School.

I am enclosing herewith Contract Forms in duplicate, which I would ask you to kindly sign and return to the Department, and when executed by the Deputy Superintendent General a copy will be sent you.

I am also sending you, under separate cover, five blue print copies of the plans and specifications for use on the work.

I would ask you to exercise great care in locating the building, as I understand the fall from the proposed location to the existing septic tank is only what is required to properly drain the building. Sheet No. 13 shows the location of the building, with reference to the septic tank and the well. Father Delmas can, no doubt, give you assistance in this matter.

I will advise you in the course of a day or so who will act as Inspector of Construction on this work.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Smith Brothers & Wilson, Limited,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, July 8, 1924.

Dear Mr. Long:

With reference to the brick for the Duck Lake School, I beg to say that I approve of using the sand lime brick on the interior of the walls of the laundry, recreation rooms, toilets and wash rooms and lighting plant room.

I would like to call your attention to the belt courses, etc., shown on the front elevation that are marked 'dark red brick'. Please arrange to get the darkest brick you can, in order to give a good contrast.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr,
Architect for the Department.

E. Long, Esq.,
o/o Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd.,
Regina, Sask.

July 5, 1924.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed Inspector of Construction of the new Indian Residential School at Duck Lake, Sask., and you will be paid for your services at the rate of $6.00 per day. You will be expected to devote all of your time to this work, and to see that the building is built in accordance with the plans and specifications. You will note that no alterations are to be made in the plans and specifications or extra work authorized without furnishing full information to the Department and obtaining written consent for the changes. I would particularly draw your attention to this clause in the specifications and ask you to see that it is strictly complied with.

The contract for the building has been awarded to Smith Bros. & Wilson, Limited of Regina, at their tendered price of $126,840.00, and you will note by the specifications that they are to be paid on their contract at the rate of 90% of the value of the labour and material in the building. Certificate forms for this purpose are being sent you, under separate cover. These forms should be filled out in duplicate, and when giving the contractors the certificate you should at the same time forward to the Department a summary of the labour and material comprised in the certificate as issued.

You will be expected to make fortnightly reports to the Department through the Indian Commissioner's office at Regina, giving full details as to the progress of the work. I am sending you, under separate cover, diary sheets which should be properly filled out and presented to Reverend Father Delmas, Principal of the Duck Lake school, at the end of each month, when he will forward them to the Department with a voucher for the payment of your salary.

I am also sending you, under separate cover, a blue print copy of the plans and specifications.

Yours very truly,

Adrien Taillon, Esq.,
Marcellin, Sask.
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

Re Duck Lake Indian School:
Your Reference 109-1-5a:

We are in receipt of yours of July 2nd together with contract forms. Herewith we are returning forms, duly signed and sealed, as requested.

We also acknowledge receipt of the 5 blueprint copies of the plans and specifications.

With reference to the location of the building, our Mr. D. D. Smith was in Duck Lake and has laid out this building in strict accordance with Sheet No. 13 of the plans. We have raised the levels as high as possible so as to take care of the drainage from the building. Father Dalmas was with Mr. Smith at the time. He would have liked the building raised higher still, but it was impossible to do so without entailing extra cost as the walls would have to be extended. We think what we have done will be perfectly satisfactory to you.

For your information, would say the excavation will be completed by Wednesday next. We have part of the material on the site and will rush construction to the limit.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.
per

Dear Sir:

We have been notified by Smith Bros. & Wilson of Regina, contractors for the erection of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, that our tile would not be used. They also intimate that it was the desire of the Department that Bruno hollow tile be used if possible.

Would you kindly advise why our tile could not be used on this job?

We are the only manufacturers of 8x12x12 and 12x12x12 tile in western Canada, as far as we know, and were of the opinion that our price per foot was much lower than any other price submitted.

Trusting that we may have the pleasure of a reply shortly, we are,

Yours very truly,

Alberta Clay Products Co.

Dear Mr. Stewart:

Our Winnipeg agents write to us with reference to the Indian School at Duck Lake, Sask. The specifications for the Metal Lath on this building read as follows:

"Internal faces of all partitions and outside walls not built of hollow tile or brick shall be strapped where required, and lathed with approved painted metal lath #24 gga., a sample of lath to be submitted for approval."

We manufacture HERRINGBONE and Standard KEY LATH, both of which have been approved by the Public Works Department at Ottawa and on many occasions in the past, they have written their specifications to read "Herringbone Lath or equal".

If it is not too much trouble, I should be obliged if you would ask your Engineer in charge of this building to give the necessary approval to our lath, so that our agents may be in a position to secure the business, if their prices are satisfactory.

Thanking you for the assistance you may be
Hon. Chas. Stewart

Dear Sir,

Re: Duck Lake Indian School

We note from the Specifications covering the above work that the Electric Generating Unit will be supplied by your department. We will therefor consider it a favor if you will forward us a copy of specifications covering this equipment and we will be glad to give a quotation for the equipment F.O.B. destination.

We are prepared to quote on the complete power plant equipment including the Engine, Generator, (Belted or Direct Coupled) and the Switchboards and Storage Battery provided these comprise the equipment specified.

This firm is of British origin with a Canadian Factory at Toronto, Canada. We are general Electrical Engineering Specialists and therefor solicit your patronage. At the present time we are building equipment in our Toronto Factory for the Elkhorn Indian School and assure you of our very best services in connection with the above contract provided we are given the opportunity to quote on your requirements.

Thanking you in anticipation,

F.H.G./P.

Yours very truly,

Ferguson and Pailin Limited,

District Manager.

P.S. All enquiries for Saskatchewan are handled in this office.
R. Gurney, Orr Esq.
Dominion Government Architect,
Ottawa, Ont., Canada.

Dear Sir,

Re: McIntosh Indian School.

Attached hereto kindly find copy of letter to the Hon. Duncan Scott, Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs in which we asked for permission to quote on the Generator and Power House Equipment in connection with the Duck Lake Indian School to which we have not received a reply.

Since writing the attached we have seen specifications covering the McIntosh Indian School and note that the Generator and Power House Equipment will be supplied by the Department in the same manner as that for the Duck Lake School. As we are not interested in the wiring and would like to quote on the Power House Equipment and as we did not get any reply from Mr. Scott to our letter of June 7th the writer has been advised by Mr. J. R. Bunn to write to you as this matter probably comes under your department.

This letter was started on July 18th but the writer was taken very ill on that date and has only now returned to work. Trusting you will advise.

Yours very truly,

F.H.G./P.

District Manager.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Re Duck Lake Indian School:

We had a conversation today over the phone with Mr. Graham. Dear Sir,

As Inspector of Construction for the new Indian School of Duck Lake, I am glad to inform you that the work which started on July 11th., is found entirely satisfactory. The excavations are completed and the concrete foundations are finished.

They started the brick work last week. There are already 36 men employed and in a few days there will be more because it is the intention of the contractor to push on the work as fast as possible. The materials are coming in every day. All the brick and a part of the lumber are on the place.

I really think that there will be no delay in the work as far as the materials are concerned.

Hoping that everything will be found satisfactory

I remain,

Dear Mr. Orr,

You must be anxious to find out how the construction of our new building is progressing. Everything is going on well. The material has been arriving on time. There is no want of men for the work. Mr. Adrian Taillon does his duty in a conscientious manner, and Smith Bros., finding him to be a man who thoroughly understands his trade, respect him and follow his ideas.

After serious consideration and after having consulted with Mr. Taillon and the Smith Bros., the following are a few suggestions which I would like to submit to your good judgment.

1. - (water system) In order to make sure of having a sufficient quantity of water, I would ask you, dear Mr. Orr, to grant that our pressure tanks be temporarily placed in the garage so that the water from well no.1 be taken to these tanks as specified. I believe that the pump and engine which we use every day are in sufficiently good order to continue this work. Only the air pipes from the old building to the new, for which no provision was made in the specifications, will be required.

I would also ask that water be taken from well no.2, as this water is of superior quality, clearer, softer, and in sufficient quantity. It is the water from this well which the contractors are using for the cement and mortar; the small pump has been kept constantly going for 10 hrs. per day and the water has not given out. This water when once boiled is like rain water, and scales made on the pipes are soft while the scales of no.1 well are as hard as stone.

2. - For this purpose there is needed a brick house of 12'x14' large enough for an electric motor water pump and air pump. A 2 H.P. electric power should be placed in order to give an automatic supply of water.

3. - Outside stairs from and to the chapel are necessary for Indians who come from the reserves.

4. - We are also in need of a cistern for soft water outside the house. Our soil does not permit to dig down more than 9 ft., as at that depth we strike quick sand which caves in. To have a large supply of soft water for boilers, washing engines this cistern should be 24 ft. in diameter and should be connected with the metallic soft water tank specified in the plan.

5. - Stairs that lead from the gallery to the chapel were forgotten in the plans. They are absolutely necessary so that the sisters and girls may enter the chapel and depart by this gallery.

6. - I would recommend a cork floor for the kitchen and scullery, in order that the fatigue of those working in these departments may be lessened.

7. - I would likewise ask for a gallery on the west side of the building (at the 1st.floor) for the use of the weak or sick sisters and children. This should be inclosed with sliding windows and screens.

8. - In order to deaden the noise of the house, we would be very grateful to you, if we could be permitted to place one thickness of deafening paper between the rough and the finishing floor instead of building paper as specified.

We need also a reducing pression valve for our tanks.

Please find inclosed a detailed statement of the cost of these extras. As the season is quite advance an early answer would greatly oblige us.

I sincerely hope, dear Mr. Orr, that you will not refuse our request, so that the construction of this new building will be a real credit to your department.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. H. Selmar
Principal

MEMORANDUM: MR. SCOTT.

A letter has been received from Rev. Father Delmas with reference to the new Duck Lake School, and he has asked for the following additional work, in connection with the school.

Building outside steps to chapel $40.00
Building of a large reinforced concrete cistern for storing of rain water $1,450.00
Building of stairs from chapel to balcony, 110.00
Laying of battleship linoleum in kitchen and scullery, 248.00
Building of balcony on west side of building $1,470.00
Placing of sound proof felt between floors 910.00

With reference to these items I would recommend that the contractors be authorized to build the outside steps leading to chapel and also the steps from chapel to balcony and the laying of the linoleum in kitchen and scullery.

Regarding the other items, owing to the large expenditure involved I would recommend that these items be referred to Commissioner Graham for his report.

Sir:-

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, No. 109-1-5A, with reference to the work on the Duck Lake Boarding School.

In my letter to you of the 18th of August there was an omission of a word; I wished to convey to you that the work was about half completed instead of about completed, as I knew perfectly well that it was far from being completed.

Dear Sir,

Subject Lighting Plant
I have just returned from Duck Lake and have gone fully into all matters electrical with Father Delmas and your inspector and as such I would like to make the following suggestions.
The plant as first quoted is large enough to handle their load and give ample satisfaction except the storage battery. My first quotation was for a 520 ampere hour globelite storage battery and though it is capable of handling this load it would not last as long as the type E-13 Manchester Chloride if you decide to install the water pressure system which I have been asked to quote to you as the motor which is started and stopped by an automatic switch take a strong current each time it starts and therefor requires a battery with a very strong positive plate. This you will find was the trouble with the battery at Punnichy which warped the plates and started discharging. The difference of cost would be Six Hundred and Forty Nine Dollars $649.00. This would make the total plant installed Five Thousand One Hundred and Forty Nine Dollars $5149.00. The quickest delivery on this battery would be seven weeks from receipt of order at factory. The total weight of this battery would be 11500 lbs against the Globelite at 5000 lbs.
I have also made a sketch of proposed lay out so as to have a straight belt feed for the laundry plant and also to have the electrical end close together. I trust this information will be satisfactory to you and that I may be entrusted with this work which I will install myself and promise to give you entire satisfaction.
I may say if I am given this work I have promised Father Delmas to take his man who is to work this plant and learn him everything necessary.

I beg to remain Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re Duck Lake Indian School:

Further to our letter of July 30th and your reply of August 7th re Electric Fixtures, etc. Our Electrician has been in communication with Reverend Father Delmas. They, together with Inspector Taillon, have prepared a list of what they wish to have. If fixtures are installed in accordance with this list, they would cost the sum of Eleven Hundred and Ninety-three Dollars ($1193.00). Our Electrician further says as an alternative estimate, he would install fixtures making the following alterations: - Using #2727 5-light fixtures and #3007 1-light brackets in place of #2927 and #6895 4-light fixtures, and #6894 brackets; also install all fixtures with 40-watt clear lamps instead of frosted. This would cost the sum of Nine Hundred and Seventy-nine Dollars and Sixty Cents ($979.60). The Electrician says he is sure this will give ample light.

Mr. Millon, your Inspector, has also approved a list of extras as follows: - 2 lights and switch in sub-cellar; 2 switches in basement dining room; 1 plug in pharmacy and 1 extra push in staff-room of top floor for songs. This would cost the sum of Fifty-four Dollars ($54.00).

You will also remember $46.00 of the amount allowed for fixtures has already been charged against that account, as per your letter of August 7th.

We are enclosing herewith the list of fixtures which Father Delmas and Inspector Taillon have O.K.'d, together with cuts, for your consideration, and would be pleased to hear from you as early as you possibly can as to what your decision is regarding the whole matter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Long:

With reference to the drying tumbler required for the Duck Lake School I have received a letter from the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., asking me to approve of the use of their tumbler.

I may say that as far as I know this is an entirely new product. I think that I am correct in saying that they have about one-half dozen of these in use, and those for a very short time, as they have just commenced manufacturing these articles. Under these circumstances I am not prepared to approve of the use of this tumbler, but if on making inquiries you wish to install it, and will guarantee its satisfactory operation to the Department, it will be all right for you to install this tumbler as manufactured by this firm.

Dear Sir,

I beg to call your attention to one particular item of the building of our new school, viz. the Toilets in the wash-room in the Basement, next to the Girls' Recreation-room.

On the Plan it is shown that there be doors to every partition of the ten toilets; while the Specifications, Page 70, #15, read: "Contractor will note that no doors are required for these partitions."

For several serious reasons, I consider that doors are absolutely necessary for toilets in the Girls' Wash-room; and the same for the seven toilets in the Girls' Dormitory, which on the Plan are shown open.

I do hope that you will find no objection to granting my request in this particular matter. And as most likely, all these steel partitions are now being under construction, I wish that you would favor us or rather the Contractor with a prompt reply, preferably by telegram.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

I beg to call your attention to some items in connection with the building of the new school at the above Institution.

1. PLAN OF ROOF. - I herewith enclose a drawing, showing sketch No 1, as per your Plan; and sketch No 2, as per suggestion of the Contractors, Smith Bros. & Wilson. The Contractors pretend that by following your Plan they cannot make a good job and will not guarantee same. You will note that on their Plan they leave out 3 leadings, and thereby save a lot of material and labor.

In my opinion your Plan is perfectly workable, and moreover will give a better and nearer drainage.

2. PLASTERING.- The Contractors intend to start the plastering of the walls before the roof is completed. I think this should not be done, as in case of rain, the plaster would be greatly damaged.

3. PARTITIONS: Walls between Wash-room and Recreation-room in Basement. The specifications do not mention whether these walls should be built with bricks or tiles.-I would suggest that bricks be used, and that this should be insisted upon by the Architect.

As these different works will be started in a few days, and as the Contractors might not accept my orders very readily, I would ask you to give me your instructions on the above matters by telegram.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my semi-monthly report on the construction of the new school at Duck Lake.

BRICK-WORK. All the exterior walls are completed up to the roof. The frame work on the roof can be proceeded with at any time. In fact the roof should be put on before any plastering of the walls be started.

WOOD-WORK. The roof over the Chapel will be completed in a few days.-The wooden partitions in the Basement and Ground Floor are all up.

WATER SYSTEM. The supply pipes all are laid in the trenches from the well to the building, and a number of the water and soil pipes have already been placed in the building itself.

STEAM HEATING. The two boilers, though set in their places, have not yet been lowered to their respective footings.-The main pipes in the Basement have been installed.

MATERIAL on the grounds.-White enamelled bricks,-tiles,-and lumber for the roof,-roofing paper and pitch,-Fire Escapes,-steam and water pipes.Two cars of plaster have been delivered.

REMARKS.I have had considerable trouble with the Contractors. 1. - Supply 2" Galvanized Water Line from Well No. 2 to the Boiler Room, assuming approximately 420 feet, $588.00. Price does not include any work on tanks or air line.

2. - Construct Brick Pump House 12'x14' with concrete footings, concrete floor, 8" brick walls with gable-ended roof, gables in brick and the roof constructed of 2x4, shiplap and shingles, the building complete with two windows and one door, with all the outside millwork painted three coats, the sum of $525.00.

3. - Construct a set of plank steps from the grade to the chapel corridor, painted three coats, for the sum of $40.00.

4. - Construct Concrete Cistern 24' inside diameter inside, the whole of the work to be in reinforced concrete as per the enclosed drawing, for the sum of $1450.00. This price does not include any piping to or from the tank for the rainwater intake or the overflow to the sewer.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, #109-1-5A, enclosing a request that has been made by the Rev. Father Delmas, Principal of the Duck Lake Indian School, for a number of changes in the work in progress at that institution.

I may say that on receipt of this letter I sent Mr. Inspector Christianson to Duck Lake to inquire into the various matters referred to. He has returned and has gone into the matter very thoroughly with me, and I shall deal with them here as they appear on the list furnished you by the Rev. Principal.

1 & 2. Water System. There appears to be no good reason why the Department should build a pump house and install pipes from well No. 2. Well No. 1 is already connected up with the school, and has an ample supply of water for the institution. The argument for this change is that the water appears to be softer in well No. 2. This argument is not borne out by tests made of samples from both wells at the Provincial Laboratory here, and I see no reason for making an additional expenditure of from $2000 to $2500 to connect up well No. 2.

3. The plank steps from the grade to the chapel corridor are necessary, and I would recommend that these be built, at a cost not to exceed $40.00.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
4. The concrete cistern appears to be necessary. You will note that the pipes and fittings in connection with this work are additional; probably $100.00 will have to be added to the price of $1450.00 quoted by Messrs. Smith Bros. and Wilson for this work. I am satisfied that it would be more economical to build this cistern now, while they have a concrete mixer and men on the job than it would be to put this off for another year. It is important that this work should be gone on with. To me it seems absurd to have this small tank of about 40 barrel capacity at an institution of this kind, and the expense of putting an overflow such as we have there has been very great.

5. The chapel stairs are necessary and I would recommend that they be supplied. The cost of this is estimated at $110.00.

6. Battleship Linoleum in Kitchen and Scullery. As there are cement floors in the kitchen and scullery, I am of the opinion that this linoleum is necessary.

7. The two outside galleries asked for are necessary. I would recommend that they be constructed at a cost of $1470.

8. The request for a deafening quilt between the floors is not recommended. This would cost at least $1000.00 and would be little or no improvement. This money can well be saved.

The documents forwarded with your letter are returned herewith.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
MEMORANDUM FROM REV. FATHER DELMAS.

COPY.

WATER SYSTEM.

In order to make sure of having sufficient quantity of water, I would ask you to grant that our pressure tanks be temporarily placed in the garage so that the water from well no 1 be taken to these tanks as specified. I believe that the pump and engine which we use every day are in sufficiently good order to continue this work. Only the air pipes from the old building to the new, for which no provision was made in the specifications will be required.

I would ask you also that water be taken from well no. 2 as this water is of superior quality, clearer, softer, and in sufficient quantity. It is the water from this well which the contractors are using for the cement and mortar; the small pump has been kept constantly going for 10 hours per day, and the water has not given out. This water when once boiled is like rain water and scales made on the pipes are soft while the scales of no. 1 well are as hard as stone.

2. For this purpose there is needed a brick house of 12 x 14 large enough for an electric motor water pump and air pump. A 2 H.P. electric power should be placed in order to give an automatic supply of water.

3. Outside stairs from end to the chapel are necessary for Indians who come from the reserves.

4. We are also in need of a cistern for soft water outside the house. Our soil does not permit to dig down more than 9 ft. as at that depth we strike quick sand which caves in. To have a large supply of soft water for boilers, washing, engines. This cistern should be 24 ft. in diameter and should be connected with the metallic soft water tank specified on the plan.

5. Stairs that lead from the gallery to the chapel were forgotten in the plans. They are absolutely necessary so that the sisters and girls may enter the chapel and depart by this gallery.

6. I would recommend that a cork floor be put in the kitchen and scullery, in order that the fatigue of those working in these departments may be lessened.

7. I would likewise ask for a gallery on the west side of the building at the 1st floor, for the use of the weak or sick sisters and children. This should be enclosed with sliding windows and screens.

8. In order to deaden the noise of the house, we would be very grateful to you, if we could be permitted to place one thickness of deafening paper between the rough and finishing floor instead of building paper as specified.
Duck Lake, Sask., September 15th, 1924.

Mr. J. D. McLean,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wish to draw your attention to a number of matters in connection with the Duck Lake School, as follows:

1. The contractor recommends that a change be made in the floor drainage in the laundry. This will only cost $15.00. A rough sketch of what is necessary is attached hereto.

2. Fire Stations. On the first floor there are only two fire stations, one at each end of the main corridor, but I am of the opinion that another station should be installed in the corridor in front of the chapel, and hose would have to be supplied for this.

3. There is no mangle in the laundry according to the plan. One is necessary, and should be installed at the same time as the other machinery.

4. In connection with the three toilets in the basement, I wish to point out that the walls are not plastered, simply the tile walling. In my opinion it would be impossible to keep these places sanitary without having them plastered. Mr. Murray, the Provincial Sanitary Engineer, states that this is absolutely necessary. Mr. Smith states that the cost of the plastering would amount to about $188.00.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

W. H. Graham, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

The plumbing work which is being installed at
the new Indian school at Duck Lake was inspected a few days
ago by an official of this Division and I understand from the
report submitted that it is the intention to connect up the
drainage from the new building to the existing septic tank,
and filter bed.

An examination was made of the latter and it
would appear that the filter bed is in very bad repair. The
trays and galvanized iron distributing troughs are badly
broken with the result that the sewage does not pass through
the filter, but discharges from the septic tank without any
other form of treatment.

I have before me a blue print showing the
original design of the septic tank and filter bed of the
Duck Lake school, which I believe was installed ten years
ago. It would appear that during this period the sludge
has been emptied from the tank on only one or two occasions,
although I am informed that it was pumped out a few weeks ago.

I would point out that with the opening of the
new school and with the operation of over one hundred
plumbing fixtures the quantity of sewage will be considerably
increased and the maintenance of the disposal plant is a matter
which will require constant attention. The solids in the
settling tank should be pumped out at least twice yearly, in
the spring and in the fall, and the filter bed should be
reconstructed to conform to the original drawings.

It is possible that owing to the lack of fall
at the outlet there may be a tendency for the sewage to
freeze and this might be overcome by constructing a shallow
tank at the point where the sewage leaves the filter bed,
and placing a siphon in this tank which would cause the
sewage to be discharged at intervals, by means of a flush
and thus avoid the possibility of freezing. This last
recommendation is submitted merely as a suggestion.

The main object of my writing you is to insure
that the plant is overhauled and placed in proper repair
before the new building is opened.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) R. H. Murray
Director,
Division of Sanitation.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter that I received from R. H. Murray, Director, Division of Sanitation for the Province of Saskatchewan.

You will see from the letter that Mr. Murray recommends that the disposal vat be overhauled and put in repair. He claims it is not in good order, although I understand that Father Delmas was of the opinion that it was working satisfactorily. However, no doubt we will have to comply with the regulations of the province in this matter.

If you will authorize this work, I will take the matter up again with Mr. Murray and ask him what it will be necessary to do in order to meet the Provincial requirements.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan J. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
