Dear Mr. Graham:

Replying to your letter of the 22nd inst., with reference to the extra work asked for by the Rev. Father Delmas in connection with the new Duck Lake school, you may authorize the contractors to build a reinforced concrete cistern as outlined in their letter of the 15th, also stairs to chapel, the laying of Battleship linoleum on the floor of the kitchen and scullery and the building of two outside galleries at the school.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information a copy of their letter of the 15th inst.

With reference to your letter of the 23rd inst., you may authorize the contractors to make the change in the floor drainage in the laundry, also to provide an additional stand pipe for fire protection in the corridor in front of the Chapel, complete with hose.

Regarding the mangle mentioned in your letter I would ask you to please advise me the size and probable cost of a suitable mangle.

Regarding the plastering the walls of the toilets in the basement, you may authorize the contractors to proceed with this work.

With reference to your letter of the 22nd inst., regarding the report of Mr. Murray, Director, Division of Sanitation for the Province of Saskatchewan regarding the septic tank you may make what arrangements you think necessary to put this tank in a condition satisfactory to the Provincial Government.

Yours truly,

W.A. Graham, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to say that I returned from Duck Lake yesterday, having gone there to straighten out difficulties existing between the contractors and the inspector.

The inspector on this job is a man who I would say has a good knowledge of general building, but has had little experience in the work that he is now doing, that is, supervising construction. He speaks very poor English, and does not appear to have the faculty of imparting his instructions to the different foremen on the job. He has a fault and that is that he is probably too exacting in details; however, it is better to err on this side than to be the other way. There was a certain amount of work that he let pass without personally supervising it and when he found out it had not been done properly he had all the work torn up. I refer to the drainage. He was supposed to inspect all drain pipes before they were covered; he did not do this and when he found that one or two joints had not been properly done he ordered the whole of the pipes uncovered. The contractors, on the other hand, say that he passed the pipes. There were a number of little matters of this kind, causing a continual wrangling.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
With regard to the bricks, Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson were six to eight thousand brick short on the original lot decided upon for the veneering of this building. They tried to obtain the same kind of brick as that originally purchased, but were unable to do so; however, they got a very good substitute and, in my opinion, a brick equally as good. They paid $2.00 per A more for them than they did for the first lot which was passed by the Department. The inspector thought these bricks not equal to sample. I had them tested and find that they are practically the same brick. I also had them examined by the architect of the Provincial Government here, who expresses the opinion that they are the same. I then had them examined by Mr. Punten, Public School Architect, and he is of the same opinion. I saw some of these bricks placed in the wall and my opinion is that it would take an expert to see any difference. In view of this I authorized the contractor to go ahead and use them.

There is another matter that requires attention, and that is the matter of the placing of the roof on this school. I understand the plans do not give the detail, merely show where the water pipes are to lead from the roof. Mr. Punten tells me that it would be a mistake to have these down pipes so near the end walls. There will be a rush of water to this opening at times which is bound to reach the brick-work if the tar, pitch and gravel should fall away with heat and rain. He tells me this is not done on first class buildings, and Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson, who brought the matter to my attention first, asked me to see whether the Government would not change this. They tell me they have a building in Saskatoon where they took every precaution to guard against water getting into the wall and in spite of this it has cost them a lot of money to keep the building in any kind of shape. The suggestion of the contractors is that they put in two 6" down pipes, and one 4" pipe. The cost of these pipes will be just as great as the six 4" specified. They claim it will be an advantage in that there will only be three pipes running through the building instead of six. Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson claim that the fall of this roof to the pipes must be absolutely correct, otherwise the Garrett people will not guarantee the roof.
Duncan J. Scott, Esq.

Sept. 30, 1924

I would be glad to have your authority by wire if you decide to act on the suggested changes.

I may say that there will be no additional cost.

Sketches of the roof are being mailed to you under separate cover.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram which reads as follows:

"Obtain and submit to the Department competitive prices for installing a ten horse power engine five K.W. direct current one hundred and ten volts generator three hundred and twenty ampere hour battery switch board complete and countershaft to laundry machinery for Duck Lake School. Prices should be obtained for both fully automatic plants and for non-automatic."

With reference to the above, I cannot see how you can use an automatic plant at this school, as the engine has to be connected to a countershaft for driving the laundry machinery. Should an automatic plant be installed you cannot use your drive through this countershaft, as the automatic end of your engine is of no use. It can only be a direct driven engine through counter-shaft to laundry machinery and generator.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Mr. Scott:

The question of batteries to be used in connection with the lighting plant at the Duck Lake School is one that should receive serious consideration by the Department.

I am told by experts that there is a great deal of difference in batteries, and if the Department should decide to install a thin plate battery, as it did in the case of Punnichy and Lebret, a serious mistake would be made. Both these batteries are now out of commission. They will not stand up against inexperienced handling, and even with expert handling the life of a thick plate battery would be double that of a thin plate.

As far as the initial cost of installing the thick plate battery as compared with the thin plate is concerned, it is made up merely in the price of the battery.

In view of our experience at Punnichy and Lebret I would strongly advise the Department to consider nothing but the thick plate battery.

In

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
In the case of the batteries at Lebret which have gone out of commission in a short period of time, the Hart people's representative was here and the reason which he advanced for the rapid depreciation of these batteries was that the thin plate were used instead of thick plate. I can hardly agree with him, however, that the thin plate batteries should have exhausted themselves in such a short period of time, and I am told that when the representative was at Lebret he pointed out to the Principal that they had had a poor run of batteries and apparently those installed at Lebret were deficient to begin with.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir,  

I have today received telegram on Lister Brunton Automatic Plant for St Michael's School Duck Lake Sask and although it does not conform with the specifications on your telegram nor yet take care of your actual lighting load nor battery requirements I at least give you the price for you to decide.  

Engine- one Lister 2 cylinder IO HP vertical water cooled enclosed type petrol engine speed 550 RPM  
Dynamo- An open protected type shunt wound having an capacity of 55 amperes at 110 volts.  
Battery- 56 cells of 60 amperes  
Price installed Duck Lake Sask. $3200.00  

You will note no mention is made of countershaft as required in your letter as this is necessary for driving the laundry machinery. The amount I have allowed on my last tender for same is $110.00.  

You must also bear in mind that the connected load of the School is 120 amperes for light alone while this plant is only capable of 60 amperes a difference of one half. As your battery is only 60 amps and your load 120 amps your battery would only remain charged one half hour, while the other battery would remain for two and three quarter hours.  

To be more clear on the output this plant has an output of 300 lamps of 20 watts each while the fixtures selected is 300 lamps of 40 watt each just double. This plant is a splendid plant and can give splendid service but no plant is made to give double the service than what it is sold for without charging a higher price. I am quite willing to install this plant as quoted in a first class manner but bear in mind it is not to your specification.  

Yours truly  

[Signature]

St. Michael's Indian School,
Duck Lake, Sask., Oct. 4th., 1924.

To the Secretary of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit my fortnightly report on the Construction of the new School at Duck Lake.

All outside brick walls are completed. All partitions in Basement, Ground Floor and first floor are completed, also lathing on three floors.

Steel staisms and fire escapes nearly completed. Water pipes and sewers completed. White enamel bricks all set in kitchen and scullery.

Steam and water pipes are put in up to third floor. Boilers also are set. Chapel's roof completed. All sashes have been painted.

Material on grounds: all plumbing, fixtures and radiators.

Remarks (1) A car of bricks delivered on the grounds was not satisfactory to me as being too soft. I reported same and sent you a sample, which you also ascertained as not being up to sample submitted by the contractors and not to be accepted. A sample of these bricks was examined at Regina and declared to be of very poor quality; nevertheless by a telegram from the Indian Commissioner of Regina, Mr. W.M. Graham, these bricks were to be used after having been selected.

(2) On specifications it is not said to put paper on both sides of the walls of the corridor going to the chapel. A ply of building paper on the inside walls before being plastered and a ply on the outside walls before receiving stucco will prove warmer. The cost is not very high.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.

October 13, 1924.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letters with reference to the installing of electric lighting plant at the Duck Lake School, I have to say that I approve of installing a plant as outlined in the enclosure submitted with your letter of the 30th ultimo using thick plate batteries referred to and recommended in your letter of the first instant.

I also approve of having the installation made by Mr. M. Wylie, but before you authorize him to proceed with the work he should be instructed to obtain prices from the different manufacturers of engines, generators, and storage batteries and submit same to you for consideration. When you have received these you may authorize him to install the equipment which you think would give the best service. It is advisable, however, to give every opportunity to the various manufacturers to submit prices before the plant is decided upon.

When you have decided on the plant to be installed kindly instruct Mr. Wylie to furnish the Inspector of Construction at the school with a sketch showing the layout of the proposed installation in order that he may make arrangements to provide a suitable concrete foundation bed for same.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

To the Secretary of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit my fortnightly report on the construction of the new School at Duck Lake.

1. All inside and outside brick work completed.
2. All inside carpenter's rough work completed.
3. Lathing also is completed.

One coat of plaster is put on all partitions and two coats up to ground floor. All steam pipes finished.
Boilers all completed, also water pipes and waste pipe.
All storm sashes are painted, two coats, glazed and placed.

The roof was finished before the last rain storm so nothing was spoiled.
Excavation for soft water cistern completed.
Material on grounds: all plumbing, fixtures, radiators and lumber for the two extra galleries on first floor.

Two lights for each gallery are required.

Re-boilers: I would suggest that you give me instructions to make sure that only one man and the same one be in charge of the said boilers during the work. I would like also to know if it is safe to use hard water - from the well - for the boilers. That water makes hard scales inside of the flues.

Sincerely yours,

Extract from Inspector's Report on the DUCK LAKE Residential School, October 15th and 16, 1924.

At the request of the agent and Father Delmas I examined the classrooms in the new school and beg to point out the following needs as to furniture and equipment.

Our Department requires that all new seats shall be single and adjustable. It would be a pity to put the old ones in the beautiful new building. A suitable teacher's desk should be provided for each room. Blackboard space appears to be very limited according to the plans. Blackboards should be put along the entire side walls as well as at the front. In the two east classrooms the blackboards can be very satisfactorily hung in large frames. All blackboards should be four feet wide and 2½ feet from the floor. The specifications call for the front blackboards to be placed entirely too high. The Sisters cannot reach within a foot of the top. I would suggest that a low bench be built along the wall under this blackboard.

Abundance of book and cupboard space is a necessity in the modern classroom. I am suggesting that these be placed across the rear walls of the two west classrooms and along the walls in the corner spaces in the east classrooms.

Translucent blinds only are approved by our Department. These should be wide enough to extend a little onto the casing.

J. T. Tomlinson,
Insp.
Adrien Taillon, Esq.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
DUCK LAKE, Sask.

Dear Mr. Scott:

My attention has been drawn to the fact that the walls in the girls' and boys' recreation rooms at the new Duck Lake School are not to be plastered, and I would ask that you re-consider this matter and authorize me to have this work done. The Rev. Principal has been pressing for this, pointing out very properly that it is unsanitary, as they can never expect to keep the walls clean in their present condition; clouds of dust will rise up from the floors when the children are playing and settle in the roughness of the mortar and on the side of the tiles, in fact it will be impossible to keep the place in any kind of shape. The benches run around the walls and the children will have to sit with their backs up against these rough walls, which would certainly tear their clothing.

I have got a price from the contractors, and they tell me if we have the work done at once it will cost $375.00 for the two rooms. This is a trifling expenditure considering the great advantage of having the walls plastered. You will remember that I drew your attention to the fact that the walls in the closets and wash room were being left in the same condition and you authorized me to have them plastered. Had I known when I made this request that the recreation rooms were not being plastered I would have recommended that they be done at the same time.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The plastering contractors are now on the job, and will be there for three weeks. If you could authorize me by wire I would have this work done.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, Nov. 15, 1924.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Interior walls of recreation rooms specified to be finished in brick. This is considered more serviceable than plastered walls and was agreed to by Father Delmas. If he has changed his views you may arrange for plastering. May purchase new range required for school.

Duncan C. Scott.

Chg. D.I.A.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., NOV. 11TH, 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to draw to your attention the fact that additional stabling accommodation will have to be provided at the Duck Lake Boarding School, in the way of a cattle barn to hold at least thirty head of cows. The stable on the old site is pretty well beyond further use, but in addition to this it is situated about half a mile from the new site.

In addition to the above building, some kind of a store house will have to be provided. This need not be an expensive building. A house of at least six rooms is required for the married Farming Instructor. A root house is also necessary.

I understand that these matters were brought to your attention in January, last, and as no definite instructions have been received from you, and the school is nearing completion, I again bring the matter before you to see what action should be taken.

Yours very truly,

V. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

I beg to send you my fortnightly report on the construction work of the new Indian School at Duck Lake. The work is going on well. On ground floor, first & second floor and chapel plastering is completed. On basement floor, concrete steps, concrete foundations for engines, generator finished. Also two coats of concrete on the walls. Engine and generator set in place. Metallic ceiling work started. Cistern & galleries completed. Finishing work started on ground floor. All the work is finished in the building but flooring. About thirty men are working.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.
R. Guerney Orr, Esq.,
Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr,

Re Duck Lake Indian School:

We expect to finish up the above contract very early in the new year. There is one matter which we would be obliged if you would take up with Mr. Scott; that is with reference to the temporary heating. This of course is called for in the specifications to be supplied by us, but we feel we should have an allowance made for the time lost between the date the tenders were received; that was June 9th; and the date we received orders that we could start on the contract, which was July 2nd; approximately three weeks. This loss of time put us back more than the three weeks, and had we been able to have started right away, the building would have been so far advanced that instead of being finished, as we said before, early in the new year, it would not have been later than the end of November.

We, of course, are quite willing to abide by the decision of your Department, but we feel we should mention this matter, and we feel sure you will see the fairness of our request and make an allowance for, say, the three weeks temporary heating.

After you have placed this matter before Mr. Scott, we would be pleased to hear from you.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.,
per

Dear Sir,

I beg to send you my fortnightly report on the construction work of the New Indian School at Duck Lake. The work is going on very satisfactorily.

The plastering, concrete flooring & steps are completed. Trim on ground floor and chapel completed. Doors hung, windows placed and stained.

On ground floor metallic ceiling finished; it has received one coat of paint (ivory color).

Doors & trim are stained (golden oak) Plumbing in kitchen and scullery are completed. Boys' toilet and wash room have proper fixtures in place; girls' toilet and wash room also.

All steam pipes are completed, ready for radiators.

Electric wiring and all fixtures are completed.

Material in building: flooring and all necessary material to finish the job.

20 men are still working.

Yours sincerely,

Adrien Tailor

Inspector of Construction.
December 16, 1924.

MEMO FOR FILE:

It is understood that the Department is acquiring at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School the 710 acres more or less, buildings, equipment, and live stock, with the exception of the old main building and its equipment. The only equipment of the old main building which is available for our use in the new building is school desks, books, etc., and the drug dispensary complete.

The church and the cemetery remain the property of the Oblate Fathers, as they are retaining title to one acre on which they are situate.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Superintendent General of Indian Education,
OTTAWA,
Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have asked Reverend Father Plourde to take up with you the question of the purchase of another of our four Indian Schools. The purchase of Kenora being completed and the necessary funds having been provided for the purchase of Lestock, we still have two schools to dispose of, namely: Camperville and Crooked Lake.

I am desirous of disposing of Camperville School in the coming year, and Reverend Father Plourde will give you personally the reasons which prompt me to ask for its purchase.

Knowing the very keen interest you have taken in all the affairs pertaining to our Indian Schools, I trust and hope that we may deserve a continuance of your patronage.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Provincial.
Dear Mr Scott,

Reverend Father Plourde is just leaving for Ottawa. He is going to speak to your Department of our dear Indian schools. Two of them have already been bought by the Government and, according to the promises made, another has to be bought this year. I hope that you will help to have that done, because it is for the good of these poor children. You know it better than anyone else.

I thank you in advance for the help you will give us and I can assure you that you can count on my sincere gratitude.

Yours thankful and devoted,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

With reference to the attached letter from His Grace Archbishop Mathieu, of Regina, I have to report that I am including in the Estimates an amount of $75,000.00 to purchase the school at Pine Creek. If you approve of this item and if it is finally included in the Estimates, there will be no difficulty in carrying out the purchase.

Deputy Superintendent General.
May 9, 1924.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

In the Estimates for Indian Education there is an item for $150,000 for the erection of a new main building at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, south of Prince Albert, Sask. The Oblate Fathers have title to the 700 acres which have been used in conjunction with the school for some years and which are necessary for its satisfactory conduct in the future.

I have had an interview with the Provincial Head of the Order and have been corresponding with him, with a view to the transfer of this farm to the Crown. The Oblate Fathers have now made a definite proposal, which is in brief that the Department purchase, before building operations, 100 acres which is the site of the buildings, at a nominal price of $10 per acre and agree to the purchase of the other 600 acres of the property at $50 an acre, as soon as the necessary appropriation can be provided.

Prior to 1911, when the institution with 100 acres was transferred from the Crown to the Oblate Fathers for a nominal consideration, the Department expended more than $20,000 for buildings and equipment. During the 30 years that this school has been in operation, the school farm grew in size and value while the institution was largely financed by per capita grants from parliamentary Appropriation.

As the Department has been associated with the Oblate Fathers in the capital and current expenses for many years, I consider that the 600 acre farm should be offered the Crown at a more reasonable price. I should be pleased to have your instructions, so that I may reply to the Provincial Head's proposal.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dr. Scott

I agree with you, that the Oblate Fathers are asking an unreasonable price for this farm. You might mention the matter to me when you are in the office again.

May 15, 24.
Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Re Duck Lake School Property.

With further reference to my memorandum of May 8th on this question, I beg to report that now that the authority of His Excellency has been obtained to enter into a contract with the lowest tenderer, Smith Brothers & Wilson, of Regina, for the erection of this school, it becomes pressingly important to decide on the price to be paid for the property. You will note in my memorandum of May 8th the suggestions that were made by the Provincial of the Oblate Order. If his suggestions were met we would pay as follows for the property:

| Acres | Price per Acre | Total |
|-------|----------------|-------|
| 320   | $50.00         | $16,000.00 |
| 297   | $50.00         | $14,850.00 |
| 100   | $10.00         | $1,000.00 |

Total: $31,850.00

For the reasons previously given, I think this price is too high. There is no special point in having a reduction on the value of the one hundred acres on which the buildings are to be situated, and I think we might fix a price per acre for the whole 717 acres. You might care to consider an offer of $25,000.00 for the whole property, or at the rate of $30.00 an acre, $21,510.00, or at the rate of $25.00 an acre, $17,925.00. The authorities of the Oblate Order should give greater weight to the fact that there has been close co-operation and financial assistance in the conduct of this school. This real estate cannot be considered as the property of the Order self-improved and developed, and there would be no cogency in making an invidious comparison between what was paid at Edmonton and Claresholm; at the same time we must realize that the energy and administrative ability of the Order went far to develop the property.
I am inclined to think that they would accept the offer of $25,000.00, but I am not so sure that they would be willing to agree to the proposal to pay $25.00 an acre. Whatever price is decided upon, I think it should be accompanied by the intimation that unless it is accepted with the Departmental view of the dual nature of the interest, we could not go on with the building of the school.

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Archbishop's Palace,
Regina, Sask.
October 24, 1924.

My dear Mr. Scott:

I have again asked Reverend Father Plourde to go to Ottawa to see you in connection with the sale of the schools belonging to the Reverend Oblate Fathers. I need not relate again the reasons which prompted me to take such personal interest in this matter. They are well known to you and your sympathetic understanding of them has greatly facilitated the purpose I had in view.

So if I take the liberty of writing to you again, it is not that I am in the least doubtful of the final outcome, but I simply wish to prove you my interest in this matter has not waned in the least, and that I am as confident as ever that by the purchase of the Crooked Lake School, your Department will bring this entire transaction to a happy and final issue.

As this may be the last time that I have the pleasure of writing to you in this connection, I wish to take this opportunity of thanking you most sincerely for the great assistance you have been to me and to the Reverend Oblate Fathers. I feel confident that the steps taken by the Government will redound to your honor and good judgment and will materially help in the successful management of our Indian Schools.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
December 19, 1924.

My dear Archbishop Mathieu,

I beg to acknowledge Your Grace's letter of October 24th, and I have to assure you that the matters therein mentioned will receive my very best attention. We are now considering our estimates, and the needs of your schools will receive sympathetic attention.

I trust that Your Grace may be long spared to stimulate those interested in the work of Indian education, and I wish to send you the Season's Greetings.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Mt. Rev. O.E. Mathieu, D.D.,
Archbishop of Regina,
Archbishop's Palace,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, January 2, 1925.

305-11A

Sir:

With reference to your #109-1-5 dated the 2nd instant I beg to draw your attention to the abstract of tender which was forwarded to you on the 17th ultimo showing the competitive prices obtained for the Electrical Equipment installed at Duck Lake, and thereon you will note that the price of the equipment quoted by the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company was F.O.B. Duck Lake, whereas the price quoted by Messrs. Liston Bruston was F.O.B Winnipeg. As the freight charges from Winnipeg to Duck Lake would greatly exceed the difference in the two prices the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company quotation was the more favourable.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

Attention Architect:

I beg to call your attention to certain details in connection with the water-system now installed in the new building, and which have not been mentioned either in the plans or specifications, and which in my opinion are of all necessity and should be attended to without delay before the contractor delivers the building over as completed.

1. The water-system, as at present provided, is not complete. According to specifications, a large air-pressure tank, now in the old building, is to be removed to the new building, as a reservoir for water to be pumped from the well; but no provision has been made in the plumber's contract to make connections with this tank.

This air-pressure tank and its valves are in very good condition.

2. You are aware that a large cistern for soft water has been constructed, with a supply-pipe from same laid only as far as the floor of the laundry, and left in that condition is of no use. This should be connected with the Laundry Machinery, and could be done by placing a force-pump and an air-compression pump, which would pump the soft water into an air-compression tank, thence to be distributed to the different laundry machines and laundry tubs. This air-pressure tank can be supplied also from the old building.

The force-pump and the air-compression pump should be run by the power from the engine in the Electric-Light room.

Moreover, for the sake of keeping the two Heating-Boilers in good order and preventing incrustation, it would be a very good plan to supply these boilers with soft water instead of hard water pumped from the well, and for that purpose it would be necessary to make a few little changes or connections.
3. For the washing of the clothes in the laundry, it is absolutely necessary that the soft water also be heated and there is no provision for this. There is here a large galvanized-iron tank which could be very easily used for that purpose, by having same cut and connected with the air-pressure tank and the small upright boiler set up in the laundry, and from this tank a connection should be made to the laundry tubs, which are already provided with the necessary pipes and taps.

4. A mangle has been added to the laundry machinery; but no provision has been made to bring the steam to this particular machine, as it is needed for the proper operation of same.

I have sent a sketch of the above mentioned suggestions to the Plumbing Contractor at Regina, so that he may more readily understand and be prepared to give an estimate of the cost.

I am making these suggestions to the best of my knowledge, with the idea that if they be done now it would be saving to the Department. I therefore trust that you will favorably take up this matter, as I consider that the suggestions made by me are of all necessity for the proper working of the water-system so far installed in the new building.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Inspector of Works.

Dept of Indian Affairs,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

(Regarding Duck Lake School)

We have been asked by your Mr. Tallion Inspector on the above school to prepare an estimate on installing a system to supply Soft water to Laundry Machinery, Fixtures in Laundry Heating Boilers, and High Pressure Boiler. You will understand that you have now installed a large Soft Water Cistern placed outside of Building, where all rain water off roofs discharge into, and a suction pipe is installed from said cistern to a point in floor of laundry, but no provision is made to pump this water from cistern or to supply it to the various Fixtures or if there any provision made to heat this soft water for the laundry purposes. We are submitting a rough sketch showing how this could be done and how we would recommend same and will outline it as under plan one.

PLAN ONE

We will remove from old school a 800 gal. pressure tank that they have now on hand, and set it up along side of Hard water tank in Garage. Install one Electric Pumping unit complete with motor and Automatic switch, and Air Compressor. Connect Pump to Suction Line from Cistern, carry discharge from pump to the above 800 gal. storage Tank, carry Air Line to Pressure Tank and Connect to Various Laundry machinery and Laundry Tubs, also carry a line of Soft water to feed the two Tubiler Heating Boilers and the High pressure Boiler in laundry. Install one 85 gal. Hot water Tank with Coil Steam Coil. Run a line of Steam from High Pressure Boiler to Coil in Tank, taking care of Condensation from Coil with a Hot Trap, and carry Hot water from tank and connect to the fixtures in laundry. The cost as outlined above is $1013.00

PLAN #2

Exactly as Plan #1 other than we would use an old Range Boiler from old school in place of the 80 gal. tank with Steam Coil, and just run a steam line into it to heat the water, feeding the fixtures from it by Gravity the cost of plan #2 is $661.00.

PLAN #3

By using a power belt driven pumping unit in place of the Automatic Electric would mean a deduction of $75.00 from the price of either Plan #1 or Plan #2.

Yours sincerely,

ROANTREE & CO.
Per F.B. Roantree.
Sir:

I beg to draw to your attention the fact that we have now completed, at the Duck Lake Boarding School, a cistern with a capacity of about 1500 barrels, for the purpose of conserving the soft water and using it in the laundry and boilers.

The work of piping this water from the cistern to the laundry has been completed, but the question is to get this water pumped from the cistern to the various laundry fixtures and boilers.

I am enclosing herewith an offer from the H.B. Roantree & Company of Regina who have the plumbing contract for this building, and it seems to me that their specification is quite easily understood. It is for you to decide whether the work is to be proceeded with at once. I think it should, and I would recommend that Plan No. 1 be adopted.

If you will let me know by wire it will facilitate matters, as the men are leaving the school shortly.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Grant,
Indian Commissioner.

Enc.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Jan. 26, 1925.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Approve plan number one soft water supply Duck Lake.

J. D. McLean.

January 21st, 1925.

Forthnightly Report.
Re Indian Residential School Duck Lake Sask.

Everything is going along good, the work is advancing, I believe that by the first of February 1925 that the building will be completed.

All of the woodwork is now completed also the metallic ceilings.

The three upper stories are finished, all the woodwork is stained, the ground floor has received a coat of shellac and varnish, the floors in the three upper floors are finished with the exception of the floor in the chapel.

The plumbing and steam fitting will be completed in a week, we now have the steam in all parts of the building and same is working very well. We still have twenty-two men employed.

Respectfully submitted,

Adrian Tailon
Inspector of Construction.
Duck Lake Sask.
January 31st, 1925.

Ottawa Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As the work of the new school is almost completed, may I be allowed to present another suggestion to your Department?

It is about the concrete floors of the dining rooms and of the corridor leading to the same. Should an accident happen; should grease or gravy be spilled, the greasy spots would always show and after a few years the places mentioned would be a real disgrace.

To obviate to this, I would ask the Department to have the concrete floors covered with two coats of paint.

This should be done also for the toilets' floor to render the deodorizing possible.

After consulting the Catalogue of the Dominion Paint Works Ltd. and the prices of the local labour, I find that I could have two coats of paint applied to the different floors for the amount of $230.00. Please authorize me to buy the paint and to have this work executed.

Sincerely yours,

Adrien Taillon,
Inspector of Works.
Sir:

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter that I received from Adrien Taillon, Inspector of Works, Duck Lake Boarding School. If you fall in with the suggestion kindly advise me. Personally I think it should be done.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

Dear Sir,

I beg to call the attention of the Department that; the Contractors Smith Bros & Wilson completed their contract and they delivered me the building on Feb. 10th. Every thing is completed but the grading which Father Delmas agrees to finish in the spring. A cheque of $75.00 had been given by the contractors to Father Delmas to do that work.

When the last certificate shall be fixed up I will send it to the Department.

I have found necessary to hire a fireman to take care of boilers and keep the building warm and necessary also to buy wood and coal until Father Delmas is moving into. We are working now on washstands and cupboards.

As soon as the furnitures arrive, Father Delmas will move in.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sirs:

Re Certificate of Acceptance.

I, A. Tallon, Inspector of Construction of Duck Lake Indian Industrial School, hereby inform you that I have thoroughly inspected the said building for and on behalf of the Indian Department and beg to recommend:

(1st) That Main Switch and Distributing Board as described in clauses ten and eleven of Page 56 of the Electrical Specifications, be supplied at contractors' own cost as called for in the said clauses and that amount paid by the Department for the said parts, be refunded.

(2) The grading around the building, not being done at present time, the contractors shall be held responsible for any damage or deterioration occurring through natural causes between this date and the date of completion of said grading. The contractors are hereby requested to deposit sufficient funds with Rev. H. Delmas to cover cost of said work and security for performance of same.

To the best of my knowledge and belief, and excepting remarks and recommendations as above stated, the construction of the Duck Lake Indian Industrial School is now completed and I hereby accept same on behalf of the Indian Department.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Adrien Tallon,
Inspector of Construction for Duck Lake Indian School.

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., March 5th, 1925.

Sir:

Referring to your #109-1-5A dated the 26th ultimo, I beg to re-submit Regina Voucher #2661, in favour of Mr. Matthew Wylie, in its original form, and to ask the Department to re-consider the question of payment thereof.

I understand your letter to indicate that Mr. Wylie cannot be paid 10% of the amount which he puts in for wages for himself. I wish to explain that it is the custom in Western Canada, when work is performed on a basis of "cost plus 10%", that the percentage should be charged on every single item of expenditure, including the wages, if any, of the Principal who undertakes to do the work on that basis. It is a form of contract often employed when the jobs are small and the Principal invariably works on the job himself. In such instances he (in this case Mr. Wylie) could not sacrifice his time by supervising the work for only the amount of percentage which he would otherwise derive.

Mr. Wylie assumed charge of the work covered by the voucher, with the intention of being employed on it himself and receiving payment on the based percentage of all charges in connection therewith as customary in this country, and having assumed the work with this understanding I submit he is entitled to payment in the customary manner. I trust the Department will, therefore, pay the voucher, as there are other vouchers for work performed by Mr. Wylie on a similar basis which will shortly have to be submitted to the Department for payment.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Indian Commissioner

Dear Sir:

Re Indian Residential School
Duck Lake Saskatchewan

I herewith enclose Final Report in connection with construction and inspection of above building. Please note following items:

(1) Re putting of metal ceiling on the underside of Gallery in Chapel, I have deducted ($44.00) Forty Four Dollars, i.e., $30.00 for metal and $14.00 for lumber. I never gave instructions nor orders to have this particular work done and payment is hereby refused.

(2) Re fuel for heating building, I wish to allow an amount of $250.00 and no more. I consider latter a very reasonable allowance. Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith a final report and estimate for the work on the Duck Lake Boarding School, prepared by Mr. Adrien Taillon.

With reference to the first paragraph of the report, it seems to me there is not much in this protest of Mr. Taillon's. A joint was put up in the room where the lighting plant is installed, instead of metal ceiling, as called for. No charge was made for this. The metal that would have been used here was placed on the under side of the gallery in the chapel, which called for no ceiling, and where the joists were left exposed in the plan. I think the $44.00 charged for this is a just one.

Regarding the matter of the charge for fuel, you will note that Mr. Taillon reduces the account by $11.80. Smith Bros. & Wilson however contend that you gave them authority to include the sum of $331.80 in their extras, and it seems to me that this is a just claim and should be paid.

With regard to paragraph three, the Propeller Fan is not yet installed. I can get a marked cheque for $150.00 from Messrs Smith Bros. & Wilson, as a guarantee that it will be installed. If you see fit to send to me the cheque for the balance due the contractors, I will not hand it over until we get this work done. However, it will be finished within a few days, as I have been informed by Messrs Smith Bros. & Wilson.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
